(1)  To study current code relevant to the construction advisory board and make recommendations for changes and amendments; 
(2)  To review the current codes and potential for updating and adopting new codes to replace or extend the existing code; 
(3)  Make recommendations to resolve disputes with code interpretation and establish general policy for enforcement; 
(4)  Regularly review and monitor contract licensing and continuing education requirements including any initial licensing requirements, the qualifications for specific individual candidates for licensing and disciplinary action for current license holders. 
(5)  To act as the construction board of appeals. 
(6)  Except when acting as the construction board of appeals, the board will function in an advisory capacity only. The board's interpretations and recommendation will be subject to the approval of city staff and ultimately the governing body. The board's decisions but not recommendations shall be considered final if not appealed in writing to the governing body within ten days by the aggrieved party or if appealed by the city staff to the governing body within ten days. 
(7)  The board shall prioritize matters as requested by the governing body and investigate or not matters as requested by the governing body. 
(Ord. No. 3199, § 1, 2-15-2016) 
Secs. 18-35-18-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BUILDING INSPECTION DEPARTMENT[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Departments, § 2-141 et seq. 

Sec. 18-51. - Created. 
    There is hereby created a building inspection department, which shall be composed of the city inspector, who shall be appointed by the governing body, and such other assistants, officers and employees as may be deemed necessary for the best interest of the city and who shall be appointed by the city inspector, with the approval of the commissioner of streets and public utilities. The building inspection department shall have charge of and supervise all building, plumbing, electrical, liquefied petroleum gas systems and gas fitting inspections and shall perform all duties pertaining to such businesses or affairs of the city and as required by the ordinances relating thereto and shall make such reports to the governing body as may be required from time to time. 
(Code 1995, § 4-201) 
Sec. 18-52. - Qualifications of city inspector. 
    To be eligible to serve as city inspector, the candidate for such position shall have had experience as an architect, structural engineer, building inspector or superintendent of building construction, and shall be physically capable of making the necessary examinations and inspections. He shall not have any interests whatsoever, directly or indirectly, in the sale or manufacture of any material, process or device entering into or used in connection with building construction, alteration, removal and demolition. 
(Code 1995, § 4-202) 
Cross reference- Appointed officers and employees generally, § 2-81 et seq. 
Sec. 18-53. - Duties of city inspector. 
    Duties of the city inspector shall be as follows: 
(1)  He shall receive applications required by the building code incorporated by reference in section 18-101, and issue permits provided thereby, and he shall examine premises for which permits have been issued and shall make necessary inspections to see that the provisions of law are complied with and that construction is prosecuted safely. He shall enforce all provisions of the building code. He shall, when requested by proper authority or when the public's interest so requires, make investigations in connection with the matters referred to in the building code and render written reports on such investigations. To enforce compliance with law, remove illegal or unsafe conditions and secure the necessary safeguards during construction or to require adequate exit facilities in buildings and structures, he shall issue such notice or orders as may be necessary; 
(2)  Inspections required under the provisions of the building code shall be made by the city inspector or his assistant. The city inspector may accept reports of inspectors or recognized inspection services, after investigation of their qualifications and reliability; 
(3)  He shall keep comprehensive records of applications, permits issued, inspections made, reports rendered and notices or orders issued. He shall retain on file copies of required plans and all documents relating to building work as long as any part of the building or structure to which such plans and documents relate may be in existence. All such records shall be open to public inspection for good and sufficient reasons at the stated office hours, but shall not be removed from the office of the city inspector without his written consent; 
(4)  He shall, upon request, make written reports to his immediate superior, and boards and commissions established by the governing body of the city; 
(5)  He may, with the permission of the governing body of the city, authorize special building procedures and methods whenever the safety of persons and property will not be endangered. 
(Code 1995, § 4-203) 
Cross reference- Appointed officers and employees generally, § 2-81 et seq. 
Sec. 18-54. - Cooperation of other officials. 
    The city inspector may request and shall receive, as far as may be necessary, in the discharge of his duties, the assistance and cooperation of other officials of the city. 
(Code 1995, § 4-204) 
Sec. 18-55. - Right of entry. 
    The city inspector, in the discharge of his official duties and upon proper identification, shall have authority to enter any building, structure or premises at any reasonable hour. 
(Code 1995, § 4-205) 
Secs. 18-56-18-70. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PERMIT AND INSPECTION FEES 

Sec. 18-71. - Building permit fees. 
(a)  No building shall be erected, enlarged, converted or altered until a building permit has been issued by the city inspector, stating that the proposed use of the land, building or premises complies with the provisions of the building code and zoning regulations of the city. The charge for building permits shall be as follows: 
(1)  New residential structures, including apartments, dormitories, attached garages and finished basements, shall be as set by resolution of the governing body. 
(2)  Commercial and industrial structures and all other uses, including their usual accessory uses and additions thereto, shall be as set by resolution of the governing body. 
(3)  Noncommercial accessory buildings, sheds and other detached structures shall be as set by resolution of the governing body. 
(4)  Alterations and repairs, shall be as set by resolution of the governing body. 
(5)  Open faced commercial low hazard storage, shall be as set by resolution of the governing body. 
(b)  Where work for which a permit is required has been started prior to issuance of a permit, unless specifically approved by the city inspector, the fees provided for in subsection (a) of this section shall be doubled. The city inspector shall remit all fees received to the city clerk. 
(Code 1995, § 4-701; Ord. No. 2646, § 1(4-701), 11-29-1999; Ord. No. 2662, § 1, 4-10-2000; Ord. No. 3102, § 1, 5-20-2013) 
Cross reference- Building code, § 18-101 et seq. 
Sec. 18-72. - Electrical wiring inspection fees. 
    All installations of electrical wiring shall be subject to inspection by the city inspector as provided in the City Code, and the city inspector shall charge the following fees for such inspections, in addition to other fees: 
(1)  Permit fee shall be as set by resolution of the governing body. 
(2)  All new construction shall be as set by resolution of the governing body. 
(3)  Remodel or service charge shall be as set by resolution of the governing body. 
(Code 1995, § 4-704; Ord. No. 2646, § 1(4-704), 11-29-1999; Ord. No. 3102, § 1, 5-20-2013) 
Cross reference- Electrical code, § 18-171 et seq. 
Sec. 18-73. - Mechanical system inspection fees. 
    All mechanical systems installation shall be subject to inspection and subsequent inspection fees shall be as set by resolution of the governing body. 
(Code 1995, § 4-703; Ord. No. 2645, § 1(4-703), 11-22-99; Ord. No. 3102, § 1, 5-20-2013) 
Cross reference- Gas piping and venting code, § 18-311 et seq. 
Sec. 18-74. - Plumbing inspection fees. 
    All plumbing installations shall be subject to inspection by the city inspector, who shall charge, in addition to other fees, the fees and expenses as set from time to time by resolution of the governing body. 
(Code 1995, § 4-702; Ord. No. 2646, § 1(4-702), 11-29-1999; Ord. No. 3102, § 1, 5-20-2013) 
Cross reference- Plumbing code, § 18-541 et seq. 
Sec. 18-75. - Sign inspections. 
    All advertising signs erected within the city shall be subject to inspection by the city inspector, who shall charge an inspection fee as set by resolution of the governing body. 
(Code 1995, § 4-705) 
Cross reference- Signs, § 18-861 et seq. 
Secs. 18-76-18-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BUILDING CODE[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Building permit fees, § 18-71. 

Sec. 18-101. - International Building Code incorporated. 
    A certain document, three copies of which are on file in the office of the city clerk, being marked and designated as the International Building Code, 2009 edition, [including Appendix Chapter C, entitled "Group U - Agricultural Buildings" (see International Building Code Section 101.2.1, 2009 edition)], as published by the International Code Council, be and is hereby adopted as the building code of the City of McPherson, Kansas for regulating and governing the conditions and maintenance of all property, buildings and structures; by providing the standards for supplied utilities and facilities and other physical things and conditions essential to ensure that structures are safe, sanitary and fit for occupation and use; and the condemnation of buildings and structures unfit for human occupancy and use and the demolition of such structures as herein provided; providing for the issuance of permits and collection of fees therefor; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of said Building Code on file in the office of the City of McPherson, Kansas are hereby referred to, adopted, and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this ordinance, with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if any, prescribed in sections 18-103 of this article. 
(Code 1995, § 4-206; Ord. No. 2577, § 1(4-206), 3-????-1998; Ord. No. 2738, § 1(4-206), 6-24-2002; Ord. No. 2966, § 1, 8-11-2008; Ord. No. 3094, § 1, 5-20-2013) 
State Law reference- Adoption by reference, K.S.A. 12-3009 et seq., 12-3301 et seq.; building codes constituting compliance with state fire code, K.S.A. 31-134a. 
Sec. 18-102. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3094, § 2, adopted May 20, 2013, deleted § 18-102, which pertained to definitions used in Article III and derived from Code 1995, § 4-209. 
Sec. 18-103. - Amendments. 
(a)  The following sections [of the International Building Code] are hereby revised: 
Section 101.1. Insert: The City of McPherson for [Name of Jurisdiction] 
Section 1612.3. Insert: The City of McPherson for [Name of Jurisdiction] 
Section 1612.3. Insert: September 16, 1982 for [Date of Issuance] 
Section 3412.2. Insert: February 15, 1949 (being the effective date of adoption of Uniform Building Code in the City of McPherson) 
(b)  The following sections of the International Building Code, 2009 Edition, are hereby modified for application within the corporate limits of the city as follows: 
(1)  Section 105.1 shall be amended to read as follows: 
Section 105.1. Permits required. It shall be unlawful for any person to erect, construct, enlarge, alter, repair, move, improve, remove, convert or demolish any building or structure regulated by this code or any electrical, mechanical, plumbing or fire prevention or suppression system device or feature regulated by any city ordinance or regulation, or cause such work to be done without first obtaining a separate permit for each building or structure from the building official. 
(2)  Section 1012.3 is hereby amended to read as follows: 
Section 1013.2 Height. Any reference to "adjacent fixed seating" is hereby deleted. 
(3)  Section 1807.1 is hereby amended to read as follows: 
Section 1805.1. General. Footings, foundations and foundation walls, unless otherwise specifically provided, shall be constructed of reinforced concrete and shall extend below the ground surface outside the building a minimum depth of 30 inches. Foundations supporting wood shall extend at least six inches above the adjacent finished grade. 
(4)  The expansive and relatively weak soil conditions existing within the entire city is determined by the governing body and the building inspector to require a spread footing 24 inches wide and 12 inches deep or as provided in table 1805.4.2, whichever is greater. All footings shall have three no. 4 longitudinal reinforcing bars unless more are required under other sections of this code. 
(5)  All continuous foundation wall sections that exceed the following length per wall thickness shall be reinforced laterally with buttress/deadman and/or double row of concrete reinforcing steel: 
Wall Thickness (inches) Length (feet) 8 20 10 32 12 42  
(6)  Section 1805.5 is hereby amended to read as follows: 
Section 1805.5. Bearing walls. Bearing walls shall be supported on concrete foundations or piles, or other approved foundation systems, which shall be sufficient in size to support all loads. Where a design is not provided, the minimum requirements for stud bearing walls shall be the greater of those set forth in section 1805.1 or table 1805.4.2. 
Exceptions: 
1.  A one-story wood or metal frame building, not used for human occupancy and not over 400 square feet in floor area, may be constructed, with walls supported on a wood foundation plate that is anchored to the ground, when approved by the building official. 
2.  The support of buildings by posts embedded in earth shall be designed as specified in section 1805.7. Wood posts or poles embedded in earth shall be pressure treated with an approved preservative. 
(Code 1995, § 4-207; Ord. No. 2557, § 1, 6-2-1997; Ord. No. 2577, § 1(4-207), 3-????-1998; Ord. No. 2738, § 1(4-207), 6-24-2002; Ord. No. 2966, §§ 2, 3, 8-11-2008; Ord. No. 3094, §§ 2, 3, 5-20-2013) 
Sec. 18-104. - Responsibility for enforcement. 
    The enforcement of this article and the building code incorporated in section 18-101 by reference shall be under the direction and supervision of the city inspector. 
(Code 1995, § 4-210) 
Cross reference- Appointed officers and employees generally, § 2-81 et seq. 
Sec. 18-105. - Fees required to be paid prior to issuance or amendment of permits. 
    No permit as required by the building code shall be issued until the fees set by resolution of the governing body have been paid. 
(Code 1995, § 4-211; Ord. No. 3102, § 1, 5-20-2013) 
Sec. 18-106. - Violations. 
    Any person who shall violate the provisions of the International Building Code, as currently adopted by the city, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 2738, § 3, 6-24-2002; Ord. No. 3102, § 1, 5-20-2013) 
Sec. 18-107. - General contractor licensing. 
    These sections, [sections 18-107-18-122], are referred to as the "contractor licensing ordinance." All definitions in this section shall apply to the contractor licensing ordinance. 
    Agent shall mean an individual that has the authority to act on behalf of another. 
    Building official shall mean the city designated authority charged with the administration and enforcement of building codes of any kind or nature or the building official's duly authorized representative. 
    Building shall mean any structure used or intended for supporting or sheltering any use or occupancy. 
    Board or construction advisory board of trades and board of appeals (board) shall have the meaning provided in Code section 18-31 et. seq. 
    Contractor shall mean any person, firm, partnership, corporation, association, or other entity or any combination thereof, who for compensation undertakes within the city, to build, construct, alter, remodel, repair, or demolish any building or any portion thereof, for which a permit from the city is required including general contractors, building contractors, residential contractors, concrete contractors and framing contractors. Unless specifically provided otherwise by this contractor licensing ordinance, only a contractor licensed herein may obtain, directly or indirectly, a building permit. 
    Designated representative shall mean an individual that may obtain a license on behalf of a firm and will be the qualifying party of the firm if the individual meets the minimum requirements defined herein. 
    Qualifying experience shall require an individual to have worked within the specific license category for the requisite time period. Individuals must be experienced workers fully qualified and able to perform the trade without supervision. All experience claims must be verifiable by a qualified and responsible person, such as a contractor, a building official, an architect or an engineer. 
    Qualifying party shall mean the individual who meets the experience and examination requirements for a license. Every license must have a qualifying party. 
    Structure shall mean that which is built or constructed, an edifice or building of any kind, or any piece of work artificially built up or composed of parts joined together in some definite manner. 
    Code training hours shall mean actual hours of verifiable hours of training that pertains directly to city building codes and taught by a qualified professional in their area of expertise. Training receiving .1 CEU shall equal one Code training hours. 
    Certificate of competency shall mean the successful completion with a score of 75 or higher on class specific contractor license exam published and supported by the International Code Council of a cycle year at or newer than the current adopted code cycle for the city. 
(Ord. No. 3215, § 1, 6-20-2016) 
Sec. 18-108. - License required. 
    Unless specifically exempted, no building permit shall be issued to any contractor who has not first obtained a license or who is delinquent in payment of his annual license fee, or whose license has been suspended or revoked by action of the board. It is further unlawful for any person to enter into a contract with another so as to bring himself under the classification of a contractor as defined in this article, or to perform any work as a contractor, or any work under a contract, without having first obtained a contractor's license. Further, it is unlawful for any person issued a license as required by this article to contract to perform any work other than specified by such license. Contractor applicants shall be licensed by satisfying the requirements in either section 18-111, 18-112, or 18-113. A license will be granted once all information as submitted is verified. 
(Ord. No. 3215, § 1, 6-20-2016) 
Sec. 18-109. - Exclusions. 
    The following persons are not "contractors" within the meaning of this contractor licensing ordinance. 
(a)  An employee or agent working for and under the supervision of a contractor licensed under this article for the type of construction, alteration, repair or demolition being undertaken; and 
(b)  A homeowner who personally occupies or will occupy and undertakes the construction, alteration, repair or maintenance of such homeowner's single-family residence or an accessory structure thereto. Notwithstanding the foregoing, for purposes of this section, any homeowner who undertakes the construction of a new residence for such homeowner's personal occupancy more than three times in any four year period shall be deemed to be a "contractor" under this article. 
(Ord. No. 3215, § 1, 6-20-2016) 
Sec. 18-110. - Contractor responsible for all work. 
    Upon issuance of a building permit to a contractor, such contractor shall be responsible to the city for all work undertaken pursuant to such building permit, including work done by the contractor's employees, agents, and subcontractors. Notwithstanding the above, nothing in this contractor licensing ordinance shall be used to establish a standard of care or negligence involving any civil litigation between private parties. 
(Ord. No. 3215, § 1, 6-20-2016) 
Sec. 18-111. - Contractor licenses. 
    There are four separate classes of licenses for contractors in this section. 
    Class A Commercial: A "Class A Commercial" license shall entitle the holder thereof to construct, remodel, repair, demolish any structure and perform work described in Class D, building specialties of framing and concrete. A Class A Commercial license requires six years of qualifying experience within the commercial construction industry. The holder thereof must also have a certificate of competency or equivalent reasonably acceptable to the lead building inspector and/or the board or, hold a bachelor's degree in engineering, architecture, or construction science from an accredited institution of higher learning. The license and renewal fee shall be as set by resolution of the governing body and will also require 30 code training hours (three CEU) per license period. 
    Class B Commercial: A "Class B Commercial" license shall entitle the holder thereof to construct, remodel, repair, demolish any structures not exceeding three stories in height and perform work described in Class D, Building specialties of framing and concrete. A Class B Commercial license will also entitle the holder to perform non-structural remodeling, tenant finish, and repairs of all structures. A Class B Commercial license requires four years of qualifying experience within the commercial construction industry. The holder thereof must also have a certificate of competency or equivalent reasonably acceptable to the lead building inspector and/or the board; or, hold a bachelor's degree in engineering, architecture, or construction science from an accredited institution of higher learning. The license and renewal fee shall be as set by resolution of the governing body and will also require 30 code training hours (three CEU) of continuing education per license period. 
    Class C Residential: A "Class C Residential" license shall entitle the holder thereof to construct, remodel, repair, and demolish single family or duplex residences, buildings accessory thereto and perform work described as Class D, Building specialties of framing and concrete. A Class C Residential license requires four years of experience within the industry. The holder thereof must also have a certificate of competency or equivalent reasonably acceptable to the lead building inspector and/or the board or, hold a bachelor's degree in engineering, architecture, or construction science from an accredited institution of higher learning. The license and renewal fee shall be as set by resolution of the governing body and will also require 20 code training hours (two CEU) of continuing education per license period. 
    Class D Specialties: "Class D Specialty" licenses shall entitle the holder to perform one or both of the services below as shown on their license: 
a.  Framing contractor: A framing contractor license shall entitle the holder thereof to frame a structure or building, including bearing walls and non-bearing walls, and including repair to any of the above. A framing contractor license requires a minimum of four years qualifying experience within the construction industry. 
b.  Concrete contractor: A concrete contractor license shall entitle the holder thereof to perform general concrete work to include the placing and erecting of steel bars for the reinforcing of foundations, pavement, flat and other concrete work. A concrete contractor license requires a minimum of four years of concrete placing, erecting, and structural experience within the construction industry. 
    The license and renewal fee shall be as set by resolution of the governing body and will also require ten code training hours (one CEU) of continuing education per license period. 
(Ord. No. 3215, § 1, 6-20-2016) 
Sec. 18-112. - Local licensing. 
(a)  Requirements to obtain a Local Class B Commercial license shall be: 
(1)  Minimum of six years in commercial construction as an employee of a commercial construction company performing various tasks common to the construction industry to include a minimum of two years management at a level of foreman or above. 
(2)  Special building limitations to the Local Class B Commercial license will be: 
a.  No new structure/building project to be over a single story; 
b.  No commercial addition to a structure/building project to be over a single story; and 
c.  Structural alterations to buildings over a single story will not be allowed. 
(3)  A Local Class B Commercial license is considered a Conditional Class B Commercial license until there are 20 code training hours (two CEU) directly related to commercial construction within 24 months of application and the granting of Conditional Class B Commercial Contractor's License. The conditional license can also become a regular Class B Commercial Contracting License with the completion of the full requirements stated in section 18-111. 
(4)  Once the experience and code training hour requirements are met within the 24 months, the Conditional Class B Commercial license will become a Local Class B Commercial license with all special building limitations remaining in force. 
(5)  The Local Class B Commercial license may not allow for reciprocating licensing in other jurisdictions without further testing. 
(b)  Qualifications for Local Class C Residential can be accomplished with the following: 
(1)  Minimum of four years in residential construction performing layout, foundation set ups and foundations, framing, and roofing tasks as are typical in the residential construction industry. 
(2)  The Local Class C Residential license is considered conditional until there are 20 code training hours (two CEU) of training within 24 months of application and granting of Conditional Class C Residential Contractor's License. 
(3)  Once the experience and the code training hour requirements are met within the conditional license period of 24 months, the Conditional Class C Residential license will become a Local Class C Residential license. 
(4)  The Local Class C Residential license may not allow for reciprocating licensing in other jurisdictions without further testing. 
(Ord. No. 3215, § 1, 6-20-2016) 
Sec. 18-113. - Conditional licensing. 
(a)  Qualifications for a Conditional Class B Commercial license can be accomplished with the following: 
(1)  Minimum of two consecutive years verifiable commercial construction as a business owner/operator in the City of McPherson immediately before the date of the application. 
(2)  Minimum of four years total commercial construction experience. 
(3)  Special building limitations to the Conditional Class B General Contractor's License will be: 
a.  No new structure/building project to be over a single story; 
b.  No commercial addition to a structure/building project to be over a single story; and 
c.  Structural alterations to buildings over a single story will not be allowed. 
(4)  The conditional license will become a Local Class B Commercial or Class B Commercial Contracting License with the completion of the full requirements stated in section 18-111 or 18-112. 
(5)  After the conditional period of 24 months with all requirements being met for a Local Class B Commercial, the Conditional Class B Commercial license will become a Local Class B Commercial license with all special building limitations remaining in force or a Class B Commercial license. 
(b)  Qualifications for Conditional Class C Residential license can be accomplished with the following: 
(1)  Minimum of four years in residential construction performing layout, foundation set ups and foundations, framing, and roofing tasks as are typical in the residential construction industry. 
(2)  Minimum of two consecutive years verifiable full time residential construction as a business owner/operator in the City of McPherson immediately before the time of application. 
(3)  After the conditional period of 24 months with all requirements being met, the Conditional Class C Residential license will become a Local Class C Residential or a Class C Residential license. 
(Ord. No. 3215, § 1, 6-20-2016) 
Sec. 18-114. - Application form. 
    The City shall receive and process contractor license applications on forms provided by the city. License fees shall be paid without proration. No contractor license may be transferred or assigned. 
(Ord. No. 3215, § 1, 6-20-2016) 
Sec. 18-115. - Contractor insurance. 
    Every contractor except a contractor who has an "inactive license" shall keep in force a policy of general liability insurance including completed operations coverage. 
(a)  Class A, B and C contractors. Every building contractor shall keep in force a policy of commercial general liability insurance including completed operations/products coverage. Such insurance policy shall be written with an insurance company licensed in the State of Kansas. The contractor shall maintain general liability coverage in an amount not less than $1,000,000.00 per occurrence single limit for bodily injury and property damage. At the time of licensing, the contractor shall provide the City of McPherson with an original certificate of insurance verifying the insurance coverage required under this section. The city shall be added as an additional insured to the insurance policy by the insurance company issuing the certificate of insurance, requiring the insurance company to notify the city in writing of any change in coverage or cancellation of such policy at least ten days prior to such changes. 
(b)  Class D contactors. Every building contractor shall keep in force a policy of commercial general liability insurance including completed operations/products coverage. Such insurance policy shall be written with an insurance company licensed in the State of Kansas. The contractor shall maintain general liability coverage in an amount not less than $500,000.00 per occurrence single limit for bodily injury and property damage. At the time of licensing, the contractor shall provide the city with an original certificate of insurance verifying the insurance coverage required under this section. The city shall be added as an additional insured to the insurance policy by the insurance company issuing the certificate of insurance, requiring the insurance company to notify the city in writing of any change in coverage or cancellation of such policy at least ten days prior to such changes. 
(Ord. No. 3215, § 1, 6-20-2016) 
Sec. 18-116. - Renewal or reinstatement of a license. 
(a)  Every contractor license shall be issued on a calendar year basis to expire on December 31 st of each year. A contractor shall be entitled to renew such contractor's license upon satisfaction of requirements of the contractor licensing ordinance as then in effect. A license renewal application may be submitted to the city beginning on December first through and including the last day of January without a late fee. Thereafter, the cost to renew will be the original license fee. Unless an expired license is renewed within one year of its expiration, the contractor shall be required to make a new application and satisfy all the then-existing contractor licensing requirements. License renewal applications shall be mailed by the City of McPherson no later than November first of each year to every licensed contractor at the address provided by the contractor. The failure to receive an application shall not excuse untimely license renewal. 
(b)  Any contractor whose license is suspended must show to the reasonable satisfaction of the board that the violation has been corrected in accordance with the applicable code within a reasonable period of time set by the board. Failure to provide such evidence may result in the revocation of the contractor's license. 
(c)  When a contractor's license is revoked, a new license shall not be granted until the contractor has taken the necessary corrective action to the reasonable satisfaction of the board. 
(d)  Any contractor with delinquent fees shall make full payment to the City of McPherson prior to the issuance of renewal of a contractor license. 
(Ord. No. 3215, § 1, 6-20-2016) 
Sec. 18-117. - Renewal of conditional licensing. 
    The holder of a Conditional Class B Commercial or Conditional Class C Residential license may not renew the conditional license. The conditional license will no longer be granted after January 1, 2019. 
(Ord. No. 3215, § 1, 6-20-2016) 
Sec. 18-118. - Firms/qualifying party. 
    Under this article, a corporation, limited liability company, partnership or other legal entity ("firm") may obtain, in the firm's name, a contractor's license provided that such firm has at least one full-time employee who is designated by the firm as its qualifying party. Whenever a building permit is issued in the name of a firm, the firm shall be subject to these regulations and the jurisdiction of the board. The qualifying party shall be the legal representative for the contractor relative to the provisions of this article. The designated qualifying party shall satisfy the requirements of this contractor licensing ordinance. A designated qualifying party shall not be a qualifying party for more than one firm, unless the firms have a majority of the ownership in common. When the qualifying party terminates employment with the licensee, the city shall be notified by the qualifying party in writing within thirty days for the disassociation and another qualifying party must qualify within sixty days. 
    A contractor, including firms, may appoint one or more individuals who shall be authorized to obtain building permits on behalf of the contractor. Such individuals are not required to be a licensed contractor. 
(Ord. No. 3215, § 1, 6-20-2016) 
Sec. 18-119. - Contractor discipline. 
    The board shall have the authority to discipline, any contractor holding any contractor's license issued by the city as detailed in section 18-120 below. The board may take such disciplinary action if the board concludes by a preponderance of the evidence, following a hearing, that the contractor's action or inaction is: 
(a)  A serious or repeated violation of the provisions of this article, any applicable code, or the failure to comply within a reasonable time to any lawful written order of a building code official. In determining the seriousness of a violation the board shall consider the risk to the life, health or safety of an individual or the community or the risk to property; 
(b)  A knowing and intentional misrepresentation of a material fact made in connection with obtaining a contractor's license or a building permit; 
(c)  A failure to obtain a building permit or to obtain a required inspection of an ongoing project as required by any applicable Code; 
(d)  A failure to timely obtain a certificate of occupancy or required final inspection for a completed structure as required by the applicable code; 
(e)  A failure to hire a licensed building specialty, electrical, plumbing, or HVAC contractor to supervise any electrical, plumbing, HVAC or specialty work on the job site for which the contractor obtained a building permit; or 
(f)  A failure to pay any required application or licensing fees for a building permit, contractor license, or inspection fee; 
    The board shall mail to the contractor, at the address on the license, at least seven days prior to the hearing date a written notice listing the reasons for the possible discipline, but the board shall not be limited to such list of reasons if evidence is developed at the hearing showing other or additional reasons for discipline. The city shall have the burden of proof. The board may adopt such rules and procedures deemed reasonably necessary to conduct such hearing. The building code official shall have the discretion, but not the duty, to issue verbal and/or written warnings without waiving any potential violation. 
(Ord. No. 3215, § 1, 6-20-2016) 
Sec. 18-120. - Board action. 
    Upon finding by a majority of the members present at the hearing that a contractor has violated one or more of the provisions of section 18-119, the board may admonish, reprimand, or take other appropriate disciplinary action against such contractor including, but not limited to: 
(a)  Admonish or reprimand the contractor; 
(b)  Restrict the allowable scope of work allowed by the contractor for a fixed period not to exceed 90 days. 
(c)  Suspension of the contractor's license for a fixed period not to exceed 90 days. 
(d)  Suspension of the contractor's license for a fixed period up to 180 days, provided, however, the contractor shall have the right to have the suspension and the terms thereof reconsidered by the board at the expiration of the first 90 days to determine if just cause exists to modify or terminate the suspension. Such reconsideration may, at the board's option, include a hearing. 
(e)  Revocation of the contractor's license for a period not less than 12 months from the date of revocation. A contractor's license shall be revoked if the contractor has been suspended two times during any 36 month period. 
    Any decision of the board shall be made in writing stating the reasons for the decision and mailed to the contractor. A contractor whose license is the subject of a board action may appeal any decision of the board to the city's governing body by filing a notice of appeal with the board within 30 days following the third day after the board's written decision was mailed to the contractor as evidenced by a certificate of mailing which shall be included with the decision. When an appeal is filed, the secretary of the board shall forward the appeal and the board's decision to the city commission together with the board's record. Appeals to the governing body shall be de novo and no action shall be taken by the board during a pending appeal. 
(Ord. No. 3215, § 1, 6-20-2016) 
Sec. 18-121. - Safe harbor provisions. 
    A contractor shall not be found in violation of this article, nor disciplined by the board for a violation of an applicable building safety code provision if the contractor performs the work in accordance with and reliance upon duly certified plans and specifications prepared or approved by an architect or engineer licensed in Kansas without actual knowledge by the contractor that such plans and specifications, or pertinent parts thereof, are in violation of applicable codes. 
(Ord. No. 3215, § 1, 6-20-2016) 
Sec. 18-122. - Rules and regulations. 
    The board may adopt rules, regulation, and procedures consistent with the provisions of this contractor's licensing ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 3215, § 1, 6-20-2016) 
Secs. 18-123-18-170. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - ELECTRICAL CODE[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference- Electrical wiring inspection fees, § 18-72; electrical connections for signs, § 18-870. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 18-171. - Liability. 
    The regulations of this article shall not be construed to relieve from or lessen the responsibility or liability of any party owning, operating, controlling or installing any electric wiring, electric devices or electric material for damages to persons or property caused by any defect therein, nor shall the city be held as assuming any such liability by reason of the inspection authorized in this article or certificate of inspection issued as provided in this article. 
(Code 1995, § 4-328) 
Secs. 18-172-18-190. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT[7] 
Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Subdivision I. - In General 

Sec. 18-191. - Enforcement. 
(a)  The city inspector shall enforce, or cause to be enforced, all of the provisions of this article or any ordinances governing the placing and installation of electrical wiring and appliances in the city and, for that purpose, shall have and is hereby granted the special powers necessary for such enforcement. 
(b)  The city inspector shall have the right, during reasonable hours, to enter any building for the purpose of making any inspection or test of the installation of electric wiring, electric devices or electric material contained therein, and shall have authority to cause the turning off of all electrical currents and cut or disconnect, in case of emergency, any wiring where such electrical currents are dangerous to life or property, or may interfere with the work of the fire department. 
(Code 1995, §§ 4-313, 4-329) 
Sec. 18-192. - Appeals. 
    The city inspector shall decide all questions not provided for in the electrical code and pertaining to the installation or use of electric wires, appliances, fixtures, conductors, apparatus and their support. Any person feeling aggrieved by any decision of the city inspector may appeal from such decision or requirement to the construction advisory board of trades and board of appeals ("board"), provided that such appeal is made within three days of receipt of such decision or requirement. The board shall promptly and thoroughly investigate the matter, hear all parties concerned and promptly render a decision sustaining, modifying or rejecting the order or requirement appealed from. 
(Code 1995, § 4-330; Ord. No. 3203, § 1, 2-15-2016) 
Secs. 18-193-18-210. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Permits and Inspections 

Sec. 18-211. - Permit required. 
    No alteration or addition shall be made in the existing wiring of a building, nor shall any building be wired for the placing of any electric light, motor, heating device or apparatus requiring the use of electrical current, nor shall any alteration be made in the wiring of any building after inspection, without first notifying the city inspector and securing a permit for such alteration, except minor repair work, such as repairing flush and snap switches, replacing fuses, changing lamp sockets and receptacles, taping bare points and repairing drop cords. The application for such permit, describing such work, shall only be made by a licensed electrician or a person doing his work, on his premises which he must own and occupy, and must be accompanied by a permit fee as set by resolution of the governing body, and the permit, when issued, shall be to such applicant (see section 18-272(e)). All work shall be in the charge of the party to whom the permit is issued. An electrician's helper shall be permitted to work only when accompanied by a licensed electrician. This section shall not apply to maintenance and repairs on the premises of a person regularly employing electricians for that purpose. 
(Code 1995, § 4-314) 
Sec. 18-212. - Inspections. 
(a)  Upon the completion of the wiring of any building, it shall be the duty of the person installing the wiring to notify the city inspector, who shall inspect the installation within 24 hours of the time such notice is given. If such installation is found to be fully in compliance with this article and does not constitute a hazard to life and property, the city inspector shall issue to the owner or agent a certificate that the wiring has been inspected and approved, and authorizing connections to the electrical service and the turning on of the current, provided that, before a certificate shall be issued, the person applying for the certificate shall pay the inspection fees provided in this City Code. 
(b)  All wires which are to be hidden from view shall be inspected before concealment and any person installing such wires shall notify the city inspector, giving him 24 hours in which to make the required inspection before such wires are concealed. If the inspector reports that the wiring does not comply with the regulations set out in this article, no certificate shall be issued until all of the requirements have been met. 
(Code 1995, § 4-315; Ord. No. 3102, § 1, 5-20-2013) 
Sec. 18-213. - Plan approval required; type of wiring. 
(a)  All plans for wiring or rewiring of commercial buildings, either within or outside the fire zones of the city, shall be approved by the inspection department and shall bear its stamp of approval. No wiring or rewiring shall be done until the approval has been obtained. 
(b)  All new commercial buildings within the city shall be wired in rigid conduit, electric metallic tubing or MI cable. 
(Code 1995, § 4-318) 
Sec. 18-214. - Reinspections. 
    The city inspector may periodically make inspections of the installations in buildings of all the electrical wiring, equipment and material installed within the city, and when the installation of any such wiring device, equipment or material is found to be in a dangerous condition, the person using or operating the wiring device, equipment or material shall be notified in writing and shall make the necessary repairs or changes required to place such wiring device, equipment or material in a safe condition and have such work completed within 15 days or any longer period specified in the notice by the inspector. The city inspector is hereby authorized and empowered to disconnect or order discontinuance of electrical service to such wiring device, equipment or material found to be defectively installed until the installation of such wiring device, equipment or material has been made safe as directed by the inspector. 
(Code 1995, § 4-316) 
Sec. 18-215. - Certificate of inspection. 
    No certificate of inspection shall be issued unless the electric light, heat or power installations are in strict conformity with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1995, § 4-317) 
Secs. 18-216-18-240. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - TECHNICAL STANDARDS 

Sec. 18-241. - National Electrical Code incorporated. 
    A certain document, three copies of which are on file in the office of the city clerk, being marked and designated as the National Electric Code, 2008, be and is hereby adopted as the Electric Code of the City of McPherson for the installation, alteration and repair of electrical wiring and appurtenances thereto, including permits and penalties; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of said Electric [Code] on file in the office of the city clerk of the City of McPherson are hereby referred to, adopted, and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this section, with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if any, prescribed in section 18-242. 
(Code 1995, § 4-302; Ord. No. 2591, § 1(4-302), 8-10-1998; Ord. No. 2739, § 1(4-302), 6-24-2002; Ord. No. 2908, § 1, 1-2-2007; Ord. No. 3100, § 1, 5-20-2013) 
State Law reference- Adoption by reference, K.S.A. 12-3009 et seq., 12-3301 et seq. 
Sec. 18-242. - Amendments. 
    Section 110-5 shall be amended to read: "Conductors normally used to carry current shall be of copper, except those conductors used in service entrance connections." 
    Section 250-50 is supplemented with the following clarifications: 
1.  The main house electrical service panel shall have its own grounding rod exterior to the building, with proper sized rod and bonding wire, which shall be located not less than six feet from the service connection grounding rod and protected from physical damage. 
2.  The house metal cold and hot water piping systems shall be bonded to the building electrical service panel grounding rod system. 
3.  The house structural metal studs shall be bonded to the building electrical service panel ground rod grounding system. 
    The following is added to the National Electrical Code: 
1.  Right of entry. Upon presentation of proper credentials, the building official or his duly authorized representative may enter any building, structure or premises in the city, at reasonable hours, to perform any duty imposed upon him by this code. 
2.  Stop orders. Whenever any work is being done contrary to the provisions of the code, the building official may notify, in writing, the person engaged in the doing or causing of such work to be done of violations found, specifying a period of time allowed to bring work into code conformance. Such notice shall not be deemed to be a condition precedent to prosecution of a person acting in violation of the provisions of the code. 
3.  Authority to condemn equipment. Whenever the building official learns or ascertains that any electrical conductor or distribution equipment, as defined in the code, has become hazardous to life, health or property, he shall order, in writing, that such equipment be restored to a condition of safety or dismantled or removed from its present location. The written notice shall fix a time limit for compliance with such order. The building official is authorized to seal off electric current and/or fuel supply to equipment as defined in the code, where such installation is installed without a permit or does not meet provisions of the code. Where electric current or fuel supply has been sealed off, it shall be unlawful for any unauthorized person to break such seal. Upon corrections being made to meet requirements set forth in the code, the building official shall remove such seal. 
4.  Liability. The building official or any employee charged with the enforcement of the code, acting for the jurisdiction in good faith and without malice in the discharge of his duties, shall not thereby render himself liable personally and he hereby is relieved from all personal liability for and damage that may occur to person or property as a result of any act required or by reason of any act or omission in the discharge of his duties. 
5.  Violations. It shall be unlawful for any person to erect, construct, enlarge, alter, repair, move, improve, remove, convert or demolish, equip, use, occupy or maintain any building or structure, or cause or permit such work to be done in violation of the code. 
6.  Inspections. All work for which a permit is to be obtained under the code shall be subject to inspection by the building official. Any portion of the work for which a permit is obtained under the code which will be concealed prior to completion shall be subject to inspection prior to such work being concealed. These regulations shall not be construed to relieve from or lessen the responsibility or liability of any person owning, operating, controlling or installing any electric wiring, electric device or electric material for damages to persons or property caused by any defect therein, nor shall the city be held as assuming any such liability by reason of the inspection authorized in this subsection or certificates of inspection issued as provided in this code. 
(Code 1995, § 4-303; Ord. No. 2591, § 1(4-303), 8-10-1998; Ord. No. 2739, § 1(4-303), 6-24-2002; Ord. No. 3100, § 2, 5-20-2013) 
Sec. 18-243. - Electrical wiring within fire limits. 
    All wiring or rewiring installed within the fire limits shall be in rigid conduit, electrical metallic tubing, electrical nonmetallic tubing for nonexposed work concealed in a 15-minute fire resistance rating, type MC corrugated metal or Mi cable. The flexible metal conduit may be used to connect fixtures or appliances and should be properly bonded. 
(Code 1995, § 4-319; Ord. No. 2739, § 1(4-319), 6-24-2002) 
Sec. 18-244. - Service entrance equipment. 
(a)  The service entrance equipment (panel) shall be installed in or near the outside wall adjacent to the meter installation. In no event shall the distance between the meter and the service entrance panel be more than ten feet, except by special permission of the inspection department. 
(b)  The service entrance equipment on all new residential construction shall be not less than 100-ampere capacity. The raceway between the service entrance equipment and the meter shall not be less than 11/4-inch rigid conduit or electrical metallic tubing, or heavy wall electrical nonmetallic PVC tubing. On overhead service, the service entrance conductors shall not be less than no. 2 type TW or equal. 
(Code 1995, § 4-320; Ord. No. 2591, § 1(4-320), 8-10-1998; Ord. No. 2908, § 2, 1-2-2007) 
Sec. 18-245. - Electric service anchorage. 
(a)  To maintain proper clearance of ten feet on low buildings, the customer shall furnish suitable anchorage for the electric service. Such anchorage shall be either a pole located in the proper place to run the service drop to the building or by a two-inch steel conduit mast with approved fittings, including the service conductors. The board of public utilities reserves the right to furnish the service entrance cable from the meter to the pole on any installation. The customer shall install the cable in the mast, and the board of public utilities shall run the service drop to the pole and make pole connection. 
(b)  The board of public utilities will not be responsible for maintenance of the equipment, nor for any damage that may result to the roof or structure from any cause whatsoever. 
(Code 1995, § 4-321) 
Sec. 18-246. - Meters. 
(a)  The meter location and point of attachment of the service drop shall be approved by the board of public utilities prior to the installation of the equipment. The meter shall be located not less than four feet, six inches, nor more than six feet above finish grade. 
(b)  The number of service feeds from the board of public utilities to a building shall be limited to one, except a building is considered separate (i.e., a duplex, townhouse, triplex, etc.) if electric, gas, water and sanitary sewer do not cross common walls and/or floor assemblies. Also, common wall and floor assemblies shall have one hour fire rated separation extending tight against exterior walls and to the underside of the roof sheathing. 
(c)  There shall be a service disconnect switch on the customer side of the meter for all commercial and residential buildings. It is permissible to use the six turnoff rule per NEC on exteriors of buildings or structures. No maximum distance or footage is specified from the point of entrance of service conductors to a readily accessible location for the installation of a service disconnect. The city inspector has the responsibility and is charged with making interpretations related to specific individual installations. The length of service entrance conductors should be kept to a minimum inside the building to prevent ignition of nearby combustible materials in the event of a fault. 
(d)  Shunt trip switches can be installed in commercial buildings if: 
(1)  The building is fully sprinkled. 
(2)  The location of the switch is within 10-15 feet of the building main. 
(3)  There is installation of indicator lights to the building primary line feeds for safety. 
(Code 1995, § 4-322; Ord. No. 2591, § 1(4-322), 8-10-1998; Ord. No. 2739, § 1(4-322), 6-24-2002) 
Sec. 18-247. - Air conditioning. 
    Where air conditioning units are installed outside of the building on a slab foundation there shall be a weatherproof disconnect installed either on the building next to the unit or on the unit itself. The air conditioning unit, including the outside housing, shall be permanently grounded. 
(Code 1995, § 4-323) 
Sec. 18-248. - Appliances. 
    Provisions for the connection of electric stoves, room coolers and electric clothes dryers shall be as follows: 
(1)  Where there is no 220-volt wiring on the premises, such appliances may be connected on a separate disconnect, independent of the existing wiring system, by installing a separate disconnect adjacent to the meter and connected directly thereto. No lighting or other appliances shall be connected to such disconnect. Where the wiring system does not have a metal meter enclosure located on the outside of the building served, the board of public utilities shall install a three-wire meter on the outside wall and reconnect the existing wiring to the meter as a two-wire installation. No other inside wiring shall be done by the board of public utilities. Such disconnect shall be installed in the same manner as a regular service entrance disconnect, including grounding, bonds, etc. 
(2)  Any appliance operating continuously for one hour or more and drawing more than 50 percent of the ampere rating of the circuit to which it is connected, shall be connected to a circuit of not less than 200 volts, unless a separate 115-volt circuit is provided for such appliance only, with no other connected load thereon. 
(3)  All 220-volt appliances shall be connected by a three-wire cord with a polarized plug receptacle and the frame of the unit shall be solidly bonded to the grounding (green) conductor. 
(4)  All motor driven appliances shall be connected to the wiring system by a cord with a polarized plug and receptacle. The motor and frame of each appliance shall be bonded to the grounding connection of the attachment plug. 
(Code 1995, § 4-324) 
Sec. 18-249. - Furnaces. 
    All furnaces installed in open areas and fed from ceiling wiring shall be connected by rigid conduit or equal in the ceiling wiring system to the junction box on the appliance. Where no box exists on the furnace, one shall be installed. All furnace motors installed after the passage of the National Electrical Code shall be protected with a separate plug fuse device that is mounted in a SSU or SSR fuse holder with a grounding type receptacle or equal. Open, unprotected wiring shall not be used. No wiring, high or low voltage, shall be taped to the gas piping system. 
(Code 1995, § 4-325; Ord. No. 2591, § 1(4-325), 8-10-1998) 
Sec. 18-250. - Roam X cable. 
    Where NM (roam X) cables are installed across or parallel to heat ducts, a clearance of not less than one inch shall be provided. 
(Code 1995, § 4-326) 
Secs. 18-251-18-270. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - ELECTRICIANS 

Sec. 18-271. - Board of electrical examiners. 
    The construction advisory board of trades and board of appeals shall serve as the board of electrical examiners ("board"). 
(Code 1995, § 4-301; Ord. No. 3200, § 1, 2-15-2016) 
Cross reference- Boards and commissions, § 2-281 et seq. 
Sec. 18-272. - License and requirement that work be performed by qualified master electricians. 
(a)  Before engaging in the business of installing, altering or repairing electric wiring, including electric signs, outline strips or festoon wiring, every master electrician or employing electrician shall apply to the city for a license to conduct an electrical business within the city. Such application shall be made on a form provided by the city. The application shall be accompanied by a bond, with sureties approved by the governing body, in the sum as set by resolution of the governing body, upon the condition that the electrician will indemnify and hold harmless the city from all liability from any accident or damage arising from negligence in performing the electrician's work or from any inadequate work done, or from misrepresentation regarding work done pursuant to the license, and on the further condition that the electrician will fill all excavations made so as to leave the alley, sidewalk, parking, street and pavement in the same grade and condition as when found, and on the further condition that the electrician will comply with all city ordinances relative to the electrician's work. The application shall be accompanied by an initial license fee as set by resolution of the governing body. All licenses shall expire on December 31 of each year. Renewal licenses shall be issued upon payment of a renewal fee as set by resolution of the governing body and the furnishing of evidence of continuation of the electrician's bond. 
(b)  No person who has obtained an electrician's license shall allow the electrician's name to be used by another person for the purpose of obtaining permits or conducting the electrician's trade or business under such other electrician's license. Any master electrician shall be guilty of a misdemeanor if a license is not renewed by February 1, and the fee for renewal of a license under such circumstances will be as set by resolution of the governing body. 
(c)  Any license granted may be revoked by the governing body if the licensee violates any ordinance or law relating to installations of electrical wiring or electrical material, or is responsible for any electrical installation which is a hazard to life and property. When a license is revoked, a new license shall not again be granted to the same licensee for a period of at least 30 days. 
(d)  Any person engaged in the business of electrical wiring who is not, by qualification, a master electrician, shall at all times keep in his employ a qualified master electrician who shall be in charge and responsible for all wiring installed by the person. The name of the master electrician shall appear on the license and in no case shall it appear on more than one electrical license in any one calendar year in the city. No person shall engage in the business of installing, altering or repairing any electrical wiring unless the performance of the electrical work performed in the course of such business is under the direct supervision of a master electrician licensed with the city. 
(e)  No person, other than a licensed electrician, shall be permitted to install electrical wiring upon or within any building or premises in the city unless the person shall be the owner and occupant of the premises, and then only by special written permission of the board. When such special permission is granted by the board, the applicant shall apply to the inspection department for a permit and call for an inspection when work is completed and before the work is covered. Before the board shall issue such permit, it shall satisfy itself that the applicant is qualified to install the proposed wiring. Any decision of the board may be appealed to the governing body pursuant to Code section. 
(f)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to any person in the employ of the city who does wiring work under the direction of the general manager of the board of public utilities. 
(Code 1995, §§ 4-304, 4-305, 4-311, 4-312; Ord. No. 2591, § 1(4-304), 8-10-1998; Ord. No. 3200, § 1, 2-15-2016) 
Sec. 18-273. - Certification of master electrician. 
(a)  Any person engaged as a master electrician, either as an owner or employee of a firm or corporation in the business of installing electrical wiring for any purpose and acting in a supervisory capacity, shall hold a master electrician's certificate issued by the city. 
(b)  Before being issued a certificate, except as a renewal of an existing certificate, the applicant shall apply by letter to the board and shall present a certificate issued by the city or another licensing jurisdiction demonstrating passage of the Prometric or International Code Council (ICC) license examination, and knowledge of local ordinance amendments governing such work. The examination may include the standard examination for the determination of competency of electrical contractors and electricians, based upon current codes and standards prepared and published and available upon such date from Prometric, www.prometric.com, or International Code Council (ICC). The fee for a master electrician's examination shall be the rate as set forth by Prometric or International Code Council (ICC) examination service, plus such additional fee as may be necessary to reimburse the city for its costs. The fee for a master electrician's certificate shall be as set by resolution of the governing body, which fee, along with examination fees, shall be deposited to the general fund of the city. An applicant must demonstrate or achieve a 75 percent passing score to be eligible for the issuance of a certificate. The certificate issued shall contain or be accompanied by an endorsement indicating that the electrician has taken the Block and Associates' examination prescribed by this section (if taken), and showing the passing score thereon obtained by the applicant. 
(Code 1995, § 4-306; Ord. No. 2591, § 1(4-306), 8-10-1998; Ord. No. 3102, § 1, 5-20-2013; Ord. No. 3200, § 1, 2-15-2016) 
State Law reference- Electrical examinations and certificates of competency, K.S.A. 12-1525 et seq. 
Sec. 18-274. - Certification of journeyman electricians. 
(a)  Any person engaged as a journeyman electrician doing electrical work for others shall hold a journeyman electrician's certificate issued by the city. 
(b)  Before being issued a certificate, the applicant shall demonstrate successful passage of the required Prometric or International Code Council (ICC) examination and then apply to the board for approval as a journeyman electrician according to the procedure prescribed in section 18-273. The board shall issue a journeyman electrician's certificate to all qualified journeyman electricians prior to their commencing work as a journeyman electrician in the city. The fee for examination shall be the rate as set forth by Prometric or International Code Council (ICC), plus such additional fee as may be necessary to reimburse the city for its costs. The fee for a certificate shall be as set by resolution of the governing body, which shall be deposited in the general fund of the city. 
(Code 1995, § 4-307; Ord. No. 2591, § 1(4-307), 8-10-1998; Ord. No. 3102, § 1, 5-20-2013; Ord. No. 3200, § 1, 2-15-2016) 
State Law reference- Electrical examinations and certificates of competency, K.S.A. 12-1525 et seq. 
Sec. 18-275. - Supervisor of journeyman electricians. 
    Journeyman electricians shall not be permitted to do electrical work for others, except under the direct supervision, license, permit and bond of a master electrician. 
(Code 1995, § 4-309) 
Sec. 18-276. - Apprentice helpers. 
    One apprentice helper shall be permitted with each master or journeyman electrician. 
(Code 1995, § 4-310) 
Secs. 18-277-18-310. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - GAS PIPING AND VENTING CODE[8] 
Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Cross reference- Gas installation inspection fees, § 18-73. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 18-311-18-330. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT[9] 
Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Subdivision I. - In General 

Secs. 18-331-18-350. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Permits and Inspections 

Sec. 18-351. - Permit required. 
    No building shall be piped or fitted for gas, nor shall any extension be made in any piping, including piping and fixtures installed by holders of a limited gasfitter's certification, unless a permit shall be granted by the city inspector. Each permit shall set out the correct location, name and address of the owner of such building, and a full and complete statement of the work proposed. The permit shall only be issued to bonded gasfitters who hold certificates of competency issued by the construction advisory board of trades and board of appeals, as provided in this Code, and must be approved by the city inspector. All work shall be in charge of the party to whom the permit is issued. A gasfitter's helper shall be permitted to work only when accompanied by a certified gasfitter. 
(Code 1995, § 4-608; Ord. No. 3203, § 2, 2-15-2016) 
Sec. 18-352. - Notification of readiness for test; violations; penalties. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of any party installing or altering gas piping in any building in the city to notify the inspector when the work is ready for inspection. No piping shall be covered or concealed from view until inspected and approved by the city inspector. 
(b)  Failure to obtain a permit and call for inspection of any additional or new piping or venting shall constitute a violation of this article, and the violator shall be subject to the same penalties as for an improper installation. 
(Code 1995, § 4-610) 
Sec. 18-353. - Inspections; enforcement. 
(a)  The city inspector or his duly authorized assistant shall inspect and witness the test of all new installations of gas piping, gas appliances and all extensions to, or alterations of, old installations in all buildings in the city. 
(b)  The inspector shall enforce, or cause to be enforced, the provisions of this article and shall have the right during reasonable hours to enter any building for the purpose of making any inspection required by this section. 
(Code 1995, § 4-609) 
Sec. 18-354. - Unsatisfactory installations. 
    If, upon inspection and test, the installation of any gas piping, or any part thereof, shall be found not to comply with the requirements set for in this article, it shall be changed, rearranged, repaired or removed, within a reasonable time as set by the city inspector, who shall notify the owner or agent of such finding in writing, and gas shall not be permitted to flow through any piping until it has been inspected and approved by the city inspector. 
(Code 1995, § 4-611) 
Sec. 18-355. - Air gauge tests; vents. 
(a)  All installations, extensions or alterations to gas piping must be inspected and tested with an air gauge by the gasfitter in the presence of the city inspector. All such installations, extensions or alterations must be capable of withstanding air pressure of not less than 20 pounds for a period of 30 minutes without showing any drop in pressure. 
(b)  All required vents shall be in place prior to test and approval of piping by the city inspector. 
(Code 1995, § 4-613) 
Sec. 18-356. - Inspection record; certificate of satisfactory inspection. 
(a)  The city inspector shall keep a record of all inspections of gas piping. 
(b)  When the gas piping in any building, after inspection, is found to comply with the requirements of this article, the city inspector shall issue to the owner a certificate of satisfactory inspection. 
(Code 1995, § 4-617) 
Secs. 18-357-18-380. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - TECHNICAL STANDARDS 

Sec. 18-381. - International Plumbing Code incorporated. 
    All gas burning appliances, gas piping and venting shall be installed in accordance with the standards of the International Plumbing Code, as adopted by the City of McPherson, Kansas. 
(Code 1995, § 4-601; Ord. No. 3204, § 1, 2-15-2016) 
Sec. 18-382. - Fittings. 
    In all construction, reconstruction or repair of piping for natural or liquefied petroleum gas, nipples and reducing couplings must be used in making an increase or decrease in straight runs of piping and in no case will bushings be allowed. A safety automatic pilot device, complete shutoff type, shall be installed on all new or replaced gas/fuel water heaters, central heating units, boilers or any appliance used as the main source of heating, including unit heaters, circulating heaters, etc. 
(Code 1995, § 4-612) 
Sec. 18-383. - Placement and size of pipes. 
    No pipe shall be laid so as to support any weight, except lighting fixtures, or be subject to any strain. All outlets shall be securely fastened in place and properly capped. No secondhand gas pipe or fittings shall be used in any building. No cast iron fittings shall be used in gas piping. The main service line shall not be laid under any concrete drive, patio or accessory building. The main shall enter the building above grade and the foundation wall. The minimum size of all service lines from the gas meter to the customer's building shall be 11/4-inch where the meter is located at the property line, and otherwise shall contain no minimum size requirement. There shall be a manual main shutoff valve in the main service line near the wall above grade. When the meter is located at the property line, there shall be an insulating union installed in the service riser at the building wall on the main side of the main shutoff valve and a separate brass manual gas valve on each appliance outlet when connected to the fixture. There shall be a swing joint at the base at all risers in service lines outside the building wall consisting of a 11/4-inch 90-degree ell and a 11/4-inch street ell. All gas service lines shall be in a separate trench at least five feet from any other trench. 
(Code 1995, § 4-614) 
Sec. 18-384. - Flexible connections. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to use an unlisted or unapproved gas appliance flexible connector or quick-disconnect. A gas shutoff valve shall be installed where the flexible connector is attached to the building's gas piping. The flexible connector shall be of minimum length necessary to make the connection and in no case be more than six feet long. The flexible connector shall not be concealed and shall not extend from one room to another or pass through a wall, partition, ceiling, or floor. 
(Code 1995, § 4-615; Ord. No. 2839, § 1, 2-14-2005) 
Sec. 18-385. - Appliance and location restrictions. 
(a)  Water heaters shall not be installed in bathrooms, sleeping rooms, clothes closets or under stairways. 
(b)  Unvented room heaters, such as radiant heaters or any appliance not approved as a vented appliance, shall not be installed in bathrooms or sleeping rooms. 
(c)  All appliances installed within the city shall have a nameplate affixed and installed by the manufacturer, showing the name of the manufacturer, including mailing address, size in BTU input and output of the appliance and the stamp of approval by an approved nationally recognized testing agency, qualified and equipped for experimental testing (i.e., American Gas Association or Underwriters' Laboratories), and shall be installed in accordance with such approval. 
(d)  No unapproved appliance shall be installed in the city without approval of the city inspector. 
(Code 1995, § 4-616) 
Secs. 18-386-18-410. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - GASFITTERS 

Sec. 18-411. - License required; application; bond; fee. 
(a)  Before any person shall engage in the business of gasfitting, he shall apply to the city clerk, upon beginning work in the city, for a gasfitter's license. 
(b)  The application shall be accompanied by a bond, with sureties to be approved by the governing body, in the sum as set by resolution of the governing body, on condition that he will: 
(1)  Indemnify and hold harmless the city from all liability from any accident or damage arising from negligence in protecting his work or from any unfaithful or inadequate work done in pursuance of his certificate; 
(2)  Fill all excavations made by him so as to leave the alley, sidewalk, parking, street and pavement in as good of a condition as when it was found; and 
(3)  Comply with all city ordinances relative to his work. 
(c)  The fee for the license shall be as set by resolution of the governing body. 
(Code 1995, § 4-604) 
Cross reference- Finance, § 2-221 et seq.; licenses, permits and miscellaneous business regulations, ch. 38. 
Sec. 18-412. - Examination and certificate. 
(a)  All work, installations, connections, extensions, alterations, repairs or any kind of improvements or installations for the purpose of installing natural or liquefied petroleum gas pipes, piping, appliances or repairing natural or liquefied petroleum gas piping or fittings and any and all extensions or alterations of old or used installations in any and all buildings in the city shall be done only by persons holding a gasfitter's certificate. 
(b)  No person shall engage in the business of gasfitting in the city until such person has presented a Prometric or International Code Counsel (ICC) certificate and been found qualified and competent to engage in and/or work at such business and shall have been issued a certificate by the board of plumbing examiners, or, if a firm or corporation, shall employ at all times a properly qualified gasfitter, and the gasfitter's license shall bear the name of the employee authorized to do gasfitting work. The fees for the examination and certificate shall be as set by resolution of the governing body. All fees received by the board of plumbing examiners for examinations and certificates shall be paid in to the general fund of the city. 
(c)  Any person employed by a firm or corporation desiring to engage in the work of setting and connecting gas stoves, ranges, central heating furnaces or other single small appliances requiring not more than ten feet in length of pipe to make the connection (setting and connecting water heaters, large gas furnaces, gas boilers or other large gas equipment is not permitted by a limited gasfitter's certificate holder) may apply to the construction advisory board of trades and board of appeals ("board") for a limited gasfitter's examination and certificate. At a time set by the board, such person shall appear for examination. The board shall determine by examination and other investigations whether the applicant, by training, knowledge and experience, is capable of setting, connecting, adjusting and repairing small gas appliances in accordance with the requirement of this article. The fee for the examination shall be as set by resolution of the governing body. If the applicant passes the examination, the board shall issue a limited gasfitter's certificate upon the payment of a fee as set by resolution of the governing body. The certificate holder shall at all times work under the direction and responsibility of a gasfitter's license holder. No part of the examination fee shall be refunded regardless of whether the applicant fails or passes the examination. 
(Code 1995, §§ 4-602, 4-603, 4-606; Ord. No. 3102, § 1, 5-20-2013; Ord. No. 3203, § 3, 2-15-2016) 
Sec. 18-413. - License and certificate expiration and renewal. 
    All gasfitter's certificates and licenses shall expire on December 31 of each year. If the renewal fee remains unpaid after February 1, the certificate and license shall be automatically revoked and a new application will be required to secure a certificate or license. 
(Code 1995, § 4-605) 
Secs. 18-414-18-425. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - FUEL GAS CODE 

Sec. 18-426. - Fuel gas code; adopted. 
    A certain document, three copies of which are on file in the office of the city clerk, being marked and designated as the International Fuel Gas Code, 2009 edition, including Appendix Chapters A, B and C, as published by the International Code Council, be and is hereby adopted as the Fuel Gas Code of the City of McPherson for regulating and governing fuel gas systems and gas-fired appliances as herein provided; providing for the issuance of permits and collection of fees therefor; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of said Fuel Gas Code on file in the office of the City Clerk of the City of McPherson are hereby referred to, adopted, and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this ordinance, with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if any, prescribed in section 18-427. 
(Ord. No. 2904, § 1, 12-26-2006; Ord. No. 3113, § 1, 7-29-2013)

Sec. 18-442. - Building official; defined.
