Sec. 18-443. - Emergencies. 
(a)  Whenever, in the judgment of the city inspector, an emergency exists which requires immediate action to protect the public health, safety or welfare, an order may be issued, without notice, conference or hearing, directing the owner, occupant, operator or agent to take such action as is appropriate to correct or abate the emergency. If circumstances warrant, the city inspector may act to correct or abate the emergency. 
(b)  The owner, occupant, operator or agent shall be granted a conference on the matter upon his request, as soon as practicable, but such conference shall in no case stay the abatement or correction of such emergency. 
(Code 1995, §§ 4-403, 4-404) 
Secs. 18-444-18-470. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - SMOKE DETECTORS[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
State Law reference- Smoke detectors, K.S.A. 31-160 et seq. 

Sec. 18-471. - Interpretation and application. 
    This article is intended to supplement existing building and fire codes adopted by the city and shall not be deemed applicable to fact situations addressed by provisions of the International Building Code or International Fire Code, except to the extent consistent therewith. 
(Code 1995, § 4-1705; Ord. No. 3102, § 1, 5-20-2013) 
Sec. 18-472. - Scope. 
    The provisions of this article shall apply to all existing buildings and mobile homes, except that, in existing owner-occupied single-family dwellings constructed prior to 1982, battery-powered smoke detectors may be installed, and shall be deemed to be in compliance with this article, provided that such detectors are maintained in an operable condition. Where battery-powered smoke detectors are already installed in locations as required in section 18-473 at or prior to the effective date of Ordinance No. 2557, and are maintained in an operable condition, the premises shall be deemed to be in compliance with this article, provided that the owner of the tenant-occupied premises shall be deemed in compliance if, at the time of delivery of the premises to the tenant, the smoke detector was in an operable condition. 
(Code 1995, § 4-1703(a)) 
Sec. 18-473. - Where required; mounting location; failure to provide. 
(a)  Every owner and occupant of every dwelling unit and mobile home, and every owner and manager of every guest room in a hotel, motel, lodginghouse or apartment house used for sleeping purposes must provide such dwelling units with smoke detectors conforming to the standards set forth in the edition of the International Building Code currently adopted for application in the city. 
(b)  In dwelling units, smoke detectors shall be mounted on the ceiling or wall at a point centrally located in the corridor or area giving access to rooms for sleeping purposes. In an efficiency dwelling unit, hotel or motel sleeping room or suite the smoke detector shall be centrally located on the ceiling of the main room or sleeping room. Where sleeping rooms are on an upper level, the smoke detectors shall be placed at the center of the ceiling directly above the stairway. All smoke detectors shall be located in accordance with approved manufacturers' instructions. When activated, the smoke detector shall provide an alarm in the dwelling unit or guest room. 
(c)  Failure of an obligated person to provide a smoke detector shall be a misdemeanor, punishable as provided in section 1-11 of the City Code. 
(Code 1995, § 4-1701; Ord. No. 2619, 5-17-1999; Ord. No. 2718, § 1, 12-26-2001; Ord. No. 3102, § 1, 5-20-2013) 
Sec. 18-474. - Power source. 
    Required smoke detectors shall receive their primary power from the building wiring. Wiring shall be permanent and without a disconnecting switch, other than those required for overcurrent protection. 
(Code 1995, § 4-1702) 
Sec. 18-475. - Compliance inspection. 
    No code enforcement inspection shall be conducted to ascertain compliance with the provisions of this article, but, if a fire occurs in any dwelling unit or sleeping room required by the provisions of this article to have installed an operating smoke detector, or the fire department is called by the owner or tenant to the premises for any other reason, and it is discovered that the premises, or any required portion thereof, is not equipped with a working smoke detector as required in this article, the owner and/or tenant or manager of the premises shall be guilty of a violation of the provisions of this article, and shall be issued a citation for such violation. A recheck will be made within seven days after the first citation is issued. A second citation will be issued upon the recheck, if compliance with the provisions of this article has not been completed. Each seven days thereafter that the premises are not in compliance shall constitute a separate violation for which additional citations shall be issued. 
(Code 1995, § 4-1703(b); Ord. No. 2718, § 2, 12-26-2001) 
Secs. 18-476-18-510. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - MECHANICAL CODE 

Sec. 18-511. - International Mechanical Code incorporated. 
    A certain document, three copies of which are on file in the office of the city clerk, being marked and designated as the International Mechanical Code, 2009 edition, including Appendix Chapter A, as published by the International Code Council, be and is hereby adopted as the Mechanical Code of the City of McPherson for regulating and governing the design, construction, quality of materials, erection, installation, alteration, repair location, relocation, replacement, addition to, use or maintenance of mechanical systems as herein provided; providing for the issuance of permits and collection of fees therefor; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of said Mechanical Code on file in the office of the City Clerk of the City of McPherson are hereby referred to, adopted, and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this ordinance, with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if any, prescribed in section 18-512 of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2645, § 1, 11-22-1999; Ord. No. 2742, § 1(4-5C01), 6-24-2002; Ord. No. 2903, § 1, 12-26-2006; Ord. No. 3097, § 1, 5-20-2013) 
State Law reference- Adoption by reference, K.S.A. 12-3009 et seq., 12-3301 et seq. 
Sec. 18-512. - Amendment and clarification. 
    The following sections of said Mechanical Code are hereby revised: 
    Section 101.1. Insert: City of McPherson for [Name of Jurisdiction] 
    Section 106.5.2. Insert: Such fees as are set forth in resolution of the governing body of the City of McPherson, as amended from time to time for [Appropriate Schedule] 
    Section 106.5.3. Insert: 80% in 106.5.3(2) and (3). 
    Section 108.4. Insert: Misdemeanor as [Specify Offense]; $500 as [amount]; 30 days as [Number of days]. 
    Section 108.5. Insert: $250 as minimum fine, $500 as maximum fine. 
(Ord. No. 2742, § 1(4-5C02), 6-24-2002; Ord. No. 2903, § 2, 12-26-2006; Ord. No. 2903, § 2, 12-26-2006; Ord. No. 3097, § 2, 5-20-2013) 
Sec. 18-513. - Mechanical contractor examination/appeals/review board. 
    The construction advisory board of trades and board of appeals shall serve as mechanical contractor examination/appeals/review board ("board") in the City of McPherson. 
(Ord. No. 2645, § 1(4-5C03), 11-22-99; Ord. No. 3201, § 1, 2-15-2016) 
Sec. 18-514. - Master mechanical contractor; examinations. 
(a)  Any person engaged as a master mechanical contractor, either as an owner or an employee of a firm or corporation in the business of installing, maintaining, repairing, fabricating, altering, or extending central air conditioning, refrigeration, heating, and ventilation systems and acting in a supervisory capacity, shall hold a master mechanical contractor certificate issued by the city. 
(b)  Before being issued a certificate (except as a renewal of an existing certificate), the applicant shall apply by letter to the board and shall pass the license examination or shall present a certificate issued by another licensing jurisdiction demonstrating passage of the Prometric or International Code Council (ICC) license examination used by the board. The examination shall examine the applicant desiring a certificate as to his or her practical and theoretical knowledge of mechanical air conditioning systems for installation, maintenance, modification, and repair, and his or her knowledge of the city's ordinances governing such work. The examination may include the standard examination for the determination of competency of mechanical contractors based upon current codes and standards prepared and published and available upon such date from Prometric or International Code Council (ICC). 
(c)  The fee for a master mechanical contractor's examination shall be the rate as set forth by Prometric or International Code Council (ICC) plus any additional fee necessary to reimburse the city of its costs in administering the examination. The fee for a master mechanical contractor certificate shall be $10.00, which fees, along with administrative examination fee, shall be deposited to the general fund of the city. 
(d)  The applicant must demonstrate or achieve a 75 percent passing score to be eligible for the issuance of a certificate. The certificate issued shall contain or be accompanied by an endorsement indicating that mechanical contractor has taken the Prometric or International Code Council (ICC) examination prescribed by this section (if taken), and showing the passing score thereon obtained by the applicant. 
(e)  As an alternative to demonstration of proficiency by passage of the Prometric or International Code Council (ICC) examination, an applicant for a license may be examined by the board based on the applicant's ownership and operation of a mechanical contracting business within the city at the time of passage of this article. If the board is satisfied as to the skill and proficiency of such an applicant, it may grant a master mechanical contractor license without requiring the applicant to take the Prometric or International Code Council (ICC) license examination. If a license is granted pursuant to this subsection, the license shall be endorsed with the following notation "Licensee has not taken the Prometric or International Code Council (ICC) examination." 
(Ord. No. 2645, § 1(4-5C04), 11-22-99; Ord. No. 3102, § 1, 5-20-2013; Ord. No. 3201, § 1, 2-15-2016) 
Sec. 18-515. - Journeyman mechanical contractor; examination. 
    Any person engaged as a journeyman mechanical contractor doing mechanical work for others, shall hold a journeyman mechanical contractor certificate issued by the city. Before being issued a certificate, the applicant shall demonstrate successful passage of the city's certificate examination or apply to the board for examination as a journeyman mechanical contractor according to the procedures prescribed in section 18-513. The board shall issue a journeyman certificate to all qualified journeyman prior to their commencing work as a journeyman mechanical contractor in the city. The fee for the certificate shall be $5.00 plus such additional fee as may be necessary to reimburse the city for its cost in administering the Prometric or International Code Council (ICC) examination if taken. The fees shall be deposited in the general fund of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2645, § 1(4-5C05), 11-22-99; Ord. No. 3102, § 1, 5-20-2013; Ord. No. 3201, § 1, 2-15-2016) 
Sec. 18-516. - Mechanical contractor bond; license, and license fee. 
    Before engaging in the business of installing, maintaining, repairing, fabricating, altering, or extending central air conditioning, refrigeration, heating, and ventilation systems and acting in a supervisory capacity, shall apply to the city for a license to conduct a mechanical business within the city. Application shall be made on a form provided by the city. The application shall be accompanied by a bond with sureties approved by the city commission in the sum of $5,000.00, on the condition that the master mechanical contractor will indemnify and hold harmless the city from liability from any accident or damages arising from negligence in performing the mechanics work or from any inadequate work done, or from misrepresentation regarding work done pursuant to the license; on further condition that the mechanic will comply with all city ordinances relative to mechanical work. The application shall be accompanied by an initial license fee of $100.00. The city licenses shall expire on December 31 of each year. Renewal licenses shall be issued upon payment of a renewal fee of $25.00 in consecutive years and furnishing evidence of the continuation of the mechanical business bond. No person or business who has obtained a mechanical license shall allow the mechanics name to be used by another person, for the purpose of obtaining permits, of for conducting the mechanics trade or business under such other mechanics license. No person shall engage in the business of installing, maintaining, repairing, fabricating, altering, or extending central air conditioning, refrigeration, heating, and ventilation systems unless the performance of the mechanical work performed in the course of such business is under the direct supervision of a master mechanic licensed with the city. 
(Ord. No. 2645, § 1(4-5C06), 11-22-99) 
Sec 18-517. - Request examination; required experience. 
    Any person requesting a master mechanical examination through Prometric or International Code Council (ICC), or other city approved testing agency, shall have had at least six years' actual experience or the equivalent. Any person requesting a journeyman's examination shall have had at least three years' apprentice experience, or the equivalent, in the judgment of the board and shall be recommended to the board by a licensed master mechanic, who has supervision over the applicant. All requests for examination shall be in writing. 
(Ord. No. 2645, § 1(4-5C07), 11-22-99; Ord. No. 3102, § 1, 5-20-2013; Ord. No. 3201, § 1, 2-15-2016) 
Sec. 18-518. - Journeyman mechanical; supervision. 
    Journeyman mechanical workers shall not be permitted to do mechanical type work for others except under the direct supervision, city license, and bond of a master mechanical contractor. 
(Ord. No. 2645, § 1(4-5C08), 11-22-99) 
Sec. 18-519. - Apprentice helper ratio. 
    Two apprentice helpers shall be permitted with each master or journeyman mechanical contractor. 
(Ord. No. 2645, § 1(4-5C09), 11-22-99) 
Sec. 18-520. - Licensed mechanical contractors for mechanical systems installation. 
    No person other than a licensed mechanical contractor shall be permitted to install mechanical systems upon or within any building or premises in the city unless the person shall be the owner and occupant of the building or premises, and then only by special written permission of the board. When such permission is so granted by the board, the applicant shall apply to the city inspection department for a permit and be responsible to call for proper inspection of the work done. The board shall issue such permits only after it has satisfied itself that the applicant is qualified to install the proposed mechanical system. 
(Ord. No. 2645, § 1(4-5C10), 11-22-99; Ord. No. 3201, § 1, 2-15-2016) 
Sec. 18-521. - Revocation of license. 
    Any license granted by the city may be revoked by the governing body if the licensee violates any article of the city mechanical codes, city ordinance or other law relating to the installation of mechanical systems or is responsible for any mechanical systems installation that is a hazard to personal life or property. The revoked license can not be granted to the same licensee for a period of 30 calendar days. 
(Ord. No. 2645, § 1(4-5C11), 11-22-99) 
Sec. 18-522. - Authority for inspection of mechanical system. 
    The city inspector shall have the right during working hours to enter any building within his jurisdiction for the purpose of making any inspection or test of the installation of the mechanical system and its components. 
(Ord. No. 2645, § 1(4-5C12), 11-22-99) 
Sec. 18-523. - Mechanical systems permits; permit fee; and inspection. 
    Any alterations or additions to existing mechanical heating and cooling comfort systems or new mechanical heating and cooling comfort systems installations shall be reported to the city inspector on the application for gas fitting permit form supplied to the licensed contractor. The form shall be filled with system descriptive information by the licensed mechanical contractor, or a journeyman doing work for him as an employee. A permit for the mechanical system shall be accompanied by the necessary fee per Article 7, Permits and inspection fees (R.O., Sec. 4-702A). Completion of the installation or modification of the mechanical system shall require an inspection within 24 hours. The licensed mechanical contractor or a journeyman working under his jurisdiction shall be responsible for proper notification. 
(Ord. No. 2645, § 1(4-5C13), 11-22-99) 
Secs. 18-524-18-540. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - PLUMBING CODE[11] 
Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Cross reference- Plumbing inspection fees, § 18-74. 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate plumbing, K.S.A. 12-1505. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 18-541. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Water distribution line means cold water lines, inside or outside of the building, intended to carry water to sprinkling outlets, barns, etc. 
    Water service line means the water line from a distribution line, usually in the street adjacent to the property served, to provide water to the house and/or buildings on the specific lot or parcel of property. 
(Code 1995, § 4-519) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Secs. 18-542-18-560. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT[12] 

Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Secs. 18-561-18-580. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PERMITS AND INSPECTIONS 

Sec. 18-581. - Permits; special permits; exceptions. 
(a)  No building or premises shall be connected with any sewer or water main and no plumbing shall be installed or reconstructed without a written permit issued by the city inspector, upon written application, giving the location for the work to be done. Permits shall be issued only to licensed, bonded plumbers, except that permits may be issued to property owners who personally do their own repair work upon their own premises, occupied by them, but all such work shall be subject to, and approved by, the plumbing inspector. All work shall be in charge of the party to whom the permit is issued. A plumber's helper shall be permitted to work only when accompanied by a certified plumber. No work shall be done under a permit that is not authorized therein, and additional permits shall be required for all additional work. 
(b)  When alterations are to be made which cannot be practically constructed in accordance with this article, a special permit may be issued by the plumbing inspector if, in his judgment, the conditions require such alterations. 
(c)  No permit shall be issued to make a connection with any main or lateral for the purpose of sewer installation on any property which has been assessed for the costs of sewers, until application has been made to the governing body and permission obtained to make such connection and the conditions of such permission have been complied with (see chapter 86 of this Code). 
(d)  No permit shall be required for minor repair work, such as repairing leaks in pipes, traps or cocks; opening up stoppage in traps, soil, water, vent or supply pipes; replacing broken fixtures when soil, waste or vent pipes are not disturbed. 
(Code 1995, § 4-510; Ord. No. 3102, § 1, 5-20-2013) 
Sec. 18-582. - Inspection fees. 
    The city inspector shall charge an inspection fee as set forth in section 18-74, or amendments thereto. 
(Code 1995, § 4-511) 
Sec. 18-583. - Tests and inspections. 
(a)  The water or air test for the roughing-in and the smoke or peppermint test of the final test may be applied by the plumber. All piping, traps and fixtures of a plumbing system shall be inspected by the city inspector to ensure compliance with all of the requirements of this article and construction of the system in accordance with the approved plans and the permit. There shall be a minimum of three inspections, as follows: 
(1)  First inspection. The first inspection is conducted when the sewer or septic tank is laid and before it is covered; 
(2)  Second inspection. The second inspection is made of soil, waste and vented pipes; 
(3)  Third inspection. The third inspection is made when the whole system is completed and the water is turned on. 
(b)  When the plumbing in any building is complete, the plumber may secure for the owner of such building a certificate of inspection, signed by the city inspector, certifying that the plumbing work has been properly done and inspected or tested as required by the provisions of this article. It shall be the duty of the city inspector to issue such certificate or release slip if the work is approved. The city inspector, at any reasonable time, shall have free access to all premises using a sewer or water system for the purpose of examining any connection with the sewer or water system for any failure to comply with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1995, § 4-512) 
Sec. 18-584. - Construction requirements. 
    No certificate of inspection shall be issued unless the plumbing installation is in strict conformity with the provisions set forth in this article. 
(Code 1995, § 4-513) 
Sec. 18-585. - Water heaters. 
(a)  Any licensed person, desiring to replace an existing water heater in the same location only, in the city, shall file an application with, and obtain a permit from, the city inspector. The application shall state the name of the occupant, street address of the building in which the installation is to be made and the location in the building. The fee for the permit shall be as set by resolution of the governing body, which fee shall be paid into the treasury of the city. The permit shall not entitle the holder thereof to do any other piping in any potable water system, nor make any connection, alteration or addition to the drainage system whatsoever. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the city inspector to issue all permits and make inspections of all new installations and replacements of existing water heaters as requested by applicants for permits. The fee for each inspection shall be as set by resolution of the governing body. Failure to call for and obtain an inspection shall constitute a violation of this article and shall be cause for revoking the license of the person making the installation by the governing body. 
(Code 1995, §§ 4-804, 4-805; Ord. No. 3102, § 1, 5-20-2013) 
Secs. 18-586-18-610. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - TECHNICAL STANDARDS 
Subdivision I. - In General 

Sec. 18-611. - International Plumbing Code incorporated. 
    A certain document, three copies of which are on file in the office of the city clerk, being marked and designated as the International Plumbing Code, 2009 edition, including Appendix Chapters B, C, D and E, as published by the International Code Council, be and is hereby adopted as the Plumbing Code of the City of McPherson for regulating and governing the design, construction, quality of materials, erection, installation, alteration, repair location, relocation, replacement, addition to, use or maintenance of plumbing systems as herein provided; providing for the issuance of permits and collection of fees therefor; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of said Plumbing Code on file in the office of the City Clerk of the City of McPherson are hereby referred to, adopted, and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this article, with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if any, prescribed in section 18-612. 
(Code 1995, § 4-501; Ord. No. 2578, § 1(4-501), 3-16-1998; Ord. No. 2741, § 1(4-501), 6-24-2002; Ord. No. 2902, § 1, 12-26-2006; Ord. No. 3098, § 1, 5-20-2013) 
State Law reference- Adoption by reference, K.S.A. 12-3009 et seq., 12-3301 et seq. 
Sec. 18-612. - Amendments. 
(a)  The following sections of said Plumbing Code are hereby revised: 
    Section 101.1. Insert: City of McPherson for [Name of Jurisdiction] 
    Section 106.6.2. Insert: Such fees as are set forth in resolution of the governing body of the City of McPherson, as amended from time to time for [Appropriate Schedule]. 
    Section 106.6.3. Insert: 80% in place of [Specify Percentage]. 
    Section 108.4. Insert: Misdemeanor for [Specify Offense], $500 for [amount], 30 days for [Number of days]. 
    Section 108.5. Insert: $250 as minimum fine, $500 as maximum fine, as appropriate for [amount]. 
    Section 305.6.1. Insert: 12 inches for [Number]. 
    Section 904.1. Insert: 6 inches for [Number]. 
    Section 1002.1. Add the following exception: (4). Two traps may be installed on a single trap arm that serves a residential kitchen sink installation. 
(b)  The following sections are hereby added to said Plumbing Code: 
    Section 605.14.6, to read: Copper pipe for water flow shall have a weight of not less than type L. 
    Section 605.15.5, to read: Copper tubing for water flow shall have a weight of not less than type L. 
(Code 1995, § 4-501A; Ord. No. 2578, § 1(4-501A), 3-16-1998; Ord. No. 2741, § 1(4-501A), 6-24-2002; Ord. No. 2902, § 2, 12-26-2006; Ord. No. 3098, § 2, 5-20-2013) 
Sec. 18-613. - Building official. 
    Whenever the term "building official" is used in the edition of the International Plumbing Code adopted in by the city, it shall be construed to mean the city inspector or his authorized representative. The powers and duties of the building official shall be as set forth in the International Plumbing Code incorporated by reference in section 18-611. 
(Code 1995, § 4-504; Ord. No. 2902, § 3, 12-26-2006; Ord. No. 3102, § 1, 5-20-2013) 
Cross reference- Officers and employees, § 2-61 et seq.; appointed officers and employees generally, § 2-81 et seq. 
Sec. 18-614. - Water conservation methods. 
    Fixtures used in all new construction within the city shall conform to the following performance requirements: 
(1)  All showers shall be equipped with showerheads designed to deliver not more than three gallons of water per minute. Variable flow showerheads shall not deliver more than three gallons of water per minute at the maximum setting. 
(2)  All faucets shall be designed or equipped with flow restricting devices so as to deliver not more than four gallons of water per minute. 
(3)  All water closets (toilets) shall be designed to operate on the capacity as required by the applicable plumbing code or water conservation program as dictated by the board of public utilities, per flush, in accordance with the manufacturer's specifications. 
(Code 1995, § 4-502) 
Sec. 18-615. - Water cooled air conditioners. 
    All newly installed water cooled air conditioners shall be designed with a water recirculation system. 
(Code 1995, § 4-503) 
Sec. 18-616. - Public swimming pools. 
    A building permit shall be required for all public swimming pools. Fees for the permit shall be the same as for buildings of equivalent value and as provided in section 18-74. Swimming pools accessory to apartment houses are considered public pools for health and safety requirements, but as private pools for zoning requirements. Public swimming pools shall be constructed, maintained and operated in accordance with the state board of health's regulations applying to such pools and in accordance with K.S.A. 65-101, and regulations issued thereunder or future amendments applying at the time of application for a permit. It shall be the duty of the applicant to obtain the regulations and comply with the requirements therein. 
(Code 1995, § 4-517) 
Sec. 18-617. - Private swimming pools. 
    A building permit shall be required for all private swimming pools with a capacity of 5,000 gallons, or four or more feet deep. The fee for the permit shall be the same as for buildings of equivalent value and as provided in section 18-74. A complete set of plans, including a plot plan, shall be filed with the building inspection department at the time of applying for the permit. There shall be a fence not less than five feet high around the entire pool, with a self-closing, self-locking gate. The gate shall lock from inside the pool area. No spring boards shall be permitted if the pool is less than seven feet deep at its deepest point. The pool may be drained into the storm sewer system or street system, if available. No drain may be connected to the sanitary sewer system. Any draining shall be done so that water is not allowed to flow across any adjoining property on its way to a street or other surface drain without permission from the adjoining landowner, and no health or public safety hazard shall be created by such draining. 
(Code 1995, § 4-516) 
Sec. 18-618. - Approved uses for plastic pipes. 
    Approved uses for plastic pipes shall be as follows: 
Materials Specifications Water service ABS CS 254-65 Cold water distribution PVC CS 207-60, CS 256-63 Outside buildings and structures PE CS 255-63 All plastic pipes must be approved by the National Foundation and be marked with a NSF seal, including the above commercial standards. (Code 1995, § 4-518) 
Sec. 18-619. - Water service and connections. 
    The board of public utilities of the city shall furnish and install the tap on the water main, the water service from the main to the meter tile, the curb cock, the meter yoke, the meter, and the meter tile. The connection fee for the tap shall be established and collected by the board of public utilities. The center of the meter tile shall be located in the parking area, approximately eight feet from the property line. The balance of the water service shall be furnished by the owner and installed by the plumber. The minimum size and the quality of the service pipe from the meter to the distributing system shall be three-fourths-inch type K copper, five-eighths-inch extra strong lead pipe, three-fourths-inch IPS brass pipe, three-fourths-inch galvanized steel or galvanized wrought iron pipe or two-inch class 150 cast iron pipe. Whenever plastic pipe is installed in the maintenance or repair of existing metal water service lines, the plumber installing the plastic pipe shall notify the owner and inspection department. All joints and connections shall be malleable iron screw type, brass screw type, copper flanged or cast iron caulked. Buildings with basements shall have a brass stop and waste valve on the service pipe inside and near the entrance into the building. Buildings with a crawl space, without basements, shall have an accessible stop and waste at the beginning of the distribution system at it slowest available level aboveground, inside the foundation wall. Buildings with slab floor construction shall have a stop and waste located inside the building, not more than six inches above the finished floor elevation. 
(Code 1995, § 4-514) 
Cross reference- Water system, § 86-31 et seq. 
Sec. 18-620. - Septic tanks. 
    Septic tanks may be used to receive the discharge from plumbing fixtures only upon written permission from the board of health, and such permission shall only be given when a public wastewater disposal system is not available. Such tanks, when authorized, shall be located not less than 25 feet from any residence and no closer than ten feet to any accessory building. 
(Code 1995, § 4-515) 
Cross reference- Private sewage treatment system, § 86-121 et seq. 
Sec. 18-621. - Materials and fittings for water softening units or water heaters. 
    All piping shall meet the plumbing code requirements. All new or replaced installations of water softeners installed in the city shall be provided with a bypass, with proper valving, to permit the removal of softeners without the installation of additional piping when the softening unit is not in use. All pipe, fittings, and valves shall be new stock. No used material shall be installed in any new or repaired installation. 
(Code 1995, § 4-803) 
Cross reference- Water softening units or water heaters, § 18-791 et seq. 
Secs. 18-622-18-640. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Nonmetallic Pipe Generally 

Sec. 18-641. - Required for cold water service. 
(a)  Only polyvinyl chloride (PVC) NSF approved, schedule 40, pipe and fittings which meet commercial standards established by the United States Department of Commerce shall be used in potable cold water services for such applications as well to building, well drop pipe, main to building service lines and cold water lines inside the building. 
(b)  Such plastic pipe shall comply with the following applicable commercial standards: 
(1)  ABS CS 218-59; 
(2)  ABS CS 219-59; 
(3)  ABS CS 220-59; 
(4)  ABS S 254-63; 
(5)  ABS CS 270-65; 
(6)  PVC S 272-65; 
(7)  Polyethylene CS 255-63; and 
(8)  Federal Housing Administration Publication MPS Rev. 31. 
(Code 1995, § 4-520) 
Sec. 18-642. - Termination of plastic supply branch. 
    If plastic pipe is used to distribute cold water in the building, the plastic supply branch leading to a domestic hot water heating unit or a space heating boiler shall terminate not less than ten feet from the supply opening of the heating equipment. In distribution systems, including a space heating boiler, a pressure relief valve and expansion tank of two gallons' capacity or two percent of the volume of the hot water system, whichever may be greater, shall be installed on the hot water system to prevent pressure build-up which would cause the pressure relief valve to discharge prior to the hazard. 
(Code 1995, § 4-521) 
Sec. 18-643. - Water heaters. 
    When hot water heaters are installed on plastic cold water supply lines, the plastic pipe shall terminate at least ten feet from the water heater. There shall be a check valve installed at the end of the plastic pipe. 
(Code 1995, § 4-522) 
Cross reference- Water softening units or water heaters, § 18-791 et seq. 
Sec. 18-644. - Pressure relief valves. 
(a)  Pressure relief valves shall be installed for all equipment used for heating or storage of hot water. Each valve shall be rated as to its BTU capacity at 140 degrees Fahrenheit, and shall be capable of discharging sufficient hot water to prevent any further rise in temperature. 
(b)  Plastic pipe as set forth in this section shall comply with the following applicable commercial standards: 
(1)  ABS CS 254-63; 
(2)  PVC CS 2079-60. 
(Code 1995, § 4-523) 
Sec. 18-645. - Seal of approval. 
    Drain-waste-vent plastic pipe must bear the National Sanitation Foundation Seal of Approval for SWV (NSF-SWV). 
(Code 1995, § 4-524) 
Sec. 18-646. - Contaminating materials. 
    Some of the common materials used around building construction and warehouses which will contaminate polyethylene include gasoline, lubricating oils, liquid or gaseous fuels, aromatic compounds, paint solvents, paint thinners, paints and acid solders. Any pipe which has been in contact with such materials is no longer suitable for use as potable water pipe and must be rejected. 
(Code 1995, § 4-525) 
Sec. 18-647. - Installation. 
    Polyethylene pipe must be cut by a knife or hand saw. The edges of the cut end are to be smoothed with a knife or rough file. 
(Code 1995, § 4-526) 
Sec. 18-648. - Expansion and contraction. 
    Polyethylene has a linear coefficient expansion of 8.3 × 10.5 per inch of length, per Fahrenheit degree. For each ten degree Fahrenheit change in temperature, an allowance of contraction and expansion of one inch per 100 feet of pipe shall be allowed. In trench work, this may be accomplished by snaking the pipe in the bottom of the ditch to take up the slack allowed. The snaking shall be uniform throughout the length of the ditch. 
(Code 1995, § 4-527) 
Sec. 18-649. - Lubricants. 
    Only water should be used to lubricate the pipe and fittings which are to be joined. The use of pipe dope, oil, detergents or other chemicals is prohibited. 
(Code 1995, § 4-528) 
Sec. 18-650. - Attachments to metallic systems. 
    When attaching plastic lines to metallic systems, it is recommended that an insert adapter be used. The insert adapter is to be attached to the plastic pipe in the same manner as other plastic insert fittings. The threaded end only of the adapter is to be coated with a plastic joint compound and tightened into the female connection. Joint compound shall not be used in the plastic pipe itself. 
(Code 1995, § 4-529) 
Sec. 18-651. - Installation. 
(a)  ABS pipe. ABS (acrylonitrile-butadiene styrene) pipe shall be installed in accordance with the Installation Manual for ABS Pipe and Fittings, published by the Society of the Plastic Industry, Inc., 250 Park Avenue, New York, New York 10805, dated January 1, 1962. The trenching, laying and backfilling procedures presented in sections 41 and 44 of such manual shall be followed in the use of ABS pipe installed underground. 
(b)  PVC pipe. PVC (polyvinyl chloride) pipe shall be installed in accordance with the Tentative Installation Manual for PVC Pipe and Fittings, published by the Society of the Plastic Industry, Inc., dated May 12, 1961. 
(c)  Addendums. The Installation Manual for ABS Pipe and Fittings and the Tentative Installation Manual for PVC Pipe and Fittings, both published by the Society of the Plastic Industry, Inc., are in accordance with approved policies of the city and should be considered as an addendum to the manuals cited in subsections (a) and (b) of this section. 
(Code 1995, §§ 4-530, 4-531) 
Secs. 18-652-18-670. - Reserved. 
Subdivision III. - Sewers and Drains[13] 

Footnotes: 
--- (13) --- 
Cross reference- Sewers and sewage disposal, § 86-91 et seq. 

Sec. 18-671. - Plastic sewer, drain pipe and fittings. 
    Plastic sewer and drain pipe and fittings are suitable for nonpressure drainage of sewage and drain water where resistance to deterioration from water and chemicals, dimensional stability, resistance to aging and strong light joints are required. For the purposes of this section, the term "sewage" means the water carrying human or organic wastes, together with such underground water, surface water, stormwater or other water as may be present. 
(Code 1995, § 4-532) 
Sec. 18-672. - Building sewers. 
    The building sewer and drain pipe is the lowest part of the piping of a drainage system which conveys its contents to a public sewer, private sewer, individual sewage disposal system or other points of disposal. 
(Code 1995, § 4-533) 
Sec. 18-673. - Storm drainage. 
    The storm drain is the part of the disposal system used for conveying rainwater, surface water, groundwater, subsurface water, condensate or similar discharge of a building storm sewer or a combined building sewer. 
(Code 1995, § 4-534) 
Sec. 18-674. - Leaching system for septic tank effluents. 
    The leaching system is that part of the system which would receive the liquid discharge from a septic tank for further treatment under the surface of the ground through a system of four-inch minimum size perforated pipe laid in gravel or crushed stone, with a minimum of not less than six inches below and above the pipe. 
(Code 1995, § 4-535) 
Sec. 18-675. - Footing drains. 
    Footing drains compose the portion of the drainage system which is used to surround the outer walls of a building for subsoil drainage. Such pipe should be perforated. Drainage should then be conveyed through unperforated pipe to a sump pump, storm sewer or point of disposal. 
(Code 1995, § 4-536) 
Sec. 18-676. - Sanitary sewers; storm sewers. 
(a)  A sanitary sewer is a pipe which carries sewage and is intended to exclude stormwater, surface water and groundwater. 
(b)  A storm sewer is a pipe used for conveying rain water, surface water, groundwater, subsurface water, condensate, cooling water or other similar discharges. 
(Code 1995, § 4-537) 
Sec. 18-677. - Size specifications. 
(a)  Building sewers shall be a minimum of four inches in diameter, but not less than the minimum size required for the installation served. 
(b)  Foundation footing drains and building storm drains shall be a minimum of three inches in diameter. 
(Code 1995, § 4-538) 
Sec. 18-678. - Pipe jointing methods. 
    Connections for solid pipes shall be made by solvent welding. Such requirement does not exclude other types of connection. The socket and the pipe or fitting which fits in the socket shall be free of dirt, grease or foreign matter. The socket and pipe shall immediately be forced together with a slight twisting motion, if possible, to ensure full engagement of the pipe end into the socket. Reasonable handling is permissible within one to two minutes before jointing. Plastic pipe connections to a pipe made of other materials shall be sealed by solvent cement, cement mortar or other methods recommended by the manufacturer, provided the joint tightness test as described in CS 207-60 and CS 256-63 can be met. 
(Code 1995, § 4-539) 
Sec. 18-679. - Testing. 
    The building sewer shall be tested by insertion of a test plug at the point of connection with the public sewer. It shall then be filled with water under a head of not less than ten feet. The water level at the top of the test head of water shall not drop for at least 15 minutes. 
(Code 1995, § 4-540) 
Sec. 18-680. - Pipe marking. 
    Marking of pipe will be in accordance with commercial standards. 
(Code 1995, § 4-541) 
Sec. 18-681. - Trenches. 
    Trench depth for building sewers connecting to sewer mains shall be sufficient to provide a minimum cover depth of 30 inches under driveways and streets. No minimum cover depth is prescribed for building storm sewers, subsoil drains or pipes used in septic tank installations, because of outfall location and elevation. 
(Code 1995, § 4-542) 
Sec. 18-682. - Trench width. 
    Trench width shall be sufficient to provide at least four inches of clearance on both sides of the pipe. A firm, smooth foundation shall be provided for the pipe. The ditch shall be excavated to a depth to provide at least two inches of thoroughly compacted sand or earth, free of rocks or debris, under the pipe, except where existing soil is adequately clean and sound. 
(Code 1995, § 4-543) 
Sec. 18-683. - Grade. 
    The grade shall be established in accordance with good, sound engineering practices for a given flow and size of pipe, and shall not be less than one-fourth inch per running foot. 
(Code 1995, § 4-544) 
Sec. 18-684. - Backfilling. 
    The pipe shall be firmly bedded and backfilled with selected backfill material, free of rocks, boulders and foreign matter over one inch in diameter, to at least three inches above the pipe. Backfill is to be tamped in thin layers not exceeding four inches in depth, and thoroughly compacted to provide solid support between the sides of the pipe and the sides of the ditch. The remainder of ditch may be mechanically filled, if desired, and should be compacted by puddling, flooding or tamping. Stones larger than eight inches at their greatest dimension shall not be used in the backfill. 
(Code 1995, § 4-545) 
Sec. 18-685. - Lawn sprinkling systems. 
    The provisions for water service lines shall apply, except the minimum working pressure of polyvinyl chloride (PVC) shall be 160 pounds per square inch. 
(Code 1995, § 4-546) 
Sec. 18-686. - Backflow prevention. 
    Each lawn sprinkling system shall be equipped with adequate backflow preventers or antisiphon devices, according to existing Uniform Plumbing Code requirements. 
(Code 1995, § 4-547) 
Sec. 18-687. - Swimming pools. 
    Water service lines to swimming pools may be plastic in accordance with provisions for water service lines. Circulating lines in the filter system may be plastic in accordance with provisions for water service lines. Drain lines for swimming pools must conform to all ordinances. 
(Code 1995, § 4-548) 
Sec. 18-688. - Use regulations. 
    No plastic pipe may be used under swimming pool property. Plastic pipe may be used under decks, sidewalks, etc. 
(Code 1995, § 4-549) 
Secs. 18-689-18-710. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - PLUMBERS[14] 

Footnotes: 
--- (14) --- 
State Law reference- Regulation of plumbers, K.S.A. 12-1508 et seq. 

Sec. 18-711. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Employing plumber means any person who employs plumbers for the purpose of doing a plumbing business. 
    Fixtures means showers, showerheads, faucets (not including faucets used for dishwashers, washing machines and bathtubs) and water closets (toilets). 
    Journeyman plumber means any person who does plumbing work for others and who is not a master or employing plumber, as defined in this section. 
    Master plumber means any person who is a practical plumber and has charge of doing plumbing work either as a foreman or contractor. 
    New construction means any residential, commercial or industrial construction of buildings of whatever nature or kind within the city, not complete or under construction 90 days after the effective date of Ordinance No. 2254. 
    Plumbing includes the pipes and fixtures, and appurtenances thereto, which are used to connect the water and sewage from the main or property line and distribute it in or about any premises or building, for any use whatsoever, and all pipes or appurtenances used, or to be used, for conveying sewage, liquids or potable water within or outside of foundation walls of any building and connected with the public sewers or approved private sewage disposal system, and all pipes and appurtenances used to ventilate the drains, fixtures and traps in the building so connected, and all pipes and connections through which gases, vapors or waters of any kind may discharge into septic tanks and cesspools or public sewers. 
    Water means water received from the distribution system of the board of public utilities of the city or any extension thereof. 
(Code 1995, § 4-505) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 18-712. - Board of examiners. 
    The construction advisory board of trades and board of appeals shall serve as a board of examiners of plumbers. 
(Code 1995, § 4-507; Ord. No. 3202, § 1, 2-15-2016) 
Cross reference- Boards and commissions, § 2-281 et seq. 
State Law reference- Board of examiners authorized, K.S.A. 12-1503. 
Sec. 18-713. - License required; application; bond; fees; expiration; renewal; fraudulent use. 
(a)  Before engaging in the business of installing or repairing water supply or sewer pipes, or plumbing fixtures, every master plumber or employing plumber shall apply to the city for a license to conduct a plumbing business within the city. The application shall be made on a form provided by the city, and shall be accompanied by a bond, with sureties approved by the governing body, in the sum as set by resolution of the governing body, on condition that the plumber will indemnify and hold harmless the city from all liability from any accident or damage arising from negligence in performing the plumber's work or from any inadequate work done, or from misrepresentation regarding work done pursuant to the license, and on the further condition that the plumber will fill all excavations made so as to leave the alley, sidewalk, parking, street and pavement in the same grade and condition as when it was found, and on the further condition than the plumber will comply with all city ordinances relative to the plumber's work. The application shall be accompanied by an initial license fee as set by resolution of the governing body. 
(b)  All licenses shall expire on December 31 of each year. Renewal licenses shall be issued upon payment of a renewal fee as set by resolution of the governing body and the furnishing of evidence of continuation of the plumber's bond. 
(c)  No person who has obtained a plumber's license shall allow his name to be used by another person, either for the purpose of obtaining permits or for conducting the plumbing trade or business under such other plumber's license. 
(d)  Any person engaging in the plumbing trade or business in the city without first obtaining a license provided for in this section shall be guilty of a violation of this article. 
(e)  If a license is not renewed by February 1, the new license fee will be as set by resolution of the governing body. 
(Code 1995, § 4-509A) 
Sec. 18-714. - Examination required. 
(a)  No person shall engage in the business of installing, repairing or altering of plumbing unless the performance of the plumbing work, performed in the course of such business, is under the direct supervision of a certified master plumber. 
(b)  Any person requesting a master plumber's examination shall have had at least six years' practical experience or the equivalent. Any person requesting a journeyman plumber's examination shall have had at least three years' practical experience or the equivalent, in the judgment of the board, and shall be recommended to the board in writing by a master plumber who has supervision over the applicant. 
(c)  Any person desiring to engage in the business of, or work at, plumbing, either as a master or employing plumber, or journeyman plumber, in the city, shall make application to the board as provided for in section 18-712, and shall, at such time and place as the board may designate, be compelled to pass such examination as to his qualifications as the board may direct. The examination may be made in whole, or in part, in writing and shall be of a practical and elementary character, but sufficiently strict to test the qualifications of the applicant. Any plumber who has been granted a certificate by another city in the state under the provisions of K.S.A. 12-1501-12-1507, and subsequent amendments thereto, shall be allowed to engage in the business of, or work at, plumbing, according to the grade of the certificate, without any further examination, but validity of the certificate shall first be determined by the board. 
(Code 1995, § 4-506; Ord. No. 3202, § 1, 2-15-2016) 
Sec. 18-715. - Examination times and places; issuance of certificates; fees; record of proceedings; reexaminations. 
(a)  The board shall, as soon as possible after their appointment, meet and then designate the times and places for examination of all applicants desiring to engage in the business of, or work at, plumbing within the city. 
(b)  The board shall examine the applicants' practical knowledge of plumbing, and, if satisfied with the competency of such applicants, shall thereupon issue certificates to such applicants, authorizing them to engage in the business of, or work at, plumbing, either as a master or employing plumber, or as journeyman plumber. 
(c)  The fee for the examination for a master plumber and journeyman plumber shall be the rate as set forth by Prometric or International Code Council (ICC) examination service. 
(d)  The fee for a certificate for a master or employing plumber, or journeyman plumber shall be as set by resolution of the governing body. All fees received by the board shall be paid into the treasury of the city. 
(e)  No applicant shall be reexamined until after the expiration of at least 30 days from the date of his examination. 
(Code 1995, § 4-508; Ord. No. 2578, § 1(4-508), 3-16-1998; Ord. No. 2741, § 1(4-508), 6-24-2002; Ord. No. 3102, § 1, 5-20-2013; Ord. No. 3202, § 1, 2-15-2016) 
Sec. 18-716. - Master plumbers' examinations. 
    Any person engaged as a master plumber, either as an owner or an employee of a firm or corporation in the business of installing or repairing water supply or sewer pipe, or plumbing fixtures for any purpose and acting in a supervisory capacity, shall hold a master plumber's certificate issued by the city. Before being issued a certificate, except as a renewal of an existing certificate, the applicant shall apply by letter to the board and shall present a certificate issued by the governing body or another licensing jurisdiction, demonstrating passage of the Prometric or International Code Council (ICC) license examination, and his knowledge of local ordinance amendments governing such work. The examination may consist of the standard examination for the determination of competency of plumbing contractors and plumbers, based upon current codes and standards prepared and published and available upon such date from Prometric (prometric.com) or International Code Council (ICC) (www.iccsafe.org). The fee for a master plumber's examination shall be the rate as set forth by Prometric or International Code Council (ICC) examination service, plus such additional fee as may be necessary to reimburse the city for its costs. The fee for a master plumber's certificate shall be as set by resolution of the governing body, which fees, along with examination fees, shall be deposited to the general fund of the city. An applicant must demonstrate or achieve a 75 percent passing score to be eligible for the issuance of a certificate. The certificate issued shall contain or be accompanied by an endorsement indicating that the plumber has taken the Prometric or International Code Council (ICC) examination prescribed by this section, if taken, and showing the passing score thereon obtained by the applicant. 
(Code 1995, § 4-509; Ord. No. 2578, § 1(4-509), 3-16-1998; Ord. No. 2741, § 1(4-509), 6-24-2002; Ord. No. 3102, § 1, 5-20-2013; Ord. No. 3202, § 1, 2-15-2016) 
Sec. 18-717. - Journeyman plumbers' examinations. 
    Any person engaged as a journeyman plumber doing plumbing work for others shall hold a journeyman plumber's certificate issued by the city. Before being issued a certificate, the applicant shall demonstrate successful passage of the Prometric or International Code Council (ICC) license examination or apply to the board for examination as a journeyman plumber according to the procedure prescribed in section 18-716 for master plumbers. The board shall issue a journeyman certificate to all qualified journeyman plumbers prior to their commencing work as a journeyman plumber in the city. The fee for examination shall be the rate as set forth by Prometric or International Code Council (ICC) examination service, plus such additional fee as may be necessary to reimburse the city for its costs. The fee for a certificate shall be as set by resolution of the governing body, which fees shall be deposited in the general fund of the city. 
(Code 1995, § 4-509B; Ord. No. 2578, § 1(4-509B), 3-16-1998; Ord. No. 2741, § 1(4-509B), 6-24-2002; Ord. No. 3102, § 1, 5-20-2013; Ord. No. 3202, § 1, 2-15-2016) 
Sec. 18-718. - Installation, service or maintenance of water heaters. 
(a)  Before any person shall engage in the business of installing, servicing, maintaining or removal of water heaters, the person shall apply to the board for an examination and certificate denoting competency (restricted plumber's certificate). 
(b)  The board shall examine the applicant, or if a firm or corporation, a representative of the firm or corporation, within ten days from the date of request. The examination, written and oral, shall be elementary, but sufficiently strict to prove the ability of the applicant to properly install and remove the water heaters without damaging or contaminating the potable water system. 
(c)  The fees for the examination and certificate shall be as set by resolution of the governing body. The license fee shall be as set by resolution of the governing body, and shall be accompanied by a surety bond in the sum as set by resolution of the governing body, which shall be deposited with the city clerk and approved by the governing body prior to issuing a license. The license and certificate shall expire on December 31 of the year issued, and shall be renewed by February 1. 
(d)  Any person engaged in the business of installing water heaters, and not certified by the board, shall maintain in their employ, at all times, a person who has passed an examination and been issued a certificate by the board, who shall personally make all new installations and/or removals in the city. A violation of this subsection shall be sufficient cause for the revoking of the license. Any license revoked for cause shall not be renewed for a period of 30 days. 
(Code 1995, §§ 4-801, 4-802; Ord. No. 3102, § 1, 5-20-2013; Ord. No. 3202, § 1, 2-15-2016) 
Secs. 18-719-18-750. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - CROSS CONNECTION CONTROL 

Sec. 18-751. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Approved means accepted by the board of public utilities as meeting an applicable specification stated or cited in this article, or as suitable for the proposed use. 
    Auxiliary water supply means any water supply on or available to a consumer's premises, other than the public water supply, including water from another purveyor's public potable water supply or any natural source, such as a well, spring, river, stream, etc., or used waters or industrial fluids. 
    Backflow means the reversal of the normal flow of water caused by either backpressure or backsiphonage. 
    Backflow preventer means an assembly or means designed to prevent backflow. The following are approved types of backflow preventers as referred to in this article: 
(1)  Air gap means the unobstructed vertical distance through the free atmosphere between the lowest opening from any pipe or faucet supplying water to a tank, plumbing fixture or other device and the flood level rim of the vessel. An approved air gap shall be at least double the diameter of the supply pipe, measured vertically, above the overflow rim of the vessel, and in no case less than one inch. 
(2)  Atmospheric vacuum breaker means an assembly containing a float check, check seat and air inlet port. The flow of water into the body causes the float to close the air inlet port. When the flow of water stops, the float falls and forms a check valve against backsiphonage and at the same time opens the air inlet port to allow air to enter and satisfy the vacuum. The entire assembly shall meet the design and performance specifications of the AWWA, ASSE or FCCC&HR. The assembly shall be used only to protect against a health hazard caused by a backsiphonage. 
(3)  Double check detector check valve assembly means an assembly composed of a line size approved double check valve assembly with a specific bypass water meter and a meter sized approved double check valve assembly. The entire assembly shall meet the design and performance specifications as determined by the AWWA, ASSE or FCCC&HR. To be approved, such assemblies must be readily accessible for in-line testing and maintenance. The assembly shall only be used to protect against a nonpollution hazard. 
(4)  Double check valve assembly means an assembly of two independently operating approved check valves with resilient seated shutoff valves on each end of the check valves, plus properly located resilient seated test cocks for the testing of each check valve. The entire assembly shall meet the design and performance specifications as determined by the AWWA, ASSE or FCCC&HR. To be approved, such assemblies must be readily accessible for in-line testing and maintenance. The assembly shall only be used to protect against a nonpollution hazard. 
(5)  Pressure vacuum breaker means an assembly containing an independently operating, internally located check valve and an independently operating, loaded air inlet valve located on the discharge side of the check valve. The assembly is to be equipped with properly located test cocks and tightly closing shutoff valves attached at each end of the assembly. The entire assembly shall meet the design and performance specifications of the AWWA, ASSE or FCCC&HR. The assembly shall be used only to protect against a health hazard under backsiphonage conditions. 
(6)  Reduced pressure principle assembly means an assembly of two independently acting, soft seated, approved check valves, together with a hydraulically operating, mechanically independent, differential pressure relief valve located between the check valves and at the same time below the first check valve. The unit shall contain properly located resilient seated test cocks and resilient seated shutoff valves at each end of the assembly. The entire assembly shall meet the design and performance specifications as determined by the American Water Works Association (AWWA), the American Society of Sanitary Engineering (ASSE) or the Foundation for Cross Connection Control and Hydraulic Research of the University of Southern California (FCCC&HR). The assembly shall operate to maintain the pressure in the zone between the two check valves at an acceptable level less than the pressure on the public water supply side of the assembly. At cessation of a normal flow, the pressure between the two check valves shall be less than the pressure on the public water supply side of the assembly. In case of leakage of either of the check valves, the differential relief valve shall operate to maintain the reduced pressure in the zone between the check valves by discharging to the atmosphere. When the inlet pressure is two pounds per square inch or less, the relief valve shall open to the atmosphere. To be approved, such assemblies must be readily accessible for in-line testing and maintenance. The assembly shall be used to protect against a health hazard. 
(7)  Reduced pressure principle detector assembly means an assembly composed of a line size approved reduced pressure principle backflow preventer with a specific bypass water meter and a meter size approved reduced pressure principle backflow preventer. The entire assembly shall meet the design and performance specifications as determined by the AWWA, ASSE or FCCC&HR. The assembly shall be used to protect against a health hazard. 
    Backpressure means the flow of water or other liquids, mixtures or substances under pressure into the distribution pipes of the system from any source, other than the intended source. 
    Backsiphonage means the flow of water or other liquids, mixtures or substances into the distribution pipes of the system from any source, other than its intended source, caused by the reduction of pressure in the system. 
    BPU means the board of public utilities of the city. 
    Certified tester means a licensed plumber or an employee of a licensed plumber in the city who has completed a training course approved by the BPU. Maintenance men who have completed a training course approved by the BPU will be considered certified testers at their place of employment. Licensed fire sprinkler contractors who have completed a training course approved by the BPU will be considered certified testers. All certified testers shall be recertified at no less than three-year intervals and provide BPU with documentation showing they have completed an approved training class within the three-year time period. Failure to perform work in conformity with this article or the manufacturer's installation requirements and procedures, provide training documentation, or correctly perform operational tests may be cause for loss of being classified as a certified tester. BPU may establish further policies and procedures deemed reasonably necessary to administer its certified tester program. 
    Consumer means any person actually ingesting water supplied by the BPU. 
    Contamination means an impairment of the quality of the potable water by sewage, industrial fluids or waste liquids, compounds or other materials, to a degree which creates an actual or potential hazard to the public health through poisoning or the spread of disease. 
    Cross connection means any physical connection or arrangement of piping or fixtures between two otherwise separate piping systems, one of which contains potable water distributed through the system and the other nonpotable water or industrial fluids of questionable safety, through which, or because of which, backflow may occur into the system, including any temporary connections, such as swing connections, removable sections, four-way plug valves, spools, dummy sectors of pipes, garden hoses, swivels or change-over devices, or sliding multiport tubes. 
    Cross connection control by containment means the installation of an approved backflow preventer at the water service connection to any customer's premises where it is physically infeasible to find and permanently eliminate or control all actual or potential cross connections within the customer's water system, or, such term shall mean the installation of an approved backflow preventer on the service line leading to and supplying a portion of a customer's water system where there are actual or potential cross connections which cannot be effectively eliminated or controlled at the point of the cross connection. 
    Cross connection controlled means a connection between the system and a nonpotable water system with an approved backflow preventer, properly installed and maintained so that it will continuously afford backflow protection commensurate with the degree of hazard. 
    Customer means any person or entity purchasing potable water from the BPU and making a water service connection to the system. 
    Fertilizer means chemicals placed in soil to improve the quality and quantity of growth. 
    Hazard, degree of, means an evaluation of the potential risk to public health and the adverse effect of the hazard upon the potable water system. 
(1)  Health hazard means any condition, device or practice which could create, or, in the judgment of the BPU, may create, a danger to the health and well-being of the water customer. 
(2)  Pollution hazard means an actual or potential threat to the physical properties of water which would constitute a nuisance or be aesthetically objectionable or could cause damage to the system or its appurtenances, but would not be dangerous to health. 
    Overhaul means a complete replacement of all internal parts. 
    Pesticide means any chemical used for killing insects or foliage. 
    Pollution means the presence of any foreign substance (organic, inorganic or biological) in water which degrades its quality so as to constitute a hazard or impair the usefulness or quality of the water to a degree which does not create an actual hazard to the public health, but which does adversely and unreasonably affect such water for domestic use. 
    Portable equipment means equipment not permanently connected to the system. 
    System means the BPU's water source facilities and distribution system, constituting the public water system serving the city and its environs and shall include all the facilities of the water system under the complete control of the BPU, up to the point where the customer's system begins. The source shall include all components of the facilities utilized in the production, treatment, storage and delivery of water to the distribution system. The distribution system shall include the network of conduits used for the delivery of water from the source to the customer's system. The customer's system shall include the parts downstream of the water service connection. 
    Water, nonpotable, means water which is not safe for human consumption, according to recognized standards, or which is of questionable potability. 
    Water, potable, means any water which, according to recognized standards, is safe for human consumption. 
    Water service connection means the terminal end of a service connection from the system (i.e., the point to which the BPU loses jurisdiction and sanitary control over the water). If a meter is installed at the end of the service connection, then the term "service connection" means the downstream end of the meter. There should be no unprotected takeoffs from the service line ahead of any meter or any backflow preventer located at the point of delivery to the customer's water system. The term "service connection" shall also include water service connection for a fire hydrant and all other temporary or emergency water service connections from the system. 
(Code 1995, § 4-5B03; Ord. No. 3049, § 2, 3-12-2012) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 18-752. - Purposes. 
    The purposes of this article are to: 
(1)  Protect the public water supply of the city from the possibility of contamination or pollution by isolating potential contamination or pollution within a customer's internal distribution system or private water system; 
(2)  Promote the elimination or control of existing cross connections, actual or potential, between a customer's in-plant potable water system and nonpotable water system, plumbing fixtures and industrial piping systems; and 
(3)  Provide for the maintenance of a continuing program of cross connection control which will systematically and effectively prevent the contamination or pollution of all potable water systems. 
(Code 1995, § 4-5B01) 
Sec. 18-753. - Responsibility for system protection. 
    The BPU shall be responsible for the protection of the system from contamination or pollution due to the backflow of contaminants or pollutants through water service connections. If, in the judgment of the BPU, an approved backflow preventer is required at the customer's water service connection or within the customer's private water system for the safety of the system, the BPU shall give notice in writing to the customer to install an approved backflow preventer at specific locations on the customer's premises. The customer shall install such backflow preventer at his own expense, and failure, refusal or inability on the part of the customer to install, have tested and maintain the backflow preventer shall constitute grounds for discontinuing water service from the system to the customer's premises until such requirements have been satisfactorily met. 
(Code 1995, § 4-5B02) 
Sec. 18-754. - Connection requirements. 
    The following are required for water service connections to the system: 
(1)  No water service connection to any customer's premises shall be installed or maintained by the BPU unless the water supply is protected as required by this article. Service of water shall be discontinued if a backflow preventer required by this article is not installed, tested and maintained, or if it is found that a backflow preventer has been removed or bypassed, or if an unprotected cross connection exists on the premises. Service will not be restored until such conditions or defects are corrected. 
(2)  The customer's system shall be open for inspection at all reasonable times to authorized representatives of the BPU to determine whether cross connections, or other structural or sanitary hazards, including violations of this article, exist. After the inspection of the customer's system, the BPU shall notify the customer in writing of the backflow preventer that must be installed, if any. The customer shall have 90 days after the date of the notification to install the required assembly. Service to the customer will be discontinued if the required assembly is not installed within the 90-day period. 
(3)  It shall be the duty of the customer at any premises where a backflow preventer is installed to have operational tests made upon each installed backflow preventer at least once per year. In the instances where the BPU deems the hazard to be greater, operational tests may be required at more frequent intervals. If the installed backflow preventer fails its operational test, it shall be repaired. If the unit cannot pass the test it shall be replaced. A repaired, replaced or new device shall pass an operational test before being placed in service. The inspections and tests shall be at the expense of the customer and shall be performed by a certified tester. BPU may notify the customer when the annual inspection is to be performed, but the lack of notice shall not be a defense. The certified tester must use and BPU will provide backflow prevention assembly test report forms which shall be signed by the certified tester and returned to the BPU. If the legible and complete test report form is not received by BPU within 14 days of its due date, BPU may charge the customer an administration fee equal to $25.00 per device for each day beginning on the 15th day after the test report is due and ending on the date of receipt or termination of service. Failure to perform the annual test or supply the BPU with the completed test report form by the test due date will constitute cause for termination of service. The BPU shall set from time to time a fee for termination and reconnection of service under this section and any other policies, procedures and standards reasonably necessary to efficiently or effectively implement the testing required herein. 
(4)  All portable equipment used for fertilizer and pesticide application shall be free of any cross connection or be separated from the system by a backflow preventer as determined by the BPU. 
(Code 1995, § 4-5B04; Ord. No. 2535, § 1, 11-12-1996; Ord. No. 3049, § 1, 3-12-2012) 
Sec. 18-755. - Installations required. 
(a)  The critical level of all atmospheric vacuum breakers shall be six inches above the overflow level of the container or highest point on the system. An atmospheric vacuum breaker shall not be used under constant pressure conditions and no normally closed valves shall be located downstream of the assembly. 
(b)  The critical level of all pressure vacuum breakers shall be 12 inches above the overflow level of the container being supplied. Valves may be located downstream from the assembly. 
(c)  If a reduced pressure principle backflow preventer is placed in a pit, the pit must contain a drain rated to handle 1.5 times the rated flow of the relief valve. 
(d)  All four-inch and larger fire lines shall have either a reduced pressure principle detector assembly or a double check detector check valve assembly as prescribed by the BPU after inspection. 
(e)  A reduced pressure principle backflow preventer will be required on any water service connection to a customer's water system that is also connected to an auxiliary water supply. 
(f)  All hose bibb connections installed after the effective date of Ordinance No. 2314 shall contain a vacuum breaker. 
(g)  All water closet tank fill valves installed after the effective date of Ordinance No. 2314 shall contain a vacuum breaker. 
(h)  Every commercial water service connection with a possible health or pollution degree of hazard cross connection shall install a backflow device, as determined by the BPU, on the water service connection. 
(i)  All lawn sprinkler systems installed after the effective date of Ordinance No. 2314 shall contain a backflow preventer. 
(j)  All lawn sprinkler systems used for fertilizer application shall contain a reduced pressure principle backflow preventer. 
(Code 1995, § 4-5B05; Ord. No. 3049, §§ 3, 4, 3-12-2012) 
Secs. 18-756-18-790. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - WATER SOFTENING UNITS OR WATER HEATERS[15]
