ARTICLE XII. - PRIVATE WATER WELLS[16] 

Footnotes: 
--- (16) --- 
State Law reference- Groundwater Exploration and Protection Act, K.S.A. 82a-1201 et seq. 

Sec. 18-821. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Aquifer means a water bearing strata, usually consisting of unconsolidated sands and gravels, associated with groundwater. 
    Backflow means the flow of water or other liquids, mixtures or substances into the distribution pipes of a potable supply of water from any source. Such term includes backsiphonage. 
    BPU means the board of public utilities. 
    Cross connection means any physical connection between the city's water supply and any fluid waste pipe, soil pipe, sewer, drain or auxiliary water supply, including any potable water supply outlet which is submerged, or can be submerged, in wastewater or any other source of contamination. 
    General manager, BPU, means a licensed professional engineer reporting directly to the board of public utilities. 
    Health hazard means any condition, device or practice on or near the water supply system and its operation which creates, or, in the judgment of the BPU general manager, may create, a danger to the quality of the water. Such term may include, but shall not be limited to, structural defects in the water supply system, whether of location, design or construction, that regularly or occasionally may prevent satisfactory purification of the water supply or cause it to be polluted from extraneous sources. 
(Code 1995, § 4-5A01) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 18-822. - Inspections. 
(a)  Authority to enter property. The BPU general manager or his designated agent shall have the right of enter onto any property, during reasonable hours, for the purpose of making inspections of the systems installed on such property, provided that such entry for the purpose of inspection is made with due course of law. 
(b)  Notification. The BPU general manager shall notify the owner or authorized agent of the owner of any such building or premises to correct, within a reasonable time, any discrepancy that is contrary to, or in violation of, this article and which, in his judgment, may, therefore, permit the pollution of the city water supply or otherwise be a health hazard. 
(Code 1995, § 4-5A02) 
Sec. 18-823. - Permit requirements. 
    Prior to the drilling of a water well within the city limits, the property owner shall comply with the following requirements: 
(1)  The property owner must obtain and exhibit either a permit to appropriate water for beneficial use, issued by the division of water resources, state board of agriculture, or a letter of exemption showing a permit is not necessary. 
(2)  The property owner must submit the following drawings: 
a.  A topographic or contour map of the site where the well is to be drilled. Such map must clearly show all features of surface drainage, previous flood levels and possible water contamination sources of the proposed site. No permit will be issued if any surface drainage can inundate the proposed site. No permit will be issued if the proposed well is located within 50 feet of any sanitary sewer line or sanitary septic field. 
b.  A drawing in elevation view, which will show the proposed depth of the water well, the type of casting, the type of water screen and the type of surface seal that will be used to keep foreign material out of the well. The drawing must indicate the method of pumping the well and the elevation of the pump base and other related structures. 
(3)  The property owner shall sign an affidavit signifying knowledge and intended compliance with any cross connection restrictions established by city ordinance or other regulations propounded by the BPU. Upon approval by the BPU general manager of all submitted material, the BPU general manager shall instruct the city inspector to issue a building permit for the well. 
(Code 1995, § 4-5A03) 
Sec. 18-824. - Special use restrictions. 
    A well drilled for the purpose of thermal heating or cooling must be designated as such on the elevation drawing. A well used to receive discharged water, such as a disposal well discharging into the potable water level of the equus beds, must include the necessary apparatus to purify the discharge so it will not impair the potable qualities of the water as it is released into the aquifer. Evidence that any disposal well has the potential to induce any contaminant classified in the National Drinking Water Act, including excessive discharge water temperatures, will be prima facie evidence that contamination will take place. No permit will be approved for such well. 
(Code 1995, § 4-5A04) 
Sec. 18-825. - Abandonment; changes to existing wells. 
(a)  Any water well not maintained in good working order and sealed from surface water ingress shall be deemed abandoned. If a water well is abandoned, either by declaration of the owner or as provided in this section, it will be plugged by an approved agency, and all costs of plugging will be charged to the property owner. If such charges are not paid when due, the bill will be certified to the county clerk to be assessed against the property as a special assessment. 
(b)  Any changes or modifications to existing water wells, other than ordinary repairs, shall be done only after the property owner has complied with the requirements of section 18-823. 
(Code 1995, § 4-5A05) 
Secs. 18-826-18-860. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIII. - SIGNS[17] 

Footnotes: 
--- (17) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; sign inspections, § 18-75; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 70; zoning, ch. 94. 

Sec. 18-861. - Permit required. 
(a)  No person shall erect, or cause to be erected, any sign within the limits of the city without first procuring a permit for such sign from the zoning administrator. All such signs constructed or erected shall comply, and be erected in accordance, with the provisions of this article. 
(b)  Before a permit is issued by the zoning administrator, the applicant shall furnish the proposed location, size, nature and method of construction of such sign to the zoning administrator and any other information which he may require in connection therewith. If the sign to be erected conforms with the regulations of this article, the zoning administrator shall, upon payment of a fee as set by resolution of the governing body, issue such permit. All such fees collected by the zoning administrator shall be paid by him to the city clerk each month, with a report showing from whom, and for what purpose, such sums are collected. 
(Code 1995, §§ 4-1001, 4-1002) 
Sec. 18-862. - Notice of completion; final inspection and approval. 
    All signs erected under the provisions of this article shall have the final inspection and approval of the city inspector, upon notice to him of the completion of such sign. Such approval shall be evidenced by a certificate to that effect, signed by the city inspector. Any person failing to promptly notify the city inspector upon the completion of any sign shall be deemed guilty of a violation of this article. 
(Code 1995, § 4-1009) 
Sec. 18-863. - Inspections; unsafe signs. 
(a)  All signs erected shall at all times be subject to the inspection of the city inspector, or whenever any complaint has been made to the city inspector or he deems such inspection necessary. 
(b)  If the inspector shall at any time find any sign insecurely anchored, unsafe in any manner or in such a condition that it, or any support or part thereof, is liable to fall or break, he shall have authority either to order the sign entirely removed or to be repaired or secured in such a manner as he may deem necessary, if, in his opinion, it can be safely repaired or secured. 
(Code 1995, § 4-1010) 
Sec. 18-864. - Abatement and removal of nuisance signs. 
    Any sign erected or maintained contrary to the provisions and requirements of this article, or which may at any time be deemed by the city inspector to be in an unsafe condition shall be deemed and is hereby declared to be a nuisance and may be abated and removed at the cost of the owner thereof in the same manner as now provided for the abatement and removal of other nuisances. 
(Code 1995, § 4-1011) 
Cross reference- Nuisances, ch. 50. 
Sec. 18-865. - Construction. 
(a)  All signs erected within the fire limits of the city shall be either of metal or other noncombustible material, or of wood construction with both faces, or the back and face, wholly covered by metal. 
(b)  Wood signs in use may be reconstructed or reerected, if the backs of signs flat against the building are covered with metal. 
(c)  Temporary cloth signs may be erected and maintained upon special permit secured from the zoning administrator and under such regulations as the zoning administrator may require, but no such temporary cloth sign shall be used for more than 30 days and no permit shall be issued for such sign for a longer period than 30 days. 
(Code 1995, § 4-1003) 
Sec. 18-866. - Projecting or hanging signs. 
    No sign erected or constructed in the city that is attached to, or projects from, any building, structure, post or other fixture, shall project into or hang over or across any street or public thoroughfare, including the part of such street or thoroughfare occupied by any sidewalk or parkway, for a distance of more than seven feet from the perpendicular side of the building, structure, post or other fixture to which any such sign may be attached or affixed, and, in no event, more than seven feet from the property line between the street and the private property upon which any such building, structure, post or other fixture is located. The lowest part of any such sign shall be at least ten feet above any such sidewalk or other portion of the street or public thoroughfare above which such sign is erected, except that flat signs made of one thickness of metal only and having an area on one side of three square feet or less, and the outer edges of which do not extend more than two feet from the building or structure to which they are attached, may have the lowest edge thereof not less than eight feet above any such sidewalk or other portion of the street directly underneath the sign, provided that the city shall have the right at any time to change the requirements or specifications for any such sign or any other sign erected which projects into or hangs over any street, or part thereof, or to order the sign removed at any time, and any permit for the erection, reerection or construction of any such sign may be revoked at any time by the governing body. 
(Code 1995, § 4-1004) 
Sec. 18-867. - Signs flat against the building. 
    All signs erected flat against any building shall be securely anchored to such building or structure in a manner sufficient to support the weight of the sign and the probable wind pressure. The method of anchoring such signs shall, in each case, be approved by the zoning administrator. 
(Code 1995, § 4-1005) 
Sec. 18-868. - Pole signs; signs attached to trees. 
    No sign erected or reerected over or across any street or public thoroughfare, or over or across any sidewalk or parkway in such street or public thoroughfare, except signs having an area of four square feet or less and not extending more than three feet from the building to which such sign is attached, shall be allowed to hang on a pole or rod in such a manner that the sign will swing with the wind, but shall be anchored so that the sign will be rigid and self-supporting, and no such sign shall have less than two side guy wires and one guy wire supporting the sign from the top, except by special permission of the zoning administrator or when he may deem such guy wires unnecessary. No sign which is erected shall be supported by a pole or support paled in or upon any street or public thoroughfare within the city, or in or upon any sidewalk or parkway in such street or public thoroughfare, nor shall any such sign be supported by, or attached to, any tree in or upon any such street or other thoroughfare or any parkway or sidewalk in such street or other thoroughfare. 
(Code 1995, § 4-1006) 
Sec. 18-869. - Hinged brackets required; exception. 
    All signs erected or reerected and that are attached to buildings or structures and extend over a sidewalk, street or public thoroughfare, except signs having an area of four square feet or less and extending not more than three feet from the building, shall be erected with hinged brackets, the center of action of which shall be not more than six inches from the building or other structure to which the sign is attached, so that the sign will swing to the building without falling should the side guy wires or braces become loosened from any cause. The supports for any such sign shall be fastened to the building or structure in a safe and secure manner, sufficient to support the sign and to withstand the probable wind pressure, and shall be subject to the approval of the zoning administrator. 
(Code 1995, § 4-1007) 
Sec. 18-870. - Electrical connections. 
    All electrical wiring in connection with the erection of signs in the city shall be done by a locally licensed electrician. All wiring shall conform to article V of this chapter and shall be covered by a permit, provided that this section shall not apply to the repair and maintenance of neon signs and strip lighting. 
(Code 1995, § 4-1008) 
Cross reference- Electrical code, § 18-171 et seq. 
Sec. 18-871. - Support of flat signs. 
    Flat signs having an area of four square feet or less on one side, which do not extend more than three feet from the building to which they are attached, may be supported by a pole or rod securely fastened to the building in a manner satisfactory to the city inspector and shall be otherwise supported in such a manner as the city inspector may direct. 
(Code 1995, § 4-1012) 
Sec. 18-872. - Commercial billboards and poster boards. 
    Commercial billboards or poster boards shall be constructed with reasonable care for the safety of persons and property and only in such areas as allowed by chapter 94 of this Code. 
(Code 1995, § 4-1013) 
Secs. 18-873-18-900. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIV. - AWNINGS 

Sec. 18-901. - Definitions and classifications. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Awning means a rooflike shelter, carried by a supporting frame or arms attached to a building, and arranged so that the shelter and frame may be folded or rolled up to the face of the building to which it is attached. 
    Marquee means an overhanging, flat, rooflike protection of lightweight, rigid construction, supported from a building without posts, and used for the outside protection of a door, window or other opening. 
    Permanent awning means a sloping or flat, rooflike protection of lightweight rigid construction, supported from a building without posts, and used for the outside protection of a door, window or other opening. 
    Supported canopy means a covering of canvas or other combustible material, rigidly supported by a metal frame attached to a building and suspended over an entrance solely for a shelter or protection. 
    Suspended canopy means a covering of canvas or other combustible material used solely for temporary shelter for a door or walk and carried by a frame supported by the ground or a sidewalk. 
(b)  Other classifications. Any construction erected primarily for shade or protection from the elements and which projects into any public area or is liable to endanger persons using public streets or alleys and which is not mentioned or defined specifically in subsection (a) of this section, or about which there is any question, shall be classified by the city inspector. 
(Code 1995, § 4-901) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 18-902. - Exceptions. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to awnings, marquees or canopies erected before the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived and in accordance with ordinances then in effect, but when recovers, renewals, replacements, repairs or structural changes are made to such awnings, marquees or canopies, they shall be brought into full compliance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1995, § 4-907) 
Sec. 18-903. - Responsibility for maintenance and security. 
    The owner of the building on which any awning, canopy or marquee is installed shall be responsible for the maintenance and security of such awning, canopy or marquee and shall be solely responsible for, and save the city harmless from, any damage caused thereby, either in the process of construction or at any time thereafter. 
(Code 1995, § 4-903) 
Sec. 18-904. - Permit required; fee. 
    No awning, suspended canopy, supported canopy, marquee or permanent awning shall be added to, altered or erected over the streets or alleys of the city until a permit has been secured from the city inspector. The fee for such permit shall be the same as set forth in section 18-71 for a building permit. Such fee shall be paid prior to the issuance of the permit or the erection of the awning, canopy or marquee. Any permit granted to erect awnings, permanent awnings, canopies or marquees, or portions thereof, so as to project into a public street or alley is revocable by the city, when, in the judgment of the governing body, it is for the best interest of the city that such permit be revoked. 
(Code 1995, §§ 4-902, 4-908) 
Sec. 18-905. - Regulations. 
    The following regulations shall apply to all construction and maintenance of awnings, permanent awnings, suspended canopies, supported canopies and marquees: 
(1)  Awnings over public areas in the city shall be arranged without posts, and shall provide clearance of not less than seven feet from a sidewalk to the lowest point of such awning, including any fringe, apron, skirt, valance or drop when the awning is lowered for use. No awning less than 13 feet above the street or sidewalk shall be closer to the vertical plane of the curb than two feet, and in no case shall any awning project from the face of the building more than eight feet. All awnings shall be covered with substantial material; 
(2)  Suspended canopies shall be supported throughout by metal framework. They may extend over public sidewalks or parking portions of a public street, but in no case shall the outer edge of a suspended canopy be closer to the vertical plane of the curb than two feet. In no case shall a suspended canopy be over ten feet in width, measured parallel to the building. The ground area of a suspended canopy shall not exceed 90 square feet. All such suspended canopies shall be securely and rigidly supported and maintained so that no part of the canopy covering, including any fringe, apron, skirt, valance or drop, shall be less than seven feet above the surface of the sidewalk immediately below; 
(3)  Supported canopies shall be adequately supported and braced, and shall be safely maintained and well lighted at night. Supported canopies are hereby prohibited on Main Street between Sutherland Street and Simpson Street; 
(4)  Marquees extending over public property shall have their main framework and support constructed of noncombustible materials, and shall be designed by an architect licensed in the state. The plans for the construction of the marquees shall bear the seal and signature of the licensed architect and shall be submitted to, and approved by, the city inspector. Marquees shall have a clearance of at least eight feet above public property and shall not extend closer to the vertical plan of the curb than two feet. The roofs shall be drained so as not to discharge water upon the sidewalk; 
(5)  Permanent awnings extending over public property shall be of rigid construction of either combustible or noncombustible material, and designed so that the roof portion shall be partly opened to ensure release of air pressure built up under the awning. The structure shall be well braced and securely fastened to the building to which it is attached. The method of construction and attachment shall be approved by the city inspector. No part of any permanent awning shall be closer to the public walkway below than eight feet, nor shall it extend more than eight feet from the face of the building to which it is attached. No permanent awning shall be closer than two feet from the vertical plane of the curb. 
(Code 1995, § 4-904) 
Sec. 18-906. - Interference with fire escapes and public utilities. 
    All structures installed under authority of this article shall be constructed and maintained so as not to interfere with fire escapes or public utilities. 
(Code 1995, § 4-905) 
Sec. 18-907. - Alleys. 
    Portions of any building, structure or utility, or appendage thereto, except signs, shall not project into any alley, except that a curb or buffer block may project nine inches and a maximum of 24 inches in height. 
(Code 1995, § 4-906) 
Secs. 18-908-18-940. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XV. - NUMBERING BUILDINGS[18] 

Footnotes: 
--- (18) --- 
Cross reference- Police department, § 2-161 et seq.; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 70. 

Sec. 18-941. - Required. 
    All business buildings and dwelling houses situated within the corporate limits of the city shall be numbered by the owners or agents thereof in a manner designated in this article. 
(Code 1995, § 4-1101) 
Sec. 18-942. - Numbering system. 
    The initial points of numbering shall be Kansas Avenue and Main Street, going north and south from Kansas Avenue and east and west from Main Street, allowing 100 numbers for each block. The first block shall begin with the number 100 on the righthand side, and the number 101 on the lefthand side; the second block shall begin with the number 200 on the righthand side and the number 201 on the lefthand side; and such numbering shall continue in such manner for all of the remaining blocks to the corporate limits of the city. All short or side streets shall take the nearest parallel corresponding block numbers, allowing no more than 25 feet for each number. 
(Code 1995, § 4-1102) 
Sec. 18-943. - Placement of numbers. 
    The building numbers shall be placed in a conspicuous place upon the front of the building. 
(Code 1995, § 4-1103) 
Sec. 18-944. - Designation of numbers. 
    The city inspector shall designate the number to be placed on each building or proposed building. 
(Code 1995, § 4-1104) 
Secs. 18-945-18-970. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XVI. - MOVING STRUCTURES[19] 

Footnotes: 
--- (19) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3112, § 1, adopted July 29, 2013, deleted Art. XVI, §§ 18-971-18-978, and enacted a new Art. XVI as set out herein. The former Art. XVI pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1995, §§ 4-1401 and 4-1403-4-1409. 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 70. 

Sec. 18-971. - Permit required; application; fee. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to move, haul or transport any house, building or other structure or load of a height of 14 feet or more, or a width of eight and one-half feet or more or a loaded weight in excess of 85,500 pounds or axle loads in excess of 20,000 pounds single axle or 34,000 pounds tandem axles (axle centers less than 40 inches are considered as one axle) ("over size load"), upon or across any street, alley or sidewalk in the city without first obtaining a permit to do so as provided in this section. 
    Any over size load shall also comply with all federal and state rules and regulations. Any over size load traveling upon or across Kansas Ave (US Hwy 56) or South Main St (US Business Hwy 81) shall also obtain a Kansas Department of Transportation (KDOT) Oversize/Overweight Permit. When a KDOT permit is required, such permit must be obtained before applying for a city over size load permit. 
(b)  All applications for permits for an over size load as required in this section shall be made in writing to the director of public works or designee not less than 48 hours before the moving is to commence through the city, subject to the provisions of section 18-973(a) and (c). Such application shall specify the day and hour the move is to commence and the route through the city's streets over which the over size load shall be moved and other details of the over size load as required. The application shall be accompanied by a permit fee as set by resolution of the governing body, which shall be deposited to the credit of the general fund. 
    The permit shall include an authorization (permit) number. The application for the permit shall describe the vehicle (or combination of vehicles), all loads and cargo for which the permit is requested, the route or routes on which the operation is sought, and conditions or restrictions deemed necessary by the city. 
(c)  No permit will be required to authorize the moving or operating of farm tractors, combines, fertilizer dispensing equipment or other farm machinery, machinery for terracing or soil or water conservation work upon farms, or vehicles owned by counties, cities, or other political subdivisions of the state; except, trucks owned by counties, cities and other political subdivision of the state specifically designed equipped, and used exclusively for garbage, refuse or solid waste disposal operations are not exempt from maximum gross weight limitations. Registration of the power unit must be the larger of the combined vehicle weight and load, or the maximum amount of registration available. 
(1)  If the load is for a house, mobile home, or building, the permit shall be designated over size load (house); 
(2)  If the over size load is anything other than a house, mobile home, or building, the permit shall be designated over size load (other). 
(d)  In addition to the cost of the permit fee, the applicant shall prepay an impact fee equal to the costs of extra city services attributable to the over size load, including but not limited to: police escort and traffic control; labor, materials, equipment, and vehicle costs for placing and removal of barricades; adjustment and removal of lighting, signage, traffic signals, and related supporting structures; and, any required engineering work as determined by the public works director or designee. The public works director or designee shall calculate a good faith estimated amount of such impact fee from the information provided and the applicant must deposit the amount of the estimate with the city clerk in immediately available funds. The fees shall be calculated based upon the then current charges and based upon the level of service determined necessary by relevant city staff. If the actual impact fee is less than the estimate, the difference shall be refunded to the applicant within ten business days. If the estimated fees are less than the actual impact fee, the applicant shall pay to the city within ten business days the difference. No permit may be issued unless and until the estimated impact fee has been received by the city. The impact fee is not in lieu of payment for property damage caused by the over size load or a defense to any claim for such damage. 
(Ord. No. 3112, § 1, 7-29-2013) 
State Law reference- Permit to move certain structures over streets having transmission lines and aerial facilities, K.S.A. 17-1914, 17-1915. 
Sec. 18-972. - Liability and insurance. 
(a)  Permit holder assumes all liability for injury to persons or damage to public or private property, including permit holder's own property, or to the object being transported, caused directly or indirectly during the transportation authorized by the permit granted herein. As a condition of accepting the permit, the permit holders agrees to hold the City of McPherson, Kansas harmless from all suits, claims, damages or liabilities of any kind or nature and to indemnify the City of McPherson, Kansas for any claims it may be required to pay related to the over size load. 
(b)  Vehicles and loads traveling under the authority of any permit authorized herein shall have in effect all motor vehicle liability insurance coverage as required by federal, state and local law for the type of vehicle for which the permit is sought. All insurance requirements shall be in force as of the date of the permit application and shall be maintained for the duration of the permit. 
(c)  At a minimum, the permit holder shall also obtain general liability insurance in at least the amount of $500,000.00 and auto liability insurance in the amount of $500,000.00 to cover bodily injury that occurs to any person and property damage liability including but not limited to roadways on which the permitted vehicle or load travels. The insuring company shall be duly authorized to conduct business in the State of Kansas. 
(d)  A properly executed insurance certificate shall be sufficient evidence of insurance coverage as required herein. The city and its board of public utilities shall be named as additional insureds on the certificate which may not be cancelled while the permit is in effect. 
(Ord. No. 3112, § 1, 7-29-2013) 
Sec. 18-973. - Advance notice. 
(a)  After issuance of an over size load (house) permit, the applicant shall give not less than 15 days' written notice to any person owning or operating any wires, cables or other aerial equipment along the proposed route of the intent to move the structure, giving the time and location that the applicant's moving operation shall necessitate the cutting, moving, raising or interfering with any wires, cables or other aerial equipment. 
(b)  The notice provision of subsection (a) of this section shall not apply where the person owning or operating any wires, cables or other aerial equipment has waived their right to advance notice. 
(c)  Should the moving operation be delayed, the applicant shall give the city not less than 24 hours' advance notice of the actual operation. 
[d]  The over size load (other) permit holder shall notify police dispatch one hour before the move commences within city limits. 
(Ord. No. 3112, § 1, 7-29-2013) 
Sec. 18-974. - Removal of interfering poles and wires; responsibility for expense. 
    It shall be the duty of the person owning or operating the poles or wires, after service of the notice as provided in section 18-973, to furnish competent linemen or workmen to remove such poles, or raise or cut such wires, as will be necessary to facilitate the moving of the over size load. The necessary expense which is incurred thereby shall be paid by the holder of the over size load or oversize/overweight permit. 
(Ord. No. 3112, § 1, 7-29-2013) 
Sec. 18-975. - Interference with poles or wires by movers. 
    No person engaged in moving an over size load shall raise, cut or in any way interfere with any poles or wires unless the person or authorities owning or having control of the poles or wires shall refuse to do so after having been notified as provided in section 18-973, and then only competent and experienced workmen shall be employed in such work and, in each case, the necessary and reasonable expense shall be paid by the person moving the over size load under a state and/or city over size load permit. The work shall be done in a careful and workmanlike manner, and the poles and wires shall be promptly replaced and the damages thereto properly repaired. 
(Ord. No. 3112, § 1, 7-29-2013) 
Sec. 18-976. - Progress inspection. 
    It shall be the duty of the public works director or designee from time to time to inspect the progress of an over size load to determine if the load is being moved in accordance with the provisions of this article. The public works director or designee may require the planking of streets and the shoring up of bridges, and may make such other requirements as he deems necessary. The public works director may suspend or revoke any permit if the application was incomplete or misleading or if the over size load is determined to be causing damage to the city streets or creating an unacceptable threat to the health or safety of the citizens. 
(Ord. No. 3112, § 1, 7-29-2013) 
Sec. 18-977. - Display of flares, etc.; pneumatic tires required. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of any person moving any over size load upon or across any street, alley, sidewalk or other public place in the city to mark such over size load in the same manner as required by state law to move upon the state highway system with the load. 
(b)  No over size load shall be moved on or across the streets, alleys or sidewalks of the city, except on trucks and trailers with adequate pneumatic tires. Tire air pressure shall not exceed 100 pounds per square inch. 
(Ord. No. 3112, § 1, 7-29-2013) 
Sec. 18-978. - Trees. 
    No tree, or part thereof, shall be broken, cut or removed for the purpose of or during the transport of any over size load except with the permission and under the direction and supervision of a person duly authorized by the city, and in such a manner and way, and with such treatment of the tree thereafter, as may be required by the city. Any person breaking any tree, or part thereof, as forbidden in this section, or who shall direct or request such breaking, cutting or removal, or who shall be responsible for such breaking, cutting or removal, shall pay the expense incurred by the city in supervising the cutting or treatment of such tree. However, this section shall not be deemed to permit the cutting or trimming of any tree contrary to state law or city ordinance, nor relieve any such person of any liability on account of such cutting, breaking or trimming of trees. 
(Ord. No. 3112, § 1, 7-29-2013) 
Sec 18-979. - Exception for some Kansas Department of Transportation permitted loads. 
(a)  A person who moves, hauls, or transports any house, building, or other structure or load and (1) whose operations are solely confined to Kansas Avenue (U.S. Hwy 56) and South Main Street (U.S. Bus Hwy 81); and (2) has a valid Kansas Department of Transportation ("KDOT") Oversize/Overweight Permit and has provided a true and correct copy to the city; and (3) is and remains in full compliance with the KDOT permit; and (4) the oversize/overweight vehicle and load extends 17 feet or less above the pavement surface; and, (5) whose route does not require a turning movement at the intersection of Kansas Avenue and Main Street shall not be required to obtain an over size load permit from the city; otherwise, a city over size load permit will be required. 
(b)  A city over size load permit is required if a KDOT permitted oversize/overweight vehicle travels on a route within the city other than as stated in subsection 18-979(a)(1) above. 
(c)  A city over size load permit may be required if a KDOT permitted oversize/overweight vehicle and load: (1) extends more than 17 feet above the pavement surface; or (2) the route requires a turning movement at the intersection of Kansas Avenue and Main Street. The KDOT permittee will be required to notify the city of such factors and the city shall review the KDOT permit and inform the KDOT permittee in writing that either a city permit will or will not be required. The director of public works or designee shall review the specific details of such oversize/overweight vehicle and load movement on a case by case basis and if it is determined that movement of the vehicle and load will result in additional costs to the city warranting the assessment of impact fees (as described in section 18-971(d)), then a city over size load permit will be required. 
(Ord. No. 3112, § 1, 7-29-2013) 
Cross reference- Vegetation, ch. 90. 
Secs. 18-980-18-1010. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XVII. - DEMOLITION OF STRUCTURES 

Sec. 18-1011. - Exceptions. 
    The term "house," "building" or "other structure," as used in this article, shall not include miscellaneous accessory buildings, such as garages, sheds, chicken houses, toolsheds or other small structures, and no permit shall be required for the tearing, wrecking or dismantling of such buildings. 
(Code 1995, § 4-1511) 
Sec. 18-1012. - Permit required; application; fee. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the owner of any house, building or structure to wreck or tear down, or cause to be wrecked or torn down, any house, building or structure in any manner whatsoever, or for any person to assist in the wrecking, dismantling or tearing down of any house, building or other structure without first obtaining a permit for such work from the building inspection department. 
(b)  Applications for permits to wreck, tear down or dismantle any structure shall be filed with the building inspection department and shall set forth the description of the structure, its location and the detailed plans of the proposed work. 
(c)  The fee for the permit for the wrecking, tearing down or dismantling of any house, building or other structure shall be the sum as set by resolution of the governing body for each 1,000 square feet, or fraction thereof, of total floor area. The floor area of each story, except basement, using outside dimensions, shall be additive and a separate permit shall be required for each building. The minimum fee for any permit shall be $10.00. 
(Code 1995, §§ 4-1501-4-1503) 
Sec. 18-1013. - Bond. 
    No permit to wreck, dismantle or tear down any house, building or other structure shall be issued or granted until the owner shall have filed with the city clerk a bond in an amount to be fixed by resolution of the governing body. The minimum bond of $10,000.00 shall be filed for the demolition of residence dwelling houses or small buildings. The minimum bond of $20,000.00 shall be filed for the demolition of commercial, industrial, mercantile, church or public buildings. The bond shall be signed by not less than two sureties or by a corporate surety company doing business within the state, which bond shall be approved by the city attorney and the governing body, or until, in the alternative, the owner shall have paid to the city clerk a cash deposit in an amount fixed by resolution of the governing body. The bond or cash deposit shall be for the protection of the city, the public and adjacent lot owners, and shall be to secure the payment of all damages of any kind or nature arising from the operation of wrecking, dismantling or tearing down of the house, building or other structure and to secure the strict compliance of the owner and the person assisting in such operation with the provisions of this article regulating the wrecking, dismantling or tearing down of such house, building or other structure. 
(Code 1995, § 4-1504) 
Cross reference- Finance, § 2-221 et seq. 
Sec. 18-1014. - Insurance requirements. 
    Each person who makes application for a permit to wreck or tear down, or cause to be torn down, any commercial, industrial, mercantile, church or public building shall furnish a certificate of liability insurance with demolition coverage and workmen's compensation insurance covering the work in which he is engaged. The certificate of insurance shall show that the applicant is covered by an effective workmen's compensation and liability insurance policy issued by an insurance company authorized to do business within the state, and shall be issued with minimum limits of $100,000.00 per person and $300,000.00 per occurrence for bodily injury, and $100,000.00 for property damage. The insurance policies shall not be canceled or terminated until at least 20 days after a notice of cancellation of the insurance policy is received by the city clerk. 
(Code 1995, § 4-1505) 
Sec. 18-1015. - Notice to adjacent owners; party walls; roof coverings. 
(a)  When demolishing any structure, the owner or wrecking contractor shall give ten days' notice to the adjacent property owners so that they may protect their property in any way necessary incidental to the wrecking. 
(b)  Where party walls are involved, the wrecker shall fill joist holes, leave the exposed surfaces clean and do such painting as may be necessary to make the walls weathertight. 
(c)  During the wrecking of any building exceeding one story in height and within ten feet of any street or alley property line, and when required by the city inspector, a roof for the entire length of the project shall be provided over the temporary or permanent sidewalk from the time the wrecking starts until it reaches the level of the first story, or until materials are no longer handled above such walkway. 
(Code 1995, § 4-1507) 
Sec. 18-1016. - Demolition operations. 
    Every person who shall wreck, dismantle or tear down any house, building or other structure shall, within 90 days from the date of the permit, unless a shorter time is specified by the permit, clear, or cause to be cleared, from the lot or tract and adjacent streets and alleys, all trash, debris, junk and discarded building materials not to be immediately used in rebuilding. Such person shall remove all foundations, or parts thereof, at least one foot below the ground level, unless another house, building or other structure is to be immediately erected upon such foundations, as specified in the application for the permit. Sewers shall be plugged with concrete three feet from main sewer line, filling all open wells and cisterns, and all cellars, basements or other excavations remaining on such lot or tract, unless they are to be immediately used in connection with other structures to be erected. A substantial fence, not less than three feet, six inches in height, shall be erected around any excavation or cellar which is not immediately filled as provided in this section. 
(Code 1995, § 4-1506) 
Sec. 18-1017. - Disposal area. 
    The person performing the demolition operations as set forth in section 18-1016 shall provide a disposal area for all debris, trash or building materials. 
(Code 1995, § 4-1508) 
Sec. 18-1018. - Public safety. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner or any person assisting in the work of wrecking, dismantling or tearing down of a house, building or other structure, to leave any structure, portion of a structure, building materials or any excavation in such a condition as to constitute a menace to the public health or safety, or to constitute a fire hazard, or which may be, or may become, a nuisance. 
(Code 1995, § 4-1509) 
Sec. 18-1019. - Failure to comply. 
    Upon the failure or neglect of any owner of such house, building or other structure, or of any person assisting in the work of wrecking, dismantling or tearing down of such house, building or other structure to fully comply with the provisions of section 18-1016, the governing body may cause all work to be done that is necessary for compliance with the provisions of section 18-1016, and the bond furnished under the provisions of section 18-1013 shall secure the payment of the expense thereof, or, if a cash deposit has been made, such expense shall be deducted from such cash deposit. All costs incurred in the removal or demolition by the governing body shall be a lien against the real property upon which the cost was incurred, and such costs shall be assessed as a special assessment against the lot or parcel of land on which the house, building or other structure was located. The city clerk shall, at the time of certifying other city taxes, certify the unpaid portion of such costs and the county clerk shall extend the unpaid portion of such costs on the tax rolls of the county against the lot or parcel of land. 
(Code 1995, § 4-1510) 
Secs. 18-1020-18-1050. - Reserved.

ARTICLE XIX. - EROSION AND SEDIMENT CONTROL[20] 
Footnotes: 
--- (20) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2932, § 1, adopted Sept. 24, 2007, supplied provisions to be added to the Code as §§ 86-1101-86-1108. At the discretion of the editor, these provisions have been redesignated as §§ 18-1101-18-1127. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 18-1101. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. 
    Clearing means any activity which removes the vegetative surface cover. 
    Drainage way means any channel that conveys surface runoff from or through a site. 
    Erosion and sediment control plan means a set of erosion and sediment control plans prepared by or under the direction of a licensed professional engineer. 
    Perimeter control means a barrier that prevents sediment from leaving a site either by filtering sediment-laden runoff, or diverting it to a sediment trap or basin. 
    Phasing means clearing a parcel of land in distinct phases, with the stabilization of each phase before the clearing of the next. 
    Sediment control means measures that prevent eroded sediment from leaving the site. 
    Site means a parcel of land, or a contiguous combination thereof, where grading work is performed as a single unified operation. 
    Site development permit means a permit issued by the city for which construction or alteration of the ground allows for improvements and structures to be placed. 
    Site plan means a plan that is governed by zoning regulations and is agreed upon by the city planning commission. One of the required submittals for site plan approval is a drainage plan which may include a site development plan per this article. 
    Stabilization means the use of practices that prevent exposed soil from eroding. 
    Start of construction means the first land-disturbing activity associated with a development, including land preparation such as clearing; grading and filling; installation of streets and sidewalks; excavation for basements, footings, piers, or foundations; erection of temporary forms; and installation of accessory buildings such as garages. 
    Stop work order means an order issued by the public works director or his designee which requires that all construction activity on a site be stopped. 
    Watercourse means any body of water, including but not limited to lakes, ponds, rivers, streams, and bodies of water, whether natural or manmade, which are indicated on the city's storm sewer system map. 
    Waterway means a channel that directs surface runoff to a watercourse or to the public storm sewer system. 
(Ord. No. 2932, § 1(86-1101), 9-24-2007) 
Secs. 18-1102-18-1120. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 18-1121. - Required. 
(a)  No person shall be granted a site development permit for land-disturbing activity which would require the uncovering of greater than or equal to one acre, or is part of a larger common plan of development that would disturb greater than or equal to one acre, without the approval of an erosion and sediment control plan by the public works director. 
(b)  No site development permit is required for the following activities: 
(1)  Any emergency activity which is immediately necessary for the protection of life, property, or natural resources. 
(2)  Existing nursery and agricultural operations conducted as a permitted main or accessory use. 
(3)  It can be demonstrated to the public works director that the proposed development is not likely to impair attainment of the objectives of this article. 
(c)  Each application shall bear the name and address of the owner or developer of the site, and of any consulting firm retained by the applicant together with the name of the applicants principal contact at such firm, and shall be accompanied by a permit fee. 
(d)  Review and approval. 
(1)  The public works department will review each application for a site development permit to determine its conformance with the provisions of this regulation. Within 30 days after receiving an application, the public works director shall, in writing, complete one of the following: 
a.  Approve the permit application; 
b.  Approve the permit application subject to reasonable conditions as may be necessary to secure substantially the objectives of this regulation, and issue the permit subject to these conditions; 
c.  Disapprove the permit application, indicating the deficiencies and the procedure for submitting a revised application. 
(2)  If the permit is in conjunction with a project which requires a site plan approval by the city planning commission, final approval of the site plan will not be given until the site development plan has been approved by the public works director. 
(e)  Duration. Permits issued under this section shall be valid from the date of issuance through the date the city notifies the permit holder that all stormwater management practices have been met. 
(f)  Charges and fees. A permit fee will be assessed based on the amount of land to be disturbed at the site. The fee structure shall be established by resolution of the governing body. 
(g)  Performance and/or security bonds. The city may, at its discretion, require the submittal of a performance and/or security bond prior to issuance of a permit in order to insure that the stormwater practices are installed by the permit holder as required by the approved stormwater management plan. The amount shall be the total estimated construction cost of the stormwater management practices approved under the permit. The bond shall contain forfeiture provisions for failure to complete work specified in the stormwater management plan. 
(Ord. No. 2932, § 1(86-1102), 9-24-2007) 
Sec. 18-1122. - Erosion and sediment control plan. 
(a)  The erosion and sediment control plan shall include: 
(1)  A sequence of construction of the development site, including stripping and clearing, rough grading, construction of utilities and infrastructure, buildings, and final grading and landscaping. The plan shall identify the expected date on which clearing will begin, the estimated duration of exposure of cleared areas, and the sequencing of clearing, installation of temporary erosion and sediment measures, and establishment of permanent vegetation. 
(2)  All erosion and sediment control measures necessary to meet the objectives of this article throughout all phases of construction and permanently after completion of development of the site. Depending upon the complexity of the project, the drafting of intermediate plans may be required at the close of each season. 
(3)  Seeding mixtures and rates, types of sod (if applicable), expected seeding dates, type and rate of initial fertilizer application, and the kind and quantity of mulching for both temporary and permanent vegetative control measures. 
(4)  Provisions for maintenance of control activities, including easements. 
(b)  Modifications to the plan. 
(1)  Amendments of the erosion and sediment control plan shall be submitted to the public works director and shall be processed and approved or disapproved in the same manner as the original plans. 
(2)  Field modifications of a minor nature may be authorized by the public works director by written authorization to the permittee. 
(Ord. No. 2932, § 1(86-1103), 9-24-2007) 
Sec. 18-1123. - Design requirements. 
    Grading, erosion control practices, sediment control practices, and waterway crossings shall meet the design criteria set forth in the most recent version of stormwater management policies and design criteria for the City of McPherson, and shall be adequate to prevent transportation of sediment from the site to the satisfaction of the public works department. 
(a)  Clearing and grading. 
(1)  Clearing and grading of natural resources, such as forests and wetlands, shall not be permitted except when in compliance with all other chapters of this Code. 
(2)  Clearing techniques that retain natural vegetation and retain natural drainage patterns shall be used to the satisfaction of the public works director. 
(3)  Phasing shall be required on all sites greater than 30 acres, with the size of each phase to be established at plan review and as approved by the public works director. 
(4)  Clearing, except that necessary to establish sediment control devices, shall not begin until all sediment control devices have been installed and have been stabilized. 
(b)  Erosion control. 
(1)  Erosion controls shall be those outlined in the most recent version of stormwater management policies and design criteria for the City of McPherson or those that are approved by the governing body. 
(2)  Soil must be stabilized within five days of clearing or inactivity in construction. 
(3)  If vegetative erosion control methods, such as seeding, have not been established within two weeks, the public works director may require that the site be reseeded or that a non-vegetative option be employed. 
(4)  On slopes greater than 3:1 or in drainage ways, special techniques that meet the approval of the public works director shall be used to ensure stabilization. 
(5)  Soil stockpiles must be stabilized or covered at the end of each work day. 
(6)  Techniques shall be employed to prevent the blowing of dust or sediment from the site. 
(7)  Techniques that divert upland runoff past disturbed slopes shall be employed. 
(8)  At the close of the construction season, the entire site must be stabilized using a heavy mulch layer or another method that does not require germination to control erosion. 
(c)  Sediment controls. 
(1)  Sediment controls shall be those outlined in the most recent version of stormwater management policies and design criteria for the City of McPherson or those that are approved by the governing body. 
(2)  Adjacent properties shall be protected by the use of a vegetative buffer strip in combination with perimeter controls. 
(3)  Settling basins, if used, shall be designed in a manner that allows adaptation to provide long term stormwater management. 
(d)  Waterways and watercourses. 
(1)  When a wet watercourse must be crossed regularly during construction, a temporary stream crossing shall be provided and approval must be obtained from the State of Kansas. 
(2)  When in-channel work is conducted, the channel shall be stabilized before, during, and after work. 
(3)  All on-site stormwater conveyance channels shall be designed according to the criteria outlined in the most recent version of stormwater management policies and design criteria for the City of McPherson, or those that are approved by the governing body. 
(4)  Stabilization adequate to prevent erosion must be provided at the outlets of all pipes and paved channels. 
(Ord. No. 2932, § 1(86-1104), 9-24-2007) 
Sec. 18-1124. - Construction site activities. 
(1)  A designated area shall be assigned for containing concrete truck wash-out to prevent runoff. 
(2)  A temporary access road shall be provided at all sites and shall be designed to ensure that sediment is not tracked onto public streets by construction vehicles. Other measures may be required by the public works director in order to ensure that sediment is not tracked onto public streets by construction vehicles or washed into storm drains. 
(3)  Erosion and sediment controls shall be maintained as specified in the most recent version of stormwater management policies and design criteria for the City of McPherson, or as approved by the governing body. 
(Ord. No. 2932, § 1(86-1105), 9-24-2007) 
Sec. 18-1125. - Violations; penalties. 
(a)  Liability. Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall become liable to the city for any expense, loss, or damage occasioned the city by reason of such violation, including such fines, penalties and other costs which may be assessed against the city for violation of the stormwater permit requirements, where such violation was created by a user of the stormwater system who, in turn, is in violation of city, state or federal regulations. 
(b)  Stop work order. A stop work order will be given by the public works director or his designee to any person that is found to have violated an order of the governing body or who has failed to comply with any provision of this article, and the orders, rules, regulations and permits issued under this article. All construction activities will be ceased until the governing body confirms that the development activity is in compliance and the violation has been satisfactorily addressed. 
(c)  Civil penalties. Any person that is found to have violated an order of the governing body or who has failed to comply with any provision of this article, and the orders, rules, regulations and permits issued under this article, shall be fined no more than $1,000.00 for each offense. Each day on which a violation shall occur or continue shall be deemed a separate and distinct offense. In addition to the penalties provided in this subsection, the city may recover reasonable attorney's fees, court costs, court reporter's fees, and other expenses against the person found to have violated this article or the orders, rules, regulations and permits issued under this article. 
(d)  Criminal penalties. Any person that is found to have willfully failed to comply with any provision of this article, and the orders, rules, regulations and permits issued under this article, shall be fined no more than $1,000 for each offense or by imprisonment for not more than six months, or both such fine and imprisonment. Each day on which a violation shall occur or continue shall be deemed a separate and distinct offense. In addition to the penalties provided in this subsection, the city may recover reasonable attorney's fees, court costs, court reporter's fees, and other expenses against the person found to have violated this article or the orders, rules, regulations and permits issued under this article. 
(Ord. No. 2932, § 1(86-1106), 9-24-2007) 
Sec. 18-1126. - Revocation. 
    In the event any person holding a site development permit pursuant to this article violates the terms of the permit, or implements site development in such a manner as to materially adversely affect the health, welfare, or safety of persons in the development, the city may suspend or revoke the site development permit. 
(Ord. No. 2932, § 1(86-1107), 9-24-2007) 
Sec. 18-1127. - Appeal. 
    Any person who is subject to a violation or penalty under the terms of this division, who feels aggrieved and feels that the charge made is unfair, inequitable, unjust, or unreasonable, may appeal the determination of the public works director or his designee to the governing body. The notice of appeal must be received by the city administrator's office within ten days from the date of the notice of violation. Hearing on the appeal before the city commission shall take place within 14 days from the date of the city's receipt of the notice of appeal. The decision of the governing body shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 2932, § 1(86-1108), 9-24-2007) 
Secs. 18-1128-18-1150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XX. - INTERNATIONAL PROPERTY MAINTENANCE CODE

(Ord. No. 2901, § 1, 12-26-2006)

    A certain document, three copies of which are on file in the office of the city clerk, being marked and designated as the American National Standard Accessible and Usable Buildings and Facilities, 2003 edition, as published by the International Code Council and approved by the American National Standards Institute, Inc., be and is hereby adopted as the Accessibility Code of the City of McPherson for the purpose of providing standards that permit persons with a physical disability to independently get to, enter and use a site, facility, building or element; and terms of said Accessibility Code on file in the office of the City Clerk of the City of McPherson are hereby referred to, adopted, and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this article. 
(Ord. No. 3101, § 1, 5-20-2013)

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL

ARTICLE II. - CITY CEMETERIES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3025, §§ 1, 2, adopted Jan. 3, 2011, repealed the former Art. II, §§ 22-31-22-42, and enacted a new Art. II as set out herein. The former Art. II pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1965, §§ 2-217, 13-401, 13-403, 13-404, 13-406, 13-407, 13-501-13-505, 13-507, 13-508; Ord. No. 2838, § 1, adopted Feb. 14, 2005; Ord. No. 3000, §§ 1-5, adopted Jan. 4, 2010; and Ord. No. 3014, §§ 1-4, adopted May 24, 2010. 
State Law reference- City cemeteries, K.S.A. 12-1401 et seq. 

Sec. 22-31. - Applicability. 
    The management and control of the city cemetery and every person using or owning lots in such cemetery shall be subject to the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 3025, § 2, 1-3-2011) 
Sec. 22-32. - Endowment fund. 
(a)  There is hereby created an endowment fund for the city cemetery. 
(b)  All money securities accruing to the endowment fund shall be placed under the control of the city clerk. All money received by the city clerk under the provisions of section 22-34 shall be placed to the credit of the cemetery endowment fund. 
(Ord. No. 3025, § 2, 1-3-2011) 
Sec. 22-33. - Acceptance of private funds. 
(a)  The city is authorized to accept funds from individuals for the upkeep of burial lots in the city cemetery and does hereby elect to come under the provisions of K.S.A. 12-1437-12-1439. 
(b)  All such funds shall be invested by the city in the manner in which the donor of the trust fund shall direct, or, if no direction is given by the donor, in such manner as other cemetery endowment funds are invested. 
(c)  The income from the trust funds shall be used in the manner directed by the donor, or, in the absence of such direction, then for the general upkeep of the city cemetery. 
(Ord. No. 3025, § 2, 1-3-2011) 
Sec. 22-34. - Appropriation of funds. 
(a)  A portion of the funds received from the sale of cemetery lots and mausoleum crypts is hereby appropriated to the endowment fund as follows: 
(1)  Cemetery lots. Twenty-five percent of the price received for the sale of each cemetery lot, or portion thereof; 
(2)  Mausoleum crypts. Fifteen percent of the price received for the sale of each crypt. 
(b)  All lots, or portions thereof, sold before the effective date of the endowment fund and which have not been endowed under any previous ordinance may be endowed by the payment of 25 percent of the cost of such lot, or portion thereof, if such lot, or portion thereof, was then being sold by the city at such time. 
(Ord. No. 3025, § 2, 1-3-2011) 
Sec. 22-35. - Fees and charges. 
    Provisions relating to fees, charges and inspections shall be as follows: 
(1)  The prices of cemetery lots and mausoleum crypts, and other charges connected therewith, shall be determined by the governing body; 
(2)  In cases where sums are deposited with the city clerk for the care of special lots, it shall be the duty of the city clerk to notify the sexton of such deposits, and the sexton shall keep an accurate account of all work done on the special lots and report the work in writing to the city clerk who shall place the report on file. No money received for work on any particular lot shall be used for any purpose other than for the particular lot for which such money was paid; 
(3)  A schedule of fees and charges for the sale of mausoleum crypts, lots or grave spaces in the city cemetery, the opening and closing of graves and the performance of other services in the cemetery by city personnel, and the preparation of certain instruments in connection with the sale and management of grave spaces shall be fixed from time to time by resolution of the governing body and a copy thereof kept permanently on file in the office of the city clerk for distribution to all interested persons at such times and in such manner as the governing body shall provide. 
(Ord. No. 3025, § 2, 1-3-2011) 
Sec. 22-36. - Sale of lots and crypts, and issuance of deeds. 
    Provisions relating to the sale of cemetery lots and crypts, and the issuance of deeds shall be as follows: 
(1)  Before an internment of any body shall be permitted in the city cemetery or mausoleum, it shall be the responsibility of the undertaker or funeral director to furnish a death certificate or burial permit issued by another city or state. It shall also be the undertaker's or funeral director's responsibility to ensure that the charge for the grave, vault or crypt opening, as well as the price of the grave space in case of a single space for adults and infants, is paid to the office of the city clerk. 
(2)  All certificates or deeds for cemetery lots or crypts shall be signed by the commissioner of public facilities and city clerk under the seal of the city and the city clerk shall keep a record of each and every lot, or part thereof, sold. No deed or certificate shall be delivered until the purchase price is paid in full. 
(3)  A cemetery grave space may be exchanged for another available space provided the owner requesting the exchange pays the difference between the amount of the original purchase price of the space being exchanged and the current price of the new space to be acquired. This is in addition to any other costs or fees established by the city commission to exchange spaces. 
(4)  The sexton of the city cemetery shall report crypt sales and entombment charges on the regular report of the sale of cemetery spaces and charges, and report entombments along with the burials on his biweekly report to the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 3025, § 2, 1-3-2011; Ord. No. 3151, § 1, 8-11-2014) 
Sec. 22-37. - Use of lots; interment regulations. 
    Provisions relating to the use of cemetery lots and regulations regarding interments shall be as follows: 
(1)  All lots shall be held as burial places for the dead and no other purpose, and when sold, shall include perpetual care. For the purpose of this subsection, the term "perpetual care" means seeding lots to grass and caring for the grass; 
(2)  No interment of any body, other than a human body, shall be permitted in the city cemetery; 
(3)  No interment shall be made for two or more bodies in one grave, except in the case of parent and infant or two children in one casket, and that two infant interments may be permitted in one grave space. Burial of two containers of ashes in one grave space or one regular burial and a container of ashes in one grave space, shall also be permitted; only one marker or monument is permitted per single space; 
(4)  Graves for adults shall be not less than five feet in depth and not less than four feet in depth for children; however, variations may be permitted in the case of an individual mausoleum; 
(5)  All interments shall be made by the sexton and no burial shall be made until the laws of the state governing burials have been fully complied with; 
(6)  Wherever interments are to be made, due notice shall be given to the sexton and, if the interment is to be made in a private lot, the location of the grave in the private lot shall be specified. No interment of any body, other than that of a relative or immediate heir of any lot owner, shall be made on any lot without the consent of the lot owner, filed in writing in the office of the city clerk; 
(7)  The owner of any lot shall not allow interments to be made in or upon his lot for remuneration, nor shall any transfer or assignment of any interest be valid without securing the registration and endorsement in writing on the back thereof by the city clerk, who shall keep a record of such transfer and shall, by stamp or otherwise, indicate such record of transfer on city records and on the deed; 
(8)  Installation of individual or family size mausoleums of any type construction or materials shall not be permitted. If an individual mausoleum was purchased prior to January 1, 2010 it will be permitted, proof of purchase may be required; 
(9)  In every earth interment, the casket shall be enclosed in a vault or box constructed of concrete or steel. The use of wooden boxes is prohibited; 
(10)  No interment, disinterment, cremation or services shall be permitted on days established by the city commission for observing holidays by city employees. There will be no services scheduled on the Saturday immediately following a city scheduled holiday if said holiday falls on a Friday. The only exception is when a city holiday falls on a Thursday and Friday; 
(11)  No interment, disinterment, cremation or services shall be scheduled to begin later than 4:00 p.m. Monday-Friday, or later than 11:00 a.m. on Saturday; 
(12)  No interment, disinterment, cremation or services shall be permitted on Sunday; 
(13)  A late service fee and a Saturday service fee will be pursuant to a schedule of fees established by resolution of the city commission. Notification of any Saturday service shall be made not later than the preceding Thursday at 12:00 p.m.; 
(14)  All disinterments shall follow the same scheduling guidelines as interment services, but shall not occur on Saturdays; 
(15)  All services (interments/disinterments) shall be scheduled by 12:00 p.m. the previous day except for Saturdays. 
(Ord. No. 3025, § 2, 1-3-2011) 
Sec. 22-38. - Monuments and plantings. 
(a)  Memorial monuments and markers-Old Cemetery. Regulations regarding memorial monuments and markers on lots in the old part of the city cemetery, described as Block A and Sections A through H inclusive of the cemetery, shall be as follows: 
(1)  The owner of any lot shall have the right to erect on such lot any proper marker or monument, the place of which shall be under the supervision of the sexton, and all such markers and monuments shall be subject to the approval of the sexton; 
(2)  Before any memorial work is commenced in McPherson City Cemetery by any employee or employees of a private business or contractor, a monument setting form must be filled out. A 48-hour notice must be given prior to setting any marker or monument; 
(3)  Memorial work shall be conducted only during those hours when cemetery personnel are on duty. No memorial work will be permitted while a funeral service is in progress; 
(4)  No monuments or markers may be set one week before Memorial Day; 
(5)  All worksites shall be properly cleaned upon completion of setting monument. No loose concrete will be left on the ground, scrap lumber, and dirt piles will be removed, tracks filled in etc; 
(6)  Only one marker shall be permitted on one grave space; 
(7)  All monuments and markers, placed after January 1, 2011, shall be marble, granite, or bronze; 
(8)  The base of all monuments shall be cut so as to rest squarely on the ground and a four-inch flange shall be installed on the base or foundation of all gravestones, monuments and markers. All foundations or bases, placed after January 1, 2011, must be lengthened to include vases, if permanent vases or concrete pots are to be used: 
a.  All monuments set in a single space in Blocks 1-46 shall have a concrete foundation not to exceed 44 by 24 inches. All monuments set in a double space must have a foundation not to exceed 88 by 24 inches; 
b.  All monuments set in a single space in Sections A-I shall have a concrete foundation not to exceed 54 by 24 inches. All monuments set in a double space must have a foundation not to exceed 108 by 24 inches; 
(9)  All foundations or bases are to be poured or precast and set in sand by the monument dealer, and work shall be executed without unnecessary delay, under the supervision of the sexton, who shall charge an inspection fee as set by resolution of the governing body. The inspection fee shall also apply to individual mausoleums with inscriptions (see section 22-35); 
(10)  All foundations must be supported by a 36 by six-inch pillar of wet concrete per 22 inches of foundation; 
(11)  All foundation work (including installation) will be done the same day the monument is delivered; 
(12)  All markers must be attached to concrete with pins and sealed to the foundation; 
(13)  All monuments must be centered on the center of a cemetery space (man and wife) unless found to be impractical, whereupon, the location must be approved by the sexton; 
(14)  No monument exceeding 32 inches in height shall be permitted; 
(15)  All marker stones for infant graves in baby land, placed after January 1, 2011, shall be of a uniform size of eight inches by 16 inches; 
(16)  All monuments or markers in the cemetery shall be subject to inspection and approved by the sexton, and any work which does not meet his approval shall be rejected and caused to be rebuilt; 
(17)  Extension to an existing concrete base for the purpose of providing holders for flower vases must be pre-approved by the sexton; 
(18)  The boundaries of any lot in the old cemetery only may not be marked by concrete, stone or other corner posts. All pre-existing corner or lot posts that deteriorate will be removed as necessary; 
(19)  Temporary markers that are provided by funeral homes will be allowed for one year from the date of interment, at which time the sexton will remove and discard the markers; 
(20)  If it is necessary to move and reset a stone to accommodate an individual burial on a grave, the individual requesting that said burial shall be responsible therefore; and pay the cost thereof in advance for such service or agree in writing to be financially responsible for such service in advance; 
(21)  All independent contractors, their agents, and employees performing work in the cemetery are required to dress in presentable working attire which consists of shirt, pants or shorts, and shoes all free of significant wear; 
(22)  In order to insure the setting of monuments and markers in a workmanlike manner and in keeping with good appearance of the cemetery as a whole, the governing body may adopt additional policies consistent with law deemed necessary and proper for the location and setting of monuments and markers. 
(b)  Memorial monuments and markers-New Cemetery. Regulations regarding memorial monuments and markers on lots in the new part of the city cemetery, described as Blocks B through J inclusive and all future areas of the cemetery, shall be as follows: 
(1)  The owner of any lot shall have the right to erect on such lot any proper marker or monument, the place of which shall be under the supervision of the sexton, and all such markers and monuments shall be subject to the approval of the sexton; 
(2)  Before any memorial work is commenced in McPherson City Cemetery by any employee or employees of a private business or contractor, a monument setting form must be filled out. A 48-hour notice must be given prior to setting any marker or monument; 
(3)  Memorial work shall be conducted only during those hours when cemetery personnel are on duty. No memorial work will be permitted while a funeral service is in progress; 
(4)  No monuments or markers may be set one week before Memorial Day; 
(5)  All worksites shall be properly cleaned upon completion of setting monument. No loose concrete will be left on the ground, scrap lumber, and dirt piles will be removed, tracks filled in etc; 
(6)  Only one marker shall be permitted on one grave space; 
(7)  All monuments and markers, placed after January 1, 2011, shall be marble, granite, or bronze; 
(8)  All monuments set in a single space in Blocks B-I shall have a base not to exceed 48 by 16 inches. Any marker set on the concrete memorial islands may not exceed any concrete ledge, or past the grave space on either the north or south side. An exception applies only in the case that here is a double marker and it will be centered between two spaces not to exceed any concrete edge; 
(9)  All monuments or markers in the new cemetery shall be placed on the concrete memorial island as provided by the city; 
(10)  All foundation work (including installation) will be done the same day the monument is delivered; 
(11)  All markers must be attached to concrete with pins and sealed to the foundation; 
(12)  All monuments must be centered on the center of a cemetery space (e.g. man and wife) unless found to be impractical, whereupon, the location must be approved by the sexton; 
(13)  No monument exceeding 32 inches in height shall be permitted; 
(14)  All monuments or markers in the cemetery shall be subject to inspection and approved by the sexton, and any work which does not meet his approval shall be rejected and caused to be rebuilt; 
(15)  Temporary markers that are provided by funeral homes will be allowed for one year from the date of interment, at which time the sexton will remove and discard the markers; 
(16)  If it is necessary to move and reset a stone to accommodate an individual burial on a grave, the individual requesting that said burial shall be responsible therefore; and pay the cost thereof in advance for such service or agree in writing to be financially responsible for such service in advance; 
(17)  All independent contractors, their agents, and employees performing work in the cemetery are required to dress in presentable working attire which consists of shirt, pants or shorts, and shoes all free of significant wear; 
(18)  In order to insure the setting of monuments and markers in a workmanlike manner and in keeping with good appearance of the cemetery as a whole, the governing body may adopt additional policies consistent with law deemed necessary and proper for the location and setting of monuments and markers. 
(c)  Plantings and decorations-Old Cemetery. 
(1)  The city does not assume liability for any items placed on graves. The city shall not be held liable for any disposed item or return of any temporary or permanent decorations or trees that were installed without written approval. Plantings may be removed without notice by cemetery staff when they become unsightly, undesirable, or interfere with cemetery maintenance. Any items removed will not be replaced and removed without notice; 
(2)  Flowers and other items placed on a grave on Memorial Day, holidays and special family dates will be removed and discarded by the sexton one week later, and on March 1 for flowers and other items placed on a grave on Christmas Day and New Year's Day; 
(3)  The owner or proprietor of any lot shall have the right to cultivate only such shrubbery, flowers or other vegetation as is approved by the sexton; 
(4)  Enclosures and curbing around burial lots and grave guards are prohibited, including wire and other types of guards or enclosures placed around shrubbery and flowers. Fences and hedges around lots or graves are also prohibited; 
(5)  Placement of cut flowers or artificial flowers, excavations for planting of seasonal flowers, perennial flowers, or shrubs, with the prior approval of cemetery staff, shall be confined to the area within six inches of the north and south ends of the foundation of the marker; 
(6)  Flowers and other items placed on a grave during a funeral will be removed and discarded by the sexton one week after the funeral; 
(7)  The concrete foundation around the marker on the west and east side of the marker is a mowing flange and should not be used for decoration purposes. All items left on the mowing flange will be removed and disposed of. An allowance will be made for items drilled into concrete flange if approved prior to drilling by the sexton;
