(8)  All items that interfere or make mowing or string trimming dangerous will be removed and discarded at the discretion of the sexton. Such items not allowed include but are not limited to: 
a.  The placing of boxes, shells (ammunition), toys, metal design, and ornaments; 
b.  Glass, wood, or iron cases and similar; 
c.  Marble chips, wood chips, rock of any kind on any grave or lot; 
d.  Objects made of wood, tin, glass, porcelain and clay; 
e.  Any borders of any kind, including wood, stone, rock, brick, and fences; 
f.  Alcoholic or non-alcoholic beverage containers meant as decorations; 
g.  No shepherd hooks will be allowed without prior approval. No approval shall be given for more than one shepherd hook per occupied space. Cemetery personnel may relocate or remove shepherd hooks when deemed necessary; 
(9)  Banners or balloons made of any material will only be allowed for one week for holidays and special family dates; 
(10)  Placement of two solar lights per marker is permissible. They may be placed on the north or south ends of markers as close to the concrete foundation as possible. The city accepts no liability for maintenance or damage to said lights; 
(11)  Artificial flowers, wreaths and cut flowers shall be placed and secured in a manner that they will not become dislodged or scattered by the wind. No holes may be dug in or around a grave to support flower vases or any other placement structures; 
(12)  Damaged or faded artificial flowers or wreaths, and neglected or dead flowers and plants may be removed by the cemetery staff as necessary to maintain the attractive and neat appearance of the cemetery; 
(13)  Trees will only be allowed to be planted in a location authorized by the sexton or cemetery staff, and the species of such trees shall be in accordance with the needs of the cemetery; 
(14)  No concrete pots or vases are allowed unless they sit entirely on the concrete foundation on the north or south side of the marker with a four-inch mowing flange. Any existing pots or vases in place as of January 1, 2011, will be permitted until such existing pots or vases become unusable. A pot or vase will be deemed unusable at the discretion of the cemetery staff after consultation with the cemetery advisory board. Unusable pots and vases will be discarded without notice; 
(15)  No benches are allowed on private spaces except when used in lieu of a traditional stone or marker. Preexisting benches will be allowed to remain until they reach a state of disrepair or the spaces or spaces on which the bench sets become occupied at which time the bench will be removed by cemetery personnel. Individuals may purchase a memorial bench, meeting specifications determined by the city sexton, to be placed in predetermined public locations in the cemetery with prices determined from time to time by resolution of the governing body; 
(16)  If, in the opinion of the sexton, a veteran's marker should be secured to the concrete by drilling, the sexton may require such drilling and cemetery staff will drill the concrete and place the item with liability for any damage done. 
(d)  Plantings and decorations-New Cemetery. 
(1)  The city does not assume liability for any items placed on graves. The city shall not be held liable for any disposed item or return of any temporary or permanent decorations or trees that were installed without written approval. Plantings may be removed without notice by cemetery staff when they become unsightly, undesirable, or interfere with cemetery maintenance. Any items removed will not be replaced and removed without notice; 
(2)  Flowers and other items placed on a grave on Memorial Day, holidays and special family dates will be removed and discarded by the sexton one week later, and on March 1 for flowers and other items placed on a grave on Christmas Day and New Year's Day; 
(3)  Since the city retains ownership of the center mulched area of the memorial islands only two personal items will be allowed per occupied space. Veteran's marker will not count as one of the items. Items must remain as close to the concrete apron as possible. All items must be fastened or secured to prevent movement from the designated space. Placement of all items needs approval of the sexton. Examples include but are not limited to: 
a.  Shepherd hooks 
b.  Artificial flowers 
c.  Solar lights; 1 Light = 1 Item 
d.  Other items with approval of sexton 
(4)  All other personal items must be confined and secured to the concrete apron of the space or spaces owned; 
(5)  Flowers and other items placed on a grave during a funeral will be removed and discarded by the sexton one week after the funeral; 
(6)  All items that interfere or make mowing or string trimming dangerous will be removed and discarded at the discretion of the sexton. All items must be fastened or secured to prevent movement from the designated space. Such items not allowed include but are not limited to: 
a.  The placing of boxes or shells (ammunition); 
b.  Glass, wood, or iron cases and similar; 
c.  Marble chips, wood chips, rock of any kind on any grave or lot; 
d.  Objects made of glass; 
e.  Any borders of any kind, including wood, stone, rock, brick, and fences; 
f.  Alcoholic or non-alcoholic beverage containers meant as decorations; 
(7)  Banners or Balloons made of any material will only be allowed for one week for holidays and special family dates; 
(8)  Damaged or faded artificial flowers or wreaths, and neglected or dead flowers and plants may be removed by the cemetery staff as necessary to maintain the attractive and neat appearance of the cemetery; 
(9)  Trees will only be allowed to be planted in a location authorized by the sexton or cemetery staff, and the species of such trees shall be in accordance with the needs of the cemetery; 
(10)  No concrete pots or vases are allowed unless they sit entirely on the concrete foundation on the north or south side of the marker. Any existing pots or vases in place as of January 1, 2011, will be permitted until such existing pots or vases become unusable. A pot or vase will be deemed unusable at the discretion of the cemetery staff after consultation with the cemetery advisory board. Unusable pots and vases will be discarded without notice; 
(11)  No benches are allowed on private spaces except when used in lieu of a traditional stone or marker. Preexisting benches will be allowed to remain until they reach a state of disrepair or the spaces or spaces on which the bench sets become occupied at which time the bench will be removed by cemetery personnel. Individuals may purchase a memorial bench, meeting specifications determined by the city sexton, to be placed in predetermined public locations in the cemetery with prices determined from time to time by resolution of the governing body; 
(12)  If, in the opinion of the sexton, a veteran's marker should be secured to the concrete by drilling, the sexton may require such drilling and cemetery staff will drill the concrete and place the item with liability for any damage done. 
(Ord. No. 3025, § 2, 1-3-2011) 
Sec. 22-39. - Mausoleum. 
    The governing body shall, from time to time, by resolution, adopt reasonable regulations for the operation and maintenance of the mausoleum. A copy of the regulations shall be kept permanently on file with the city clerk, and the city clerk shall make a reasonable effort to supply each key holder with such regulations as originally adopted and as amended. The sexton has responsibility for the mausoleum and columbariums; 
(Ord. No. 3025, § 2, 1-3-2011) 
Sec. 22-40. - Hours; cleanliness; vandalism. 
    Provisions relating to rules of cemetery hours, cleanliness and vandalism shall be as follows: 
(1)  No interments shall be made in the cemetery or mausoleum on Sundays or holidays, nor shall any cemetery burial service commence after 4:00 p.m.; 
(2)  The hours of admission to the cemetery shall be from 7:00 a.m. until sundown, and any person entering the grounds at any other time, except for a legitimate purpose, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor; 
(3)  All persons are hereby prohibited from touching any article in the cemetery that is not their own, or picking any flowers, shrubbery, plants or other vegetation, or injuring anything on the cemetery grounds; 
(4)  No one other than cemetery staff shall be allowed to spray any chemical agent including fertilizer, weed killers, herbicides, and ground sterilants; 
(5)  All vehicles must be kept off the grass. No unauthorized vehicle shall be permitted to drive at any place within the cemetery except on roads. Driving on walkways, grass, alleys, or in vacant spaces is prohibited. Notwithstanding the above, vehicles may be parked on the grass within six feet of either side of the road; 
(6)  It shall be unlawful for any person to throw, or cause to be thrown, any paper, grass, rubbish or other material in or upon the cemetery grounds, except in any places specifically provided for such purpose; 
(7)  No vehicle shall be driven more than 15 miles per hour in the cemetery; 
(8)  The governing body shall have the right to: 
a.  Close any walkway, street or driveway existing in the cemetery, provided, sufficient access is left to all lots; 
b.  Establish grades; and 
c.  Make any additional rules and regulations for the government and operation of the cemetery that are not inconsistent with this article. 
(Ord. No. 3025, § 2, 1-3-2011) 
Sec. 22-41. - Dogs. 
    No person having the care, custody or control of a dog, other than a blind person accompanied by his Seeing-eye dog, shall take or permit such dog to go onto the grounds of the city cemetery. This section shall not apply to: 
(1)  A dog confined to an automobile while in the cemetery. 
(2)  Guide dogs used by totally or partially blind persons or other disabled persons and guide dog trainers when training such dogs, and hearing ear dogs used by hearing impaired persons and hearing ear trainers when training such dogs. 
(3)  Service dogs and service dog trainers while training such dogs. 
(Ord. No. 3025, § 2, 1-3-2011) 
Sec. 22-42. - Cremation garden. 
    The Cremation Garden area of the McPherson City Cemetery shall be used to place cremains in the common depository in the Cremation Garden. A memorial plaque may be purchased and caused to be placed on monument in the Cremation Garden, pursuant to a schedule of fees established by resolution of the city commission from time to time. 
    Veterans' memorial plaques cannot exceed 5.5 by 8.5 inches, and civilian plaques may not exceed two by five inches; 
(Ord. No. 3025, § 2, 1-3-2011) 
Sec. 22-43. - Violations; penalties. 
(a)  Liability. Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall become liable to the city for any expense, loss, or damage occasioned the city by reason of such violation. 
(b)  Stop work order. A stop work order will be given by the sexton or his designee to any person or firm that is found to have violated an order of the governing body or who has failed to comply with any provision of this article. All work will be ceased until the sexton confirms that the activity is in compliance and the violation has been satisfactorily addressed. 
(c)  Civil penalties. Any person that is found to have violated an order of the governing body or who has failed to comply with any provision of this article shall be fined no more than $500.00 for each offense. Each day on which a violation shall occur or continue shall be deemed a separate and distinct offense. In addition to the penalties provided in this subsection, the city may recover reasonable attorney's fees, court costs, court reporter's fees, and other expenses against the person found to have violated this article or the orders, rules, regulations and permits issued under this article. 
(d)  Criminal penalties. Any person that is found to have willfully failed to comply with any provision of this article shall be fined no more than $500.00 for each offense or by imprisonment for not more than six months, or both such fine and imprisonment. Each day on which a violation shall occur or continue shall be deemed a separate and distinct offense. In addition to the penalties provided in this subsection, the city may recover reasonable attorney's fees, court costs, court reporter's fees, and other expenses against the person found to have violated this article. 
(Ord. No. 3025, § 2, 1-3-2011) 
Sec. 22-44. - Appeal. 
    Any person who is subject to a violation or penalty under the terms of this article, who feels aggrieved and feels that the charge made is unfair, inequitable, unjust, or unreasonable, may appeal the determination of the sexton or his designee to the governing body. The notice of appeal must be received by the city administrator's office within ten days from the date of the notice of violation. Hearing on the appeal before the city commission shall take place within 14 days from the date of the city's receipt of the notice of appeal. The decision of the governing body shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 3025, § 2, 1-3-2011) 
Sec. 22-45. - Cemetery advisory board. 
    To the extent reasonably practical, changes to cemetery regulations, rules or policy shall first be submitted to the cemetery advisory board for comment. 
(Ord. No. 3025, § 2, 1-3-2011) 
Sec. 22-46. - Disinterment requests and procedures. 
(a)  Requests for disinterment of an individual interred or inurned at the McPherson Cemetery must be submitted in writing to the city on authorized forms, pursuant to this section. 
(b)  Disinterment will only be approved if: 
(1)  All living heirs at law of the decedent and the person who initiated the interment, if living (whether or not an heir at law), give their written consent; or 
(2)  Pursuant to a court order of competent jurisdiction directing the disinterment. 
" Heirs at law " are defined as surviving spouse, even if remarried, all children of the decedent and the issue of any predeceased children of the decedent. In the event any individual required to consent herein is a minor or not legally competent, the legal guardian, agent under an appropriate durable power of attorney or court appointed representative shall be required to consent in writing. In the absence of a surviving spouse or children, the decedent's living parents will be considered "heirs at law." 
(c)  All disinterments will be without expense to the city and all fees for a disinterment charged by the city are due before a disinterment will be scheduled. Fees will be set from time to time by resolution of the governing body. A request must include the following requirements: 
(1)  A description of the disinterment including relocation plans for the remains. 
(2)  A notarized statement from all heirs at law and the person who initiated the interment, if living, affirmatively stating no objection to the proposed disinterment and relocation plan. If the statement is signed by an authorized representative of a minor or legally incompetent party, acceptable documents must be provided demonstrating the agency (e.g. copy of power of attorney, letters of guardian/conservatorship, etc.). 
(3)  An affidavit of heirship attesting that those persons who provided statements are indeed the only living heirs at law of the interred decedent. 
(4)  In lieu of the documents required listed above, an order of a court of competent jurisdiction will be accepted. The City of McPherson or officials of the cemetery should not be made a party to the court action. 
(d)  No disinterment shall be performed in the cemetery except by the Cemetery Sexton, or under the Sexton's supervision. Cemetery staff shall only be responsible for removing the soil from the grave. A Kansas licensed funeral director ("director") must be present throughout the disinterment and work will not begin without a director present and shall cease if the director leaves. The selected director shall be responsible for removing and transporting the casket/vault/urn and all remains from the burial site. In the case of traditional casket burial, a vault company shall also be present with an additional vault should the original vault be damaged for reburial in the cemetery. No damaged or structurally unsound vaults will be reinterred in the cemetery. In the case of an urn, a vault company is not required; however, an additional intact vessel shall be present should the original vessel be damaged for reburial in the cemetery. As a condition of approval, all parties must agree that the city shall not be liable for any damages incurred during the removal or placement of the disinterred vault. 
(e)  No disinterment shall be performed two weeks before Memorial Day, nor shall any be performed on Saturdays, Sundays, or any city observed holidays. The city must be notified at least one week before the disinterment and all disinterment fees due to the city must be paid prior to scheduling the opening. The Cemetery Sexton reserves the right to postpone and reschedule any disinterment due to weather on any other unforeseeable events. 
(Ord. No. 3268, § 1, 4-9-2018) 
Chapter 26 - ELECTIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; governing body, § 2-31 et seq. 
State Law reference- Elections generally, K.S.A. 25-101 et seq.; city elections, K.S.A. 25-2101 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 26-1. - City government. 
(a)  Governing body. The governing body consists of a mayor, a commissioner of public facilities and a commissioner of public works. The mayor and commissioners shall be residents and qualified electors of the city. Every four years an election shall be held for a mayor and two commissioners with staggered terms as provided below. The mayor and commissioners shall hold offices for four years and until their successors are elected and qualified. 
(b)  General elections. Beginning in 2017, on the Tuesday succeeding the first Monday in November of each year an election shall be held for the officers of the city as provided by K.S.A. 25-2107 and this Code. The current term of the mayor shall now expire on the second Monday in January of 2018, when the person elected in the November 2017 general election take office. The current terms of the commissioners of public facilities and public works shall now expire on the second Monday in January of 2020, when the persons elected in the November 2019 general election take office. All elections for the city shall be nonpartisan. 
(Ord. No. 3230, § 1, 11-14-2016) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3230, § 1, adopted Nov. 14, 2016, repealed the former § 26-1 and enacted a new § 26-1 as set out herein. The former § 26-1 pertained to city elections and derived from Code 1995, § 5-101. 
Sec. 26-2. - Voting hours. 
    The hours of voting at all elections in the city shall be as provided by K.S.A. 25-2111. 
(Code 1995, § 5-102) 
Sec. 26-3. - Nomination petition requirements. 
    In accordance with K.S.A. 25-205 and amendments thereto, any person may become a candidate for city office elected at large by having had filed on their behalf, a nomination petition or a declaration of candidacy, accompanied by any fee required by law. The nomination petition must be signed by 25 of the qualified electors of the city. 
(Ord. No. 3230, § 1, 11-14-2016) 
Secs. 26-4-26-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - WARDS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Wards, K.S.A. 14-1103; precincts, K.S.A. 25-26a02 et seq. 

Sec. 26-31. - Division. 
    The city is hereby divided into four wards designated as the first, second, third and fourth wards, respectively. 
(Code 1995, § 5-201) 
Sec. 26-32. - Ward number one. 
(a)  Ward number one shall be comprised of all of that part of the city lying north of Kansas Avenue and east of Main Street. 
(b)  All of that part of ward number one lying north and west of the center of West Lakeside Drive, as extended, along the southern boundary of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad right-of-way to the center of First Street, as extended, and thence east on the centerline of First Street, as extended, and also lying south of the center of First Street shall constitute a precinct and shall be known as the first precinct of the first ward. 
(c)  All of that part of ward number one lying south and east of the center of West Lakeside Drive, as extended, along the southern boundary of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad right-of-way to First Street, and thence east on the center of First Street shall constitute a precinct and shall be known as the second precinct of the first ward. 
(d)  All of that part of the city lying north of First Street and south of a line beginning at the intersection of Hulse Street and Main Street, running east along the centerline of Hulse Street to the intersection of Hulse Street and North High Drive, north along the centerline of North High Drive to its intersection with Countryside Drive, east along the centerline of Countryside Drive to the 116th section line subdividing the northeast one-fourth of section 21-19s-3W, thence south along such 116th section line to the north line of the southeast one-fourth of section 21, thence east along the north line to the east city limits shall constitute a precinct and shall be known as the third precinct of the first ward. 
(e)  All that part of the city lying east of Main Street and north of such line shall constitute a precinct and shall be known as the fourth precinct of the first ward. 
(Code 1995, § 5-202) 
Sec. 26-33. - Ward number two. 
    Ward number two shall be comprised of all of that part of the city north of Kansas Avenue and west of Main Street. 
(Code 1995, § 5-203) 
Sec. 26-34. - Ward number three. 
    Ward number three shall be comprised of all of that portion of the city south of Kansas Avenue and west of Main Street. 
(Code 1995, § 5-204) 
Sec. 26-35. - Ward number four. 
(a)  Ward number four shall be comprised of all of that part of the city lying south of Kansas Avenue and east of Main Street. 
(b)  All of that part of ward number four lying west of the center of Grand Avenue and Grand Avenue extended south to East Avenue A, or south of the center of Avenue A shall constitute a precinct and shall be known as the first precinct of the fourth ward. 
(c)  All of that part of ward number four lying east of the center of Grand Avenue and Grand Avenue extended south to east Avenue A and north of the center of Avenue A extended shall constitute a precinct and shall be known as the second precinct of the fourth ward. 
(Code 1995, § 5-205) 
Chapter 30 - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; police department, § 2-161 et seq.; fire prevention and protection, ch. 34; licenses, permits and miscellaneous business regulations, ch. 38; water shortages, § 86-51 et seq. 
State Law reference- Emergency preparedness for disasters, K.S.A. 48-904 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 30-1. - Emergency powers of mayor. 
    Whenever a state of disaster emergency has been proclaimed under K.S.A. 48-924 or during a state of local disaster emergency has been proclaimed under K.S.A. 48-932, the mayor or commissioner acting for the mayor shall have the power to do the following: 
(1)  Declaration of curfew hours. Declare hours of curfew for all persons, and during the hours of curfew, all persons shall be at their homes and shall not be on the streets, alleys or other public areas of the city. The curfew shall be declared in a proclamation of the mayor, which proclamation shall be delivered to the chief of police, who shall then ensure that the proclamation is delivered to all news media within the city, and shall also use public address systems throughout the city and immediately notify the public of the proclamation and curfew, and warn the public that any violation of the curfew shall be deemed a violation of this Code and violators will be arrested. 
(2)  Closing of certain businesses. Declare all or any business establishments to be closed and remain closed until further order. Any person violating any provision of this subsection, after notice, and refusing to close and remain closed shall be deemed guilty of a violation of this Code. The mayor shall issue a proclamation which shall be delivered to the chief of police, who shall inform the businesses of the proclamation. 
(Code 1995, § 12-238) 
Cross reference- Officers and employees, § 2-61 et seq. 
Sec. 30-2. - Authority to close public ways. 
    The chief of police shall have authority to temporarily close any and all streets, alleys and other public ways in the city to the public whenever, in the opinion of the chief of police, it is necessary in order to maintain the peace of the community. 
(Code 1995, § 12-239) 
Sec. 30-3. - Authority to close city parks, drainage ways and other public spaces. 
    The chief of police, or designee, shall have the power to temporarily close any and all parks, drainage ways and other public spaces or parts thereof in the city to the public whenever, in the opinion of the chief of police, or designee, it is necessary in order to safeguard the citizens from an emergent situation or to free up city resources to deal with an emergent situation. For purposes of this section, an emergent situation may be a natural or manmade event regardless of whether an official disaster has been declared. The governing body may over-ride or modify any such decision by majority vote at a regular or special meeting. Such order shall not extend more than 72 hours without being renewed by the chief of police or designee. The chief of police is hereby authorized to post appropriate signage in the event of any such closure. Any person entering or remaining on land so posted may be charged with misdemeanor criminal trespass. 
(Ord. No. 3116, § 1, 8-19-2013) 
Secs. 30-4-30-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - EMERGENCY INTERIM SUCCESSORS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to enact ordinances providing for emergency interim successors, K.S.A. 48-1206. 

Sec. 30-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Attack means any action or series of actions taken by an enemy of the United States resulting in substantial damage or injury to persons or property in the state, whether through sabotage, bombs, missiles, shellfire or atomic, radiological, chemical, bacteriological or biological means, or other weapons or methods. 
    Emergency means a situation caused by the death of all members of the governing body at the same time, where death occurs prior to the appointment by any member of the governing body of the interim successors in office. 
    Emergency interim successor means a person designated pursuant to this article, if the officer is unavailable, to exercise the powers and discharge the duties of an office until a successor is appointed or elected and qualified as may be provided by the constitution and statutes of the state or by Charter ordinances and other ordinances of the city, or until the lawful incumbent is able to resume the exercise of the powers and discharge the duties of the office. 
    Event of a catastrophe or emergency means a catastrophe or emergency in which all, or a majority, of the members of the governing body are fatally injured. In such event, the interim governing body shall then be composed of such officers as are set out in section 30-34(1). 
    Office includes all city offices, the powers and duties of which are defined by the constitution and statutes of the state or by Charter ordinances and other ordinances of the city. 
    Unavailable means either that a vacancy in office exists and there is no deputy authorized to exercise all of the powers and discharge the duties of the office, or that the lawful incumbent of the office, including any deputy exercising the powers and discharging the duties of an office because of a vacancy, and his duly authorized deputy are absent or unable to exercise the powers and discharge the duties of the office. 
(Code 1995, § 1-301) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 30-32. - Emergency temporary locations of government. 
    Whenever, due to an emergency, it becomes imprudent, inexpedient or impossible to conduct the affairs of the city at the usual place thereof, the governing body may meet at any place, within or without the territorial limits of the city, upon the call of the presiding officer or any two members of the governing body, and shall proceed to establish, by ordinance, resolution or other manner, alternate or substitute sites or places as the emergency temporary location of government where all or any part of the public business may be transacted and conducted during the emergency situation. Such site or place may be within or without the territorial limits of the city and within the state. 
(Code 1995, § 1-302) 
Cross reference- Governing body, § 2-31 et seq. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 48-1401. 
Sec. 30-33. - Powers and functions of governing body and officers at emergency temporary location. 
    During the period when the public business is being conducted at the emergency temporary location, the governing body and other officers of the city shall have, possess and exercise at such location all of the executive, legislative and judicial powers and functions conferred upon the governing body and officers by and under the laws of the state. Such powers and functions may be exercised in the light of the exigencies of the emergency situation, without regard to, or compliance with, time consuming procedures and formalities prescribed by law and pertaining thereto, and all acts of the governing body and officers shall be as valid and binding as if performed within the territorial limits of the city. 
(Code 1995, § 1-303) 
Cross reference- Governing body, § 2-31 et seq. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 48-1402. 
Sec. 30-34. - Emergency interim successors. 
    Emergency interim successors for city offices shall be as follows: 
(1)  If any member of the governing body shall be unavailable following an attack, then the remaining members of the governing body shall designate an emergency interim successor for each member of the governing body who is unavailable. If all members of the governing body are unavailable following an attack or in the event of an emergency as defined in section 30-31, an acting governing body is hereby designated to be composed of the city clerk, city attorney and chief of police. Such officers shall exercise the powers and discharge the duties of the governing body until such time as a special election is held to fill the vacancies. The city clerk shall be the acting mayor, the city attorney shall be the acting commissioner of public facilities and the chief of police shall be the acting commissioner of streets and utilities. Each officer shall exercise the powers, perform the duties and be in charge of the departments which are assigned to the mayor and the commissioners under present policies; 
(2)  If any officer of the city, other than members of the governing body, is unavailable following an attack, then the acting governing body shall designate an emergency interim successor for such officer. 
(Code 1995, § 1-304; Ord. No. 3150, § 1, 8-11-2014) 
Sec. 30-35. - Call of special election. 
    The acting members of the governing body shall, within five days after first taking office, call a special election for the purpose of electing new members of the governing body. The election shall be held not later than 25 days after the call of such special election. 
(Code 1995, § 1-305) 
Sec. 30-36. - Duties of acting governing body. 
    The acting members of the governing body shall perform their duties only until a special election is held at which new members of the governing body are elected as provided by law. The persons elected to the governing body shall take office immediately after the canvass of the vote at the special city election by the acting members of the governing body. 
(Code 1995, § 1-306) 
Cross reference- Governing body, § 2-31 et seq. 
Chapter 34 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; emergency management, ch. 30; garbage burning, § 66-44; fires on public property, § 66-45; fires on private property, § 66-46; trees on street corners and near fireplugs, § 90-107; removal or burning of cut down trees, § 90-112. 
State Law reference- Fire prevention, K.S.A. 31-132 et seq.; local fire safety regulations, K.S.A. 31-134. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 34-1. - General responsibilities of fire chief. 
    The fire chief shall be responsible for all fire prevention in the city and enforcing the provisions of this chapter and such other and further regulations for the purpose of fire prevention as may from time to time be ordained or enacted. 
(Code 1995, § 14-802) 
Cross reference- Appointed officers and employees generally, § 2-81 et seq. 
Sec. 34-2. - Authority to enter and inspect premises. 
    The fire chief or his duly authorized assistant shall have the right at all reasonable hours, for the purpose of examination, to enter into and upon all buildings and premises in the city. Whenever, in any building or upon any premises, he shall find combustibles endangering any such building or premises, he shall order such combustibles to be removed or remedied and such order shall be forthwith complied with by the owner or occupant of the building or premises. If the owner or occupant shall deem himself aggrieved by such order, he may, within ten days after the issuance of such order, appeal to the state fire marshal. 
(Code 1995, § 14-803) 
Sec. 34-3. - Tampering with fire hydrants. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, other than authorized city employees or employees of the board of public utilities, to open, close or tamper with any fire hydrant belonging to the city. 
(Code 1995, § 12-214) 
Sec. 34-4. - False alarms for commercial properties and at college campuses. 
    In the event that the McPherson Fire Department responds to a false alarm of fire at a college campus or a commercial building within the city limits and after investigation, there are no individual(s) identified for which charges may be filed against for giving a false alarm under applicable city ordinance, the owner of the real property may be assessed a fine equal to $500.00 per false alarm. A false alarm shall be defined as transmitting in any manner, except by voice phone call, to the fire department or emergency dispatch a false alarm of fire when there is no reasonable ground for believing that such a fire exists. It shall be presumed that no reasonable ground existed if the responding fire department personnel can find no reasonable grounds for believing that a fire or other emergency existed and no individual acknowledges initiating the alarm to the responding fire department personnel. All fines collected herein shall be deposited in the general fund of the city. 
(Ord. No. 3088, § 1, 2-11-2013; Ord. No. 3156, § 1, 9-15-2014) 
Sec. 34-5. - Open burning. 
(a)  Open burning prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, corporation, partnership, association, organization or governmental agency properly regulated by the city, to burn or cause to be burned any bonfire, outdoor recreational fire in any structure or device, or open pit fire except: 
(1)  Fires using allowable outdoor recreational devices, as defined herein; 
(2)  Fires for the non-commercial preparation of food; 
(3)  Fire places or heaters constructed, installed, operated and maintained pursuant to International Fire Code (2009) Section 307.4.3 as amended from time to time; 
(4)  Fires used for training if granted approval of the Chief of the McPherson Fire Department; and 
(5)  Recreational fires allowed by advance written permission of the Chief of the McPherson Fire Department or designee and complying with all such conditions and restrictions as stated in the written approval. 
(b)  Incendiary. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, corporation, partnership, association, organization or governmental agency properly regulated by the city to deliberately, maliciously or negligently kindle or cause to be kindled a fire for the purpose of fraud, spite, revenge, vandalism, or for any reason that may endanger public health, safety or cause loss of life or property, or endanger the personnel assigned to respond. 
(c)  Trash burning prohibited. For purposes of the prohibition of burning trash contained in section 66-44 of the Code of the City of McPherson, leaves and yard waste shall be considered trash. 
(d)  Discontinuance. The McPherson Fire Chief or designee is authorized to require that any recreational fire shall be immediately discontinued if such fire is determined by the chief to constitute a hazardous condition under existing conditions. 
(e)  Fires used for non-commercial preparation of food. Fires used for non-commercial preparation of food, such as barbecuing, are permitted provided that the fire is in a freestanding cooking device using fossil fuel or natural gas, except it shall be unlawful to use, store or maintain a freestanding cooking device on the balcony, deck or patio of a multi-family dwelling containing more than four units unless: 
(1)  Such device uses only natural gas supplied by a fixed pipe; or 
(2)  Such device is at a distance that is not less than 15 feet from the structure of the multi-family dwelling and uses only natural gas, charcoal, wood or liquid propane. 
(f)  Attendant. Recreational fires shall be constantly attended by a person 18 years of age or older knowledgeable in the use of fire extinguishing equipment required by this section. An attendant shall supervise a recreational fire until such fire has been extinguished. Buckets, fire extinguishers, shovels or garden hoses shall be readily available for use at recreational fires. 
(g)  Recreational fire device. It shall be unlawful to use, store or maintain a recreational fire device, such as a chiminea, patio fireplace, patio heater or similar device on the balcony, deck or patio of a multi-family dwelling containing more than four units unless: 
(1)  Such device uses only natural gas supplied by a fixed pipe; or 
(2)  Such device is at a distance that is not less than 15 feet from the structure of the multi-family dwelling and uses only natural gas, charcoal, wood or liquid propane. 
(h)  Allowable outdoor recreational devices. It shall be unlawful to use a recreational fire device, such as a chiminea, patio fireplace, patio heater or similar device that is not UL certified or a UL certified device that has been modified so that spark arresters and other safety equipment are not operating as designed. Open fire pits are not permissible. As an alternative to a UL certified device, it is acceptable to use a non-UL certified or modified device if: 
(1)  The fire box is constructed of non-combustible materials and measures no larger than three feet wide, three feet long and two feet deep; 
(2)  Has spark arresting mesh of a quarter-inch square or smaller over all openings; and 
(3)  The owner has received written approval from the McPherson Fire Chief or designee prior to use or subsequent modification. 
(i)  Violation. The sentence for any violation of this section shall be the same penalty as provided herein for a class C violation of the uniform public offense code as adopted from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 3171, § 1, 4-20-2015) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3171, § 1, adopted April 20, 2015, set out provisions intended for use as § 34-4. To preserve the existing § 34-4, and at the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included herein as § 34-5. 
Sec. 34-6. - Cost recovery for hazardous material spills. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words and phrases when used in this section shall have the following definition. 
    Responsible party means person or organization which has been placed or assumes control of hazardous material, including the vehicle or facility, where the hazardous material is located immediately before the spill; 
    Hazardous materials or hazardous substances means those elements and compounds and hazardous wastes designated in 40 CFR 304.4 as amended; 
    Spill means any event required to be reported to proper state officials under K.A.R. 28-48-2. 
(b)  When a city emergency response team is activated to respond to a spill, the responsible party for the hazardous materials shall be responsible for paying the costs incurred as a result of the emergency response. The costs shall be set from time to time by resolution of the governing body. The responsible party shall be billed by the McPherson Fire Department. If the responsible party fails to pay the bill in full within 30 days of its issue, a second billing shall be issued by the McPherson Fire Department. The second billing and any subsequent billings shall include interest on the unpaid balance equal to the statutory rate on unpaid judgments as published from time to time by the Kansas Secretary of State's office. If payment is not made in full within 60 days of the initial billing, legal action may be brought to recover the costs of the response, reasonable attorneys' fees and costs, and any other related expenses. 
(c)  Within 30 days of the original billing issued, any responsible party who disagrees with a billing for costs incurred as a result of an emergency response may request a hearing before the governing body. The request for a hearing shall specifically identify the portion of the billing that is disputed and the factual basis of that dispute. Any remaining portion of the bill that is undisputed shall be paid in accordance with subsection (b). The decision of the governing body shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 3263, § 1, 2-5-2018) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3263, § 1, adopted Feb. 5, 2018, set out provisions intended for use as § 34-4. Inasmuch as there were already provisions so designated, said section has been codified herein as § 34-6 at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 34-7-34-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FIREFIGHTERS' RELIEF ASSOCIATION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Boards and commissions, § 2-281 et seq. 

Sec. 34-31. - Membership; organization; rules and regulations. 
    The firefighters' relief association shall be composed of the chief of the fire department and all the members of the fire department of the city. It shall be the duty of the association to organize in such manner and adopt such rules and regulations, not in conflict with the ordinances of the city or the laws of the state, as, in their judgment, they deem proper and necessary in carrying out and promoting the objectives of the association. 
(Code 1995, § 14-603) 
Sec. 34-32. - Moneys and funds. 
    All moneys and funds received by the treasurer of the firefighters' relief association of the city, under and by virtue of the provisions of K.S.A. 40-1701-40-1707, and all amendments thereto, shall be held and kept by the treasurer as a special fund and it shall be his official duty to keep such fund separate and apart from all other funds belonging to the city. Such fund is to be known and designated as the "McPherson Firefighters' Relief Association Fund," which is to be held in trust by the treasurer for the exclusive use and benefit of the members of the fire department of the city, their families and those dependent upon them, on account of death or injuries received by such firefighters in the discharge of their duties in connection with the fire department. The funds are to be paid out only in the manner provided for in this article, and shall be distributed and disbursed by the firefighters' relief association in pursuance of, and in accordance with, such bylaws, rules and regulations as may be adopted from time to time by the firefighters' relief association in pursuance of, and in conformity with, the laws of the state providing for the creation, use and distribution of the fund. 
(Code 1995, § 14-601) 
Cross reference- Finance, § 2-221 et seq. 
Sec. 34-33. - Disbursements. 
    All disbursements of funds as set forth in section 34-32 equal to or in excess of $1,500.00 shall first be presented to the city attorney by the firefighters' relief association, stating the amounts requested, for what purposes and the payee of such disbursement, and if it shall appear to the city attorney that such disbursements are proper under the Firefighters Relief Act, K.S.A. 40-1701 et seq., the city attorney shall authorized such disbursement in writing. If such disbursements are for less than $1,500.00 and comply with the requirements of the Code and the firefighters relief act, the treasurer of the firefighters relief association shall make such disbursement without further approval. 
(Code 1995, § 14-602; Ord. No. 2977, § 1, 12-15-08) 
Cross reference- Finance, § 2-221 et seq. 
Secs. 34-34-34-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - FIRE PREVENTION CODE 

Sec. 34-61. - International Fire Code. 
(a)  [Adopted.] That a certain document, three copies of which are on file in the office of the city clerk, being marked and designated as the International Fire Code, 2009 edition including Appendices B, C and D, as published by the International Code Council, be and is hereby adopted as the fire code of the City of McPherson for regulating and governing the safeguarding of life and property from fire and explosion hazards arising from the storage, handling and use of hazardous substances, materials and devices, and from conditions hazardous to life or property in the occupancy of buildings and premises as herein provided; providing for the issuance of permits and collection of fees therefor; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of said fire code on file in the office of the city clerk of the City of McPherson are hereby referred to, adopted, and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this section, with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if any, prescribed in subsection (b) of this section. 
(b)  Modifications. The following sections are hereby revised: 
Section 101.1. Insert: 
The City of McPherson for [Name of Jurisdiction]. 
Section 108.1 is deleted in its entirety and in its place the following is inserted: 
In order to hear and decide appeals of orders, decisions or determinations made by the fire code official relative to the application and interpretation of this code, there shall be and is hereby created a board of appeals. The City Commission of the City of McPherson is hereby constituted a board of appeals of orders, decisions or determinations made by the fire code official relative to the application and interpretation of this code. The City Commission may adopt rules of procedure, and shall render all decisions and findings in writing to the appellant with a duplicate copy to the fire code official. 
Section 108.3 is deleted in its entirety and in its place the following is inserted: 
Qualifications. The City Commission, sitting as a board of appeals hereunder, need have no special qualifications, but may appoint masters or experts as necessary or desired to obtain relevant information regarding matters pertaining to hazards of fire, explosions, hazardous conditions, or fire protection systems. Such persons, if appointed, may not be employees of the City. 
Section 109.3. Insert: 
Misdemeanor for [Specify Offense]; $500.00 for [amount]; 30 days for [Number of days]. 
Section 111.4. Insert: 
$250.00 as a minimum fine and $500.00 as a maximum fine for [amount] in appropriate places. 
Section 903.2.8 is revised to add the following: 
Notwithstanding anything to the contrary, this section shall not require automatic sprinkler systems in one and two-family dwellings and townhomes which are stand-alone buildings. Section 903.3.2 is revised to delete Group R from requirement 2. 
(c)  That the geographic limits referred to in certain sections of said Fire Code are hereby established as follows: 
Section 3404.2.9.6.1: The city limits of the City. 
Sections 3404.2.9.6.1; 3406.2.4.4; 3506.2; and 3804.2: The city limits of the City; provided, that the provisions of such Sections of the Fire Code shall be modified as set forth in existing Section 34-140 of the McPherson City Code (2009) as amended. Any references to the Uniform Fire Code shall be changed to the International Fire Code, 2009 edition. 
(Code 1995, § 14-701; Ord. No. 2515, § 1, 2-5-1996; Ord. No. 2702, § 1, 4-9-2001; Ord. No. 2734, §§ 1, 2, 10-7-2002; Ord. No. 2905, §§ 1-3, 12-26-2006; Ord. No. 2923, § 1, 7-2-2007; Ord. No. 3096, §§ 1, 3, 5-20-2013; Ord. No. 3184, §§ 1, 3, 9-8-2015; Ord. No. 3237, §§ 1-3, 3-13-2017) 
State Law reference- Adoption by reference, K.S.A. 12-3009 et seq., 12-3301 et seq. 
Sec. 34-62. - Violations; penalties. 
(a)  Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of the code in section 34-61 or fail to comply therewith, or who shall violate or fail to comply with any order made under such code, or who shall build in violation of any detailed statement of specifications or plans submitted and approved under such code, or any certificate or permit issued under such code, and from which no appeal has been taken, or who shall fail to comply with such an order as affirmed or modified by the fire chief or a court of competent jurisdiction, within the time fixed in this subsection, shall severally for each and every such violation and noncompliance respectively, be guilty of a misdemeanor. The imposition of one penalty for any violation shall not excuse the violation or permit it to continue, and all such persons shall be required to correct or remedy such violation or defect within a reasonable time, and when not otherwise specified, each ten days that prohibited conditions are maintained shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  The application of the penalty set forth in subsection (a) of this section shall not be held to prevent the enforced removal of prohibited conditions. 
(Code 1995, § 14-703) 
Sec. 34-63. - Appeals. 
    Whenever the fire chief shall disapprove an application or refuse to grant a permit applied for, or when it is claimed that the provisions of the Uniform Fire Code do not apply or that the true intent and meaning of the code have been misconstrued or wrongly interpreted, the applicant may appeal from the decision of the fire chief to the governing body of the city within 30 days from the date of the decision appealed. 
(Code 1995, § 14-702) 
Secs. 34-64-34-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - FIREWORKS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Bottle rockets, K.S.A. 31-155 et seq.; local regulation of fireworks, K.S.A. 31-134(b). 

Sec. 34-91. - Variances. 
    The fire chief may, with the approval of the governing body, authorize variations of the regulations of this article to avoid unnecessary hardship whenever the safety of persons and property will not be affected. 
(Code 1995, § 14-810) 
Sec. 34-92. - Sale and discharge of fireworks. 
    No person shall sell or discharge fireworks within the city, except between July 2 and July 4, inclusive, in each year, and only between the hours of 10:00 a.m. and 10:30 p.m., except that fireworks may be discharged from 10:00 a.m. to Midnight on July 4. For purposes of this article "fireworks" shall mean any pyrotechnical device regulated by the regulations promulgated by the Kansas State Fire Marshal and "state regulations" shall mean such regulations. Except as provided in this section, fireworks, which are lawfully permitted under such regulations, may be sold or discharged within the city. Fireworks shall not be sold or fired at any time on public property, in the public streets or in the central business district of the city which is defined as that area bounded on the north by Woodside Street, on the south by Sutherland Street, on the east by Ash Street and on the west by Maple Street. All fireworks shall at all times be sold, purchased, stored and discharged in accordance with state regulations. The governing body may grant special permission for pyrotechnical displays at such times and places as the governing body may determine. In addition to federal and state prohibitions, the following types of fireworks are shall not be sold or used within the city limits unless part of an authorized pyrotechnical display: 
(1)  Bottle rocket fireworks; 
(2)  Lanterns, sky lanterns or any other uninhabited free floating device which includes a flame or other heating device to heat air as a lifting mechanism; 
(3)  Metal sparklers or other hand-held firework that burn slowly while emitting flames, sparks, and other effects that also contain a stiff metal wire covered in part by a dried slow-burning pyrotechnic composition. Bamboo sparklers shall be permitted. 
(Code 1995, § 14-804; Ord. No. 2644, § 1, 11-22-1999; Ord. No. 2936, § 2, 10-15-2007; Ord. No. 3060, § 1, 6-11-2012; Ord. No. 3091, § 1, 4-8-2013) 
Cross reference- Licenses, permits and miscellaneous business regulations, ch. 38. 
Sec. 34-93. - Sales permit required. 
    Every person selling or offering for sale at retail fireworks permitted by state regulations and section 34-92 shall obtain a temporary use permit from the city inspector for each location from which the applicant proposes to sell or offer for sale fireworks at retail, which permit shall be issued upon the completion of an application form to be supplied by the city inspector, and payment of the permit fees required by section 34-94. Prior to opening each location for sales, the premises shall be inspected by a representative of the city's fire department to determine compliance with the state regulations, and if the permittee is found to be in compliance, an occupancy and sales permit shall be issued by the fire department. Permits granted under this section shall be valid during any year only as long as fireworks may be lawfully sold pursuant to section 34-92. No permits shall be issued to any person who, within the past five years, has had permits revoked for violation of applicable laws, city ordinances or state regulations or to any such person's spouse or minor children, and no permit shall be issued for any premises to be operated by a manager or agent unless such person would be eligible to hold a permit. 
    Notice. Every person selling or offering for retail sale fireworks within the city ("vendor") shall prominently display a written notice at the point of purchase listing the allowable hours and days that fireworks may be discharged within the city and a statement that fireworks may not be discharged in specific parts of the city. It shall be sufficient if the vendor prominently posts a legible copy of section 34-92 the point of purchase. 
(Code 1995, § 14-805; Ord. No. 2936, § 2, 10-15-2007) 
Cross reference- Licenses, permits and miscellaneous business regulations, ch. 38. 
Sec. 34-94. - Permit fees. 
    Prior to the issuance of a permit, the permittee shall pay a permit fee to the city as set by resolution of the governing body. Further, unless the permittee is a recognized nonprofit charitable organization currently exempt from income tax under the Federal Internal Revenue Code, the permittee shall pay an additional permit fee as set by resolution of the governing body. The proceeds of such fees shall go to the city's general fund. 
(Code 1995, § 14-806; Ord. No. 2612, § 1(14-806), 3-1-1999) 
Sec. 34-95. - Permit revocation. 
    All permittees shall at all times conduct their business according to the terms of the permit, applicable law, city ordinances and current orders and regulations of the state fire marshal, or the permits shall be revoked. Permits shall be revoked on the order of either the city inspector or the fire chief, or the fire chief's designated representative, if violations of the terms of the permit, applicable law, ordinances or state regulations are discovered. Warnings may be issued only once, and then only if nonconforming conditions are immediately remedied. 
(Code 1995, § 14-807) 
Secs. 34-96-34-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - LIQUEFIED PETROLEUM GAS SYSTEMS 

Sec. 34-131. - Liability. 
    Compliance with the regulations set forth in this article shall not be construed to relieve from or lessen the responsibility or liability of any party owning, operating, controlling or installing any system for handling or burning of liquefied petroleum gas, or material damage to persons or property caused by any defect therein, nor shall the city be held as assuming any such liability by reason of the inspection authorized in this article, or certificate of inspection authorized in this article, or certificate of inspection issued as provided in this article. 
(Code 1995, § 14-915) 
Sec. 34-132. - Classification of storage containers. 
    See NFPA No. 58, ch. 2. 
(Code 1995, § 14-903) 
Sec. 34-133. - Appeals. 
    Within five days after written notification by the city inspector to the owner or occupant of any building to correct or remedy any hazardous condition with respect to any liquefied petroleum gas system installed in such building, or within five days after refusal of the city inspector to approve any application for installing such system, or within five days after refusal of the city inspector to issue a permit for placing any such system in operation, an appeal, specifically stating the questions which the applicant desires to have passed upon, may be taken. Such appeal shall be promptly heard by the governing body. Upon such hearing, the members of the governing body are authorized to take testimony and grant or reject such appeal, subject to review by the proper court. 
(Code 1995, § 14-914) 
Sec. 34-134. - Permit required; application; fee; inspections and tests. 
(a)  Before installing in the city any system and/or appliances for the burning of liquefied petroleum gas, any person desiring to make such installation shall make written application to the city inspector on forms provided by him and such application shall be promptly examined by the city inspector. If the city inspector finds that the proposed system and appliances conform to the terms of the state regulations and this article, he shall approve the application, but otherwise, he shall deny the application until the system and appliances are made to conform with such regulations. A fee as set by resolution of the governing body shall be collected by the city inspector for each permit issued. The fee shall be paid to the city clerk each month with a report showing from whom and for what purpose such sum was collected. 
(b)  After approval of any such application, the applicant may proceed with the installation of the system and appliances expressly covered by such application. Such work shall only be done by gasfitters licensed by the city, and upon completion of such installation, the applicant shall notify the city inspector that such installation has been completed. No such installation or system shall be placed in operation until the actual installation in place has been inspected by the city inspector, who shall inspect such installation promptly upon being notified by the applicant that the installation has been completed (see section 18-411). 
(c)  If, upon such inspection and test, the city inspector finds that the installation has been made and completed in compliance with the application and the terms of the state regulations and this article, he shall then issue a permit allowing the system to be placed in operation. If, upon such inspection, the system or installation has not been made in compliance with the application and with such regulations, then a permit shall be refused until the installation is made to so comply. 
(Code 1995, § 14-906) 
Sec. 34-135. - Inspections; notice of noncompliance. 
    The city inspector shall have the right at any reasonable hour to inspect any system or installation in the city designed for the burning of liquefied petroleum gas. If, on such inspection, any system or installation is found to have become defective or unsafe and not in compliance with the terms of this article and the state regulations referred to in section 34-137, the city inspector shall notify, in writing, the owner or occupant of the premises where such system or installation is located of the particulars wherein such system or installation is defective or unsafe. Such notice shall be served by the city inspector on the occupant of the premises, if such premises are occupied, either by personally delivering the notice to the occupant or by firmly attaching the notice to the outside of the premises in a conspicuous place. Such notice shall specify the number of days within which such defective or unsafe system or appliance shall be placed in compliance with the regulations of this article and the state regulations, and upon failure of such system or appliance to be placed in compliance with the regulations of this article and the state regulations within the time specified in the notice, the city inspector shall, by written order served in the same manner as the notice provided for in this subsection, direct the use of the system or appliance to be discontinued until it is repaired and made safe in compliance with the terms of the notice. At any time the city inspector finds any such system or appliance to have become in such a defective or unsafe condition as to present an immediate hazard to persons or property, he shall order immediate discontinuance of the use of such system or appliance until it is made to comply with the regulations. 
(Code 1995, § 14-907) 
Sec. 34-136. - Propane exchange stations. 
    No propane exchange stations are allowed to be in a fire zone without the written permission of the fire chief or designee. No more than 20, 20-pound containers shall be stored in cabinets prescribed in NFPA No. 58. 
(Code 1995, § 14-909) 
Sec. 34-137. - Piping and connections. 
    No liquefied petroleum gas shall be piped or led into any industrial or other building, except a house or residence, at greater than an eight-ounce pressure. No piping, other than rigid iron pipe with airtight connections and capable of a working pressure of not less than 125 pounds, shall be used in conveying liquefied petroleum gas from the regular equipment to and into the appliance. 
(Code 1995, § 14-910) 
Sec. 34-138. - Equipment location; piping tests; changes in system. 
(a)  All regular equipment used on a liquefied petroleum gas system shall be located outside the building or structure. 
(b)  All piping leading from the regular equipment to the building or structure and then to the appliance shall be tested after installation and proven free from leaks at not less than 20 pounds of operating pressure, and the test is to be made in the presence of the city inspector before a permit to place the system in operation will be issued by the city inspector. 
(c)  Any change whatsoever that is made in the system after a permit has been issued by the city inspector shall nullify the permit, and a new test shall be made. 
(Code 1995, § 14-911) 
Sec. 34-139. - Tanks and cylinders used for transportation. 
    All tanks or cylinders used for the transportation of liquefied gases over the streets and alleys of the city shall be approved by the Interstate Commerce Commission and the state fire marshal department. 
(Code 1995, § 14-912) 
State Law reference- Regulations for transportation of liquid fuels, K.S.A. 31-146. 
Sec. 34-140. - Restrictions on liquefied petroleum gas storage tanks. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to install, store, use or otherwise maintain any liquefied petroleum gas cylinder, bottle or tank larger than 25-gallon individual capacity on residential property. It is further unlawful for any person to install, store, use or otherwise maintain any combination of cylinders, bottles or tanks with capacity greater than 50 gallons in the aggregate on any residential property. These regulations shall not apply in any areas within the city where natural gas is not available for heating and/or cooking purposes at reasonable rates and charges (taking into account rates and charges paid elsewhere in the state of Kansas). 
(b)  Installations of liquefied petroleum gas cylinders, bottles or tanks shall meet the requirements of the 2003 edition of the International Fire Code and NFPA 58. 
(c)  Liquefied petroleum gas cylinders, bottles or tanks having a water capacity of 500 gallons or less may be used on a temporary basis on construction sites, but not for longer than 180 days in any 12-month period. Anyone intending such use must obtain a permit to do so from the fire department. Permits will be issued if such use does not pose a significant fire or explosion risk, and will be issued subject to such reasonable conditions as are described in the permit. 
(d)  Liquefied petroleum gas cylinders, tanks and bottles on residential property to which natural gas service is not reasonably available shall not be larger than 124-gallon water capacity. Anyone intending to use such a tank with a capacity exceeding 50 gallons water capacity must obtain a permit to do so from the fire department. Permits will be issued if such use does not pose a significant fire or explosion risk, and will be issued subject to such reasonable conditions as are described in the permit. 
(e)  Liquefied petroleum gas cylinders, bottles or tanks having a water capacity of 500 gallons or less may be used by permit of the fire department in industrial areas where in the opinion of the fire chief or his/her designee it would be safe to do so. 
(f)  Under extraordinary circumstances, liquefied petroleum gas cylinders, bottles or tanks having a water capacity of more than 500 gallons may be used by permit of the fire department in industrial areas where in the opinion of the fire chief or his/her designee it would be safe to do so and will be issued subject to such reasonable conditions as are described in the permit. 
(g)  The following terms, as used in this section, shall be defined as follows: 
(1)  "Residential property" shall mean any property located within any district in the city zoned R-1, R-2, R-3, MH-1, MH-2, any planned unit development district that contains residential buildings, or any property upon which a residential building is situated. 
(2)  "Residential building" shall mean a building all or part of which contains one or more dwelling units, including single-family dwellings, two-family dwellings, multiple-family dwellings, earth-sheltered housing, lodging houses, dormitories, sororities and fraternities, as well as modular homes. 
(3)  "Construction site" shall mean any location where construction work is being actively pursued for which a building permit has been issued by the city. 
(4)  "Industrial area" shall mean any property located within any district in the city zoned A-1, I-1, I-2 and B-4. 
(h)  Except as provided by chapter 34 of the City Code, no liquefied petroleum gas cylinders, bottles or tanks may be maintained in any district in the city except for personal, recreational or non-resale use. 
(Ord. No. 2864, § 1, 12-19-2005; Ord. No. 2991, §§ 1, 2, 9-11-2009) 
Chapter 38 - LICENSES, PERMITS AND MISCELLANEOUS BUSINESS REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Alcoholic beverages, ch. 6; retail license for cereal malt beverages, § 6-61 et seq.; requirements and restrictions for retail establishments for cereal malt beverages, § 6-91 et seq.; state license required for alcoholic liquor, § 6-131; retailers for off-premises consumption of alcoholic liquor, § 6-151 et seq.; license for private clubs, § 6-211; license for drinking establishments, § 6-231; gasfitters license required; application; bond; fee, § 18-411; emergency management, ch. 30; sale and discharge of fireworks, § 34-92; sales permit required for fireworks, § 34-93; taxation, ch. 78; utilities, ch. 86; license for arborists and tree or shrub pruners, § 90-141 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 38-1. - Interstate commerce and business. 
    No provision of this chapter shall be construed to, in any way, relate to or interfere with the subject of commerce between states as provided by Article 1, Section 8 of the Constitution of the United States and as defined and decided by the supreme court of the state, and it is hereby declared to be the intent of this chapter not to levy any license fee on any interstate business of any licensee. 
(Code 1995, § 8-115) 
Secs. 38-2-38-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BUSINESS LICENSES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 38-31. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct, pursue, carry on or operate any calling, trade, profession, business or occupation for which a license is required by ordinance without first procuring a license from the city clerk. The amount to be paid for each and every license issued for any calling, trade, profession, business or occupation shall be as provided in this chapter. 
(Code 1995, § 8-101) 
Sec. 38-32. - Issuance; expiration. 
    All licenses shall be issued by the city clerk for the term stated, or any fraction thereof, upon payment of the proper sums as provided for in section 38-31 and, except for licenses authorized for shorter periods than six months, shall expire on June 30 or December 31 after such licenses are issued. Any person, at the time of applying for a license for the first six months of any year, may apply for and be granted a license for the last six months of such year. 
(Code 1995, § 8-111) 
Sec. 38-33. - Due date of fees. 
    All license fees shall be due and payable immediately upon the commencement of a profession or business for which the license is required, and for all such businesses, trades or professions which have been licensed for the preceding six months, the license tax shall be payable on January 1 or July 31 of each year. 
(Code 1995, § 8-114) 
Sec. 38-34. - Assignability and transferability. 
    No license shall be assigned or transferred unless specifically provided otherwise. 
(Code 1995, § 8-112) 
Sec. 38-35. - Revocation. 
    Any license issued under the provisions of this chapter shall be subject to revocation, without notice, by the governing body, when it appears from competent evidence that any licensee has failed to comply with any of the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1995, § 8-113) 
DIVISION 2. - SCRAP METAL DEALERS 

Sec. 38-36. - Scrap metal dealers; registration required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any business to purchase any regulated scrap metal without having first registered each place of business with the city as herein provided. 
(Ord. No. 3051, § 1, 3-12-2012) 
Sec. 38-37. - Definitions. 
    The words and phrases listed below when used in this article shall have the following meanings: 
    Bales of regulated metal means regulated scrap metal properly processed with professional recycling equipment by compression, sharing or shredding, to a form in which it may be sold by a scrap metal dealer consistent with industry standards. 
    Ferrous metal means a metal that contains iron or steel. 
    Junk vehicle means a vehicle not requiring a title as provided in chapter 8 of the Kansas Statutes Annotated, and amendments thereto, aircraft, boat, farming implement, industrial equipment, trailer or any other conveyance used on the highways and roadways, which has no use or resale value except as scrap. 
    Nonferrous metal means a metal that does not contain iron or steel, including, but not limited to, copper, brass, aluminum, bronze, lead, zinc, nickel and their alloys. 
    Regulated scrap metal shall mean wire, cable, bars, ingots, wire scraps, pieces, pellets, clamps, aircraft parts, junk vehicles, vehicles parts, pipes or connectors made from aluminum; catalytic converters containing platinum, palladium or rhodium; and copper, titanium, tungsten, stainless steel and nickel in any form, for which the purchase price described in K.S.A. 2010 Supp. 50-6, 110 and 50-6, 111, and amendments thereto, was primarily based on the content therein of aluminum, copper, titanium, tungsten, nickel, platinum, palladium, stainless steel or rhodium; any item composed in whole or in part of any nonferrous metal other than an item composed of tin, that is purchased or otherwise acquired for the purpose of recycling or storage for later recycling. Aluminum shall not include food or beverage containers. 
    Regulated scrap metal yard means any yard, plot, space, enclosure, building or any other place where regulated scrap metal is collected, gathered together and stored or kept for shipment, sale or transfer. 
    Scrap metal dealer means any person that operates a business out of a fixed location, and that is also either: 
(1)  Engaged in the business of buying and dealing in regulated scrap metal; 
(2)  Purchasing, gathering, collecting, soliciting or procuring regulated scrap metal; or 
(3)  Operating, carrying on, conducting or maintaining a regulated scrap metal yard or place where regulated scrap metal is gathered together and stored or kept for shipment, sale or transfer. 
    Tin means a metal consisting predominantly of light sheet metal ferrous scrap, including large and small household appliances, construction siding and construction roofing. 
    Vehicle part means the front clip consisting of the two front fenders, hood, grill and front bumper of an automobile assembled as one unit; or the rear clip consisting of those body parts behind the rear edge of the back doors, including both rear quarter panels, the rear window, trunk lid, trunk floor panel and rear bumper, assembled as one unit; or any other vehicle part. 
(Ord. No. 3051, § 1, 3-12-2012) 
Sec. 38-38. - Registration; application; fees; penalty. 
(a)  Application for registration for a scrap metal dealer shall be verified and made upon a form furnished by the city and approved by the attorney general and shall contain; 
(1)  The name and residence of the applicant; 
(2)  The length of time that the applicant has resided within the state of Kansas and a list of all residences outside the state of Kansas during the previous ten years; 
(3)  The particular place of business for which a registration is desired; 
(4)  The name of the owner of the premises upon which the place of business is located; and 
(5)  The applicant shall disclose any prior convictions within ten years immediately preceding the date of making the registration for theft, as defined in K.S.A. 21-3701, prior to its repeal, or section 87 of chapter 136 of the 2010 Session Laws of Kansas, theft of property lost, mislaid or delivered by mistake, as defined in K.S.A. 21-3703, prior to its repeal, or section 88 of chapter 136 of the 2010 Session Law of Kansas, theft of services, as defined in K.S.A. 21-3705, prior to its repeal, or section 89 of chapter 1136 of the 2010 Session Laws of Kansas, or any other crime involving possession of stolen property. 
(6)  In addition to the information required in subsection (a)(5), above, the applicant shall also disclose any prior convictions within ten years immediately preceding the date of making the application for registration for any federal or local crime or offense similar to those stated in subsection (a)(5), to include, but not be limited to, sections 6.1, theft, 6.3, theft of lost or mislaid property, and 6.5, criminal deprivation of property, and amendments thereto, of the Uniform Public Offense Code for Kansas Cities. 
(b)  Each registration for a scrap metal dealer to purchase regulated scrap metal shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable fee set from time to time by resolution of the governing body, but in no event outside of statutory limits. 
(c)  The city clerk shall provide the chief of police written notice of the filing of registration by a scrap metal dealer within ten days of registration or renewal. 
(Ord. No. 3051, § 1, 3-12-2012) 
Sec. 38-39. - Issuance of registration; renewal; renewal fees. 
(a)  Upon receipt of the application for registration, the application fee and verifying the information contained in the registration application that the applicant is qualified, the city clerk shall forward the application to the governing body, or its designee. The governing body, or its designee, shall accept a registration for a scrap metal dealer as otherwise provided for herein, registration, to purchase regulated scrap metals. 
(b)  Registrations issued hereunder, unless revoked as herein provided, shall be effective for a period of ten years. 
(c)  If an original registration is accepted, the governing body, or its designee, shall grant and issue renewals thereof upon application of the registration holder, if the registration holder is qualified to receive the same and the registration has not been revoked as provided by law. The registration fee for such renewal, which shall be in addition to the fee provided by Code section 38-38, shall be a nonrefundable fee set from time to time by resolution of the governing body, but in no event outside of statutory limits). 
(d)  No registration or renewal issued hereunder shall be transferable. 
(Ord. No. 3051, § 1, 3-12-2012) 
Sec. 38-40. - Penalty. 
    Violation of Code section 38-36 is a class A violation and punishable by a fine of not more than $2,500.00 or imprisonment in jail of not more than 12 months or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. No. 3051, § 1, 3-12-2012) 
Sec. 38-41. - Exception. 
    This division shall not apply to a business licensed under the provisions of K.S.A. 8-2404, and amendments thereto, unless such business buys or recycles regulated scrap metal that are not motor vehicle components. 
(Ord. No. 3051, § 1, 3-12-2012) 
Sec. 38-42. - Issuance; disqualification. 
(a)  After examining the information contained in a filing for a scrap metal dealer registration and determining the registration meets the statutory requirements for such registration, the governing body, or its designee, shall accept such filing and the scrap metal dealer shall be deemed to be properly registered. 
(b)  No scrap metal registration shall be accepted for: 
(1)  A person who is under 18 years of age and whose parents or legal guardians have been convicted of a felony or other crime which would disqualify such a person from registration under this section and such crime was committed during the time that such parents or legal guardians held a registration under this article.
