The appropriate authorities of the city or the McPherson Area Solid Waste Utility, in addition to other remedies, may institute injunction, mandamus or other appropriate action or proceedings to prevent or correct violations of this article and collect such civil penalties. 
(Code 1995, § 7-421) 
Chapter 70 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Any ordinance vacating any easement or park land saved from repeal, § 1-5(7); any ordinance levying or imposing any special assessment saved from repeal, § 1-5(9); any ordinance dedicating, establishing, naming, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening, repairing or vacating any street saved from repeal, § 1-5(10); any ordinance establishing the grade of any street or sidewalk saved from repeal, § 1-5(11); any ordinance levying, imposing or otherwise relating to taxes not codified in this Code saved from repeal, § 1-5(13); consumption of alcoholic liquor on public property, § 6-3; selling, serving, dispensing, possessing and consumption of alcoholic liquor in public places, § 6-4; open containers, § 6-5; control of dog waste; exception, § 10-50; aviation, ch. 14; buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; signs, § 18-861 et seq.; numbering buildings, § 18-941 et seq.; moving structures, § 18-971 et seq.; cemeteries, ch. 22; peddlers, solicitors, canvassers, § 38-271 et seq.; taxicabs and limousines, use of streets for stalls and parking places, § 38-342; manufactured homes and trailers, ch. 42; begging and soliciting alms, § 54-175; parks and recreation, ch. 58; fires on public property, § 66-45; subdivisions, ch. 74; traffic and vehicles, ch. 82; riding bicycles on sidewalks, § 82-146; utilities, ch. 86; excavations for building sewer installations, § 86-161; vegetation, ch. 90; trees on public property, § 90-101 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 70-1. - Use of streets or parking for private purposes. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to use any part of any public parking, parking lot or street for any private purpose, except as otherwise provided by the ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1995, § 12-210) 
Cross reference- Stopping, standing and parking, § 82-101 et seq. 
Sec. 70-2. - Erecting or maintaining buildings in rights-of-way. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to erect or maintain any building or structure within, or partially within, any street, avenue or alley right-of-way or which encroaches to any extent upon any street, avenue or alley right-of-way, except as otherwise provided by an encroachment easement duly authorized by the governing body. This section shall not prevent the erection of necessary scaffolding used temporarily in the construction of permanent buildings. 
(Code 1995, § 12-211) 
Sec. 70-3. - Surface water from air conditioners. 
    It shall be declared a nuisance for any surface water discharge from any air conditioner to be discharged through, by or on the streets, alleys or sidewalks of the city, except by means of a properly installed collection system, or in any other manner approved by the board of health that releases the discharge no more than 12 inches above the street, alley or sidewalk. If the owner or occupant of a lot or parcel of ground on which an air conditioner is located fails or refuses to abate such nuisance as described in this section when so ordered by the board of health, the city's public works director shall proceed to correct the nuisance and shall report the actual cost thereof to the city clerk, which cost shall be assessed against the lot or parcel of ground in the same manner as provided in section 50-40. 
(Code 1995, § 11-301; Ord. No. 2628, § 1, 7-19-1999) 
Sec. 70-4. - Leaving articles on sidewalks and public ways. 
    No person shall leave, or allow to be left, any implement, tool, box, merchandise, goods, trash can, crate or other article on any of the sidewalks, parking or other public ways of the city for a period of time longer than is necessary for loading or unloading such article, unless special permission is granted by the governing body. 
(Code 1995, § 12-204) 
Sec. 70-5. - Sidewalk construction permit. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in the city to construct, or cause to be constructed, repaired, altered, removed or replaced, any sidewalk or other permanent walk in the parking of any street in the city without first having secured a permit therefore. Application for any such permit shall be made in writing to the city engineer and shall give the description of the property along which the walk or work is proposed to be done, the width of the walk and location with reference to the property line and curb line, and the specification and materials proposed to be used for such work. Such a permit shall be issued upon a showing of compliance with all applicable ordinances and upon payment of any required fee. If approved, a permit shall be issued, with the fee as set by resolution adopted from time to time by the governing body. 
(Code 1995, § 6-301; Ord. No. 3050, § 1, 3-12-2012) 
Sec. 70-6. - Duty of abutting property owner to maintain sidewalk. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the owner, occupant or agent of the owner of any lot or tract of land abutting on any sidewalk to keep the abutting sidewalk free of the following, which are hereby declared to be public nuisances: 
(1)  Weeds or other vegetation growing between the cracks and joints of the sidewalk; 
(2)  Accumulations of snow or ice on the sidewalks; 
(3)  Permitting any segment of the sidewalk to be raised more than one-half inch above the established level of the sidewalk in any manner which might catch the foot of a pedestrian, or to permit any crack, hole or depression to remain in the sidewalk in which a pedestrian might step or catch his foot in a manner liable to cause injury; and 
(4)  Any tree, shrub or other plant installed in parking in violation of sections 90-73, 90-101 and 90-102. 
(b)  Accumulations of snow or ice shall be removed from sidewalks within 12 hours after such snow or ice has fallen or accumulated, except if such snowfall or ice accumulation occurs during the nighttime, then removal shall be made within 12 hours after sunrise on the following day. Where ice or compacted snow is of such a character as to make its removal practically impossible, then the provisions of this subsection may be complied with by sprinkling sand, ashes or any other noncorrosive material or chemical thereon within such 12-hour time limit. 
(c)  Upon failure or refusal of any person whose duty it is to abate the nuisances described in this section, the city clerk shall serve written notice upon such person either by mailing the notice or by personal service of such notice by a city police officer, requiring the notice to be served immediately, and if such person fails to abate the nuisance within the following time periods such person shall be guilty of a misdemeanor: 
(1)  Weeds or vegetation, one day; 
(2)  Snow or ice, 12 hours; 
(3)  Holes, depressions or elevations, 30 days. 
(d)  The notice shall be deemed sufficient if it is delivered or mailed to the owner or occupant of the property affected at his usual place of business or residence, and if the owner is a nonresident and he or an agent cannot be found within the city, by mailing a copy to the owner at his last known address and posting a copy of the notice in a conspicuous place on the property. 
(e)  If the nuisance described is not abated within the time period allowed in the notice provided for in this section, the city may proceed to abate such nuisance, and the cost of abating such nuisance shall be assessed against the abutting property in the manner provided in section 50-40. 
(Code 1995, §§ 11-401-11-404; Ord. No. 3120, § 2, 9-3-2013) 
Sec. 70-7. - Permit for boring in right-of-way. 
(a)  Any party that desires to underground bore any line or service that will cross or parallel, as defined below, a city sanitary or storm sewer line ("city line"), in or through existing city rights-of-way shall first submit plans for approval to the public works department at least five business days before the desired start date. The public works director or designee shall review the plans and indicate approval or denial within five business days of receipt of the final plans. The time for review shall not begin until the public works director has received plans in sufficient detail to make the necessary review. Any denial shall include the reason(s) for the denial. Upon payment of the permit fee, as set from time to time by resolution of the governing body, and an acceptable written indemnity provided to the city for any damage caused, a permit shall be issued for all approved work. The permit fee shall be assessed per crossing and per parallel segment. A parallel segment is the line from manhole to manhole. Permits issued under this section shall be required when boring operations: 
(1)  Cross within three vertical feet of a city line during a horizontal bore; or 
(2)  Cross within five vertical feet of a city line during a non-horizontal bore; or 
(3)  Parallel a city line within three horizontal feet. 
(b)  In order to determine if damage has occurred to a city line, the permit holder shall have the city line video inspected by the city, or by a contractor acceptable to the city. The permit holder shall be solely responsible for payment of the video contractor. The permit holder may elect to pothole or open dig the city line ("pothole"); however, the city line must be exposed in the same hole, for inspection by city staff. In the event a city line cannot be inspected by video, in the sole discretion of the city public works director, potholing of the city line will be required. 
(c)  With a pothole inspection or an approved contractor provided video inspection, a 70 percent refund of the permit fee will be to the permit holder if the result of the visual inspection reasonably assures the city line has not been damaged. There will be no refund for city conducted video inspection because of the increased cost. Any damage shown by the pothole inspection shall first be paid from the 70 percent of the permit fee with the remaining damage paid under the indemnification agreement required above. 
(Ord. No. 3262, § 1, 1-22-2018; Ord. No. 3265, § 1, 2-19-2018) 
Sec. 70-8. - Overhanging hedges and trees. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person owning or controlling any hedge or tree bordering on any street, park street, sidewalk or alley in the city to permit the hedge or tree to grow lower than nine feet above the surface of such sidewalk or lower than 16 feet above the traveled portion of such street or alley. 
(Code 1995, § 12-203; Ord. No. 3120, § 1, 9-3-2013) 
Cross reference- Trees and shrubs, § 90-71 et seq. 
Sec. 70-9. - Camping in municipal parking lots and on certain public streets. 
(a)  Definitions. As used in this ordinance the following terms have the following meanings: 
    Camp means to occupy an automobile, truck or recreational vehicle as living quarters. Camp also means to park a recreational vehicle on a street or in a municipal parking lot for three or more consecutive hours in any 24-hour period, unless the recreational vehicle is unoccupied the entire time it is parked there. 
    Municipal parking lot means any public parking area owned by the city. 
    Recreational vehicle means a vehicle or portable structure without permanent foundation, capable of being towed, hauled or driven over the road and primarily designed as a temporary living accommodation for recreational, camping and travel use, including, but not limited to, travel trailers, truck campers, camping trailers, self-propelled motor homes, and trucks, buses, or vans converted for such uses. 
    Street means any public way, private way, or driveway, except a private way or driveway providing access only to a single-family or two-family dwelling. 
(b)  Camping in certain places prohibited. No person shall camp in any municipal parking lot within the city or on any street in any area of the city not zoned for residential uses. Camping in any area not prohibited is subject to all limitations thereon provided by city zoning regulations and park use regulations. 
(c)  Persons liable; penalties. Any person who violates this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by a fine in an amount not exceeding $500.00 or a jail sentence not exceeding 30 days, or both. The following persons shall be guilty of violation of this article: 
(1)  Any person above the age of 18 who is occupying the automobile, truck or recreational vehicle at the time of violation; 
(2)  The driver who parked the automobile, truck or recreational vehicle involved in the violation; and 
(3)  The owner of the automobile, truck or recreational vehicle involved in the violation. 
Ord. No. 2800, §§ 1-3, 11-24-2003) 
Secs. 70-10-70-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - EXCAVATIONS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Excavations for building sewer installations, § 86-161. 

Sec. 70-41. - Permit required; fees. 
(a)  No person shall make excavations in the streets, sidewalks, alleys or other public grounds of the city for the purpose of laying any pipe, wire or conduit, or for any other purpose, without such person first obtaining a permit authorizing such excavation from the public works director. Such a permit shall be issued upon a showing that there will be compliance with all applicable ordinances and upon payment of any required fee. The department of public works or its designee shall cut and replace the pavement as directed in the permit and the person shall be required to pay a fee for labor, equipment and materials as required by the public works director and approved by the governing body. No person, other than the department of public works, BPU or contractor previously approved in writing by the director of public works, shall cut any pavement in the city. 
(b)  Any person who has obtained a permit to excavate as provided for in subsection (a) of this section shall pay the amount stipulated in subsection (a) of this section to the city clerk to cover the cost of replacing whatever pavement is cut. All such fees collected by the city clerk shall be credited to the city street fund and all expenses of replacing the pavement cut under the provisions of this section shall be charged to the street fund. 
(Code 1995, §§ 6-201, 6-204; Ord. No. 3050, § 2, 3-12-2012) 
Sec. 70-42. - Barricades, safety guards and lights required. 
    Any person making an excavation in any of the streets, sidewalks, alleys or public grounds of the city shall, at all times during the work, maintain proper barricades, safety guards and lights for the protection of the traveling public, and in all cases, any such excavation shall be braced to prevent caving or injury to adjoining premises, and the party making the excavation and his bondsman shall at all times be liable to the city for damages arising by reason of any neglect or carelessness in any respect concerning the excavation. All streets must be opened in a manner which will occasion the least inconvenience to the general public and admit the uninterrupted passage of water along the gutters. No excavation of any public street or alley, or any public ground shall be allowed to be open overnight without proper barricades and being illuminated with lights or flares from sunset to sunrise. 
(Code 1995, § 6-202) 
Cross reference- Removing barricades, § 54-143. 
Sec. 70-43. - Backfilling. 
    Any person making an excavation in any of the streets, sidewalks, alleys or public grounds of the city shall backfill all trenches, ditches or excavations made by such person. All streets, sidewalks and alleys excavated must be restored to as good a condition as such streets, sidewalks and alleys were prior to such excavation, and all dirt, stone or other rubbish must be immediately removed upon the completion of the work. It shall be the duty of such person making such excavation to follow the directions of any person directed by the city to supervise the work. Should any excavation upon any street, sidewalk, alley or public ground be left open or unfinished for more than 24 hours, or should the work be improperly done, or the rubbish not removed, the public works director shall have the right, and is hereby authorized, to finish or correct the work and the expense incurred shall be charged to the party making the excavation, and the expense must be paid before such party shall be allowed another permit. 
(Code 1995, § 6-203) 
Secs. 70-44-70-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CURB CUTS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 70-71. - Permit required. 
    No person shall cut any curb and gutter in or along any street in the city without first having obtained a permit from the city engineer authorizing such work to be done. The applicant shall furnish such information as is required by the city engineer to show that the work is to be done in accordance with accepted standards and all forms shall be inspected by the engineering department before the concrete is poured. Such a permit shall be issued upon a showing of compliance with all applicable ordinances and upon payment of any required fee. 
(Code 1995, § 6-205) 
Secs. 70-72-70-90. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - MAIN TRAFFICWAYS 

Sec. 70-91. - Compliance required. 
    No portion of the existing curbing on any street or avenue designated by the governing body as a main trafficway shall be cut or removed by any adjoining property owner, his agent or employee, except as provided in this division. 
(Code 1995, § 6-206) 
Sec. 70-92. - Application for permission; fee. 
    Should an adjoining property owner desire to cut or remove the cubing along any main trafficway within the city, the property owner shall apply directly, or through the city engineer or his agent, to the governing body for permission to make such cutting or removal of the curbing. The application shall be in writing and shall contain a verbal description of the proposed cut or removal, including the precise length of that portion of the curbing to be cut or removed, the purpose of the proposed cut or removal, and a statement of the precautions the adjoining property owner intends to take to preserve the character of the main trafficway, both as to construction and function. The application shall be accompanied by a fee to be established from time to time by resolution of the governing body. 
(Code 1995, § 6-207) 
Sec. 70-93. - Application review and decision of governing body. 
    The governing body shall, as promptly as possible, review each application and, if such application does not conflict with the state department of transportation agreements or the 40-foot maximum for driveways, and is otherwise approved, shall enter such approval in the minutes of the governing body. The governing body may, however, deny the application as provided in section 70-95. If such cut or removal is approved, it may thereafter be made, but only under the supervision of the city engineer and upon such conditions as the governing body may establish in each case to assure that the grade and construction specifications of the main trafficway shall be preserved. 
(Code 1995, § 6-208) 
Sec. 70-94. - Subdivisions. 
    In lieu of the application provided for in section 70-92, any person proposing to subdivide land adjoining a main trafficway shall be deemed to have complied with the requirements of sections 70-91-70-95 upon approval, in due course, by the city planning commission and the governing body of the final plat of such subdivision, which plat shows additional entrances onto the main trafficway from streets in the platted subdivision. The governing body may, however, condition its approval of such plat upon the furnishing of whatever guarantees are deemed appropriate, in the discretion of the governing body, to assure that the grade and construction of the main trafficway are preserved by the subdivider. 
(Code 1995, § 6-209) 
Cross reference- Subdivisions, ch. 74. 
Sec. 70-95. - Application denial. 
    The application provided for in section 70-92 shall not be unreasonably denied, and if such application is denied, the governing body shall deliver to the applicant a written statement of its reasons for denial. In evaluating such application, however, the governing body shall give primary consideration to preservation of the character of the street as a main trafficway and the burden is on the applicant to show that the function of such street as a main trafficway will not be significantly altered or reduced by the proposed cut or removal. 
(Code 1995, § 6-210) 
Secs. 70-96-70-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PUBLIC DRAINAGEWAYS 

Sec. 70-131. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Public drainageway means a strip or tract of land in which the city has an ownership interest, created for the purpose of conveying surface water from one point to another, or for the purpose of permitting, unhindered, the natural flow of surface water from one point to another. Public drainageways may be created by deed, grant of easement or plat dedication, or may be taken by eminent domain, and include utility easements and other public dedications not denominated as drainage easements that are in fact serving as drainageways for surface waters. 
(Ord. No. 2715, § 1, 11-26-2001) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 70-132. - Failure to comply; assessment of costs. 
    If any landowner obligated under this article fails or refuses to discharge the obligations imposed by this article, within ten days after the city has given written notice to such owner of his failure to comply with the provisions of this article, the city may enter upon the easement or other drainageway, perform the work required of the landowner to keep the easement or drainageway maintained, open and free of hindrances or trash as required in this article and as specified in the written notice, and repair any damage caused by such failure. The city shall keep a record of the costs of such work, including reasonable administrative costs to the city, and shall bill the landowner for such costs. If the landowner fails or refuses to pay such costs within 30 days after such billing, then the city shall certify such costs to the county clerk as an assessment to be assessed against the affected land in the manner provided in K.S.A. 12-1617e. Any such assessment shall include interest at the statutory rate from the due date of the initial billing until it is paid. Nothing in this section shall be deemed to restrict the city's ability to enforce the provisions of this article in the manner provided in either K.S.A. 12-1617e or K.S.A. 12-1617f, as applicable. 
(Ord. No. 2715, § 7, 11-26-2001) 
Sec. 70-133. - Hearing. 
    Any landowner receiving a written notice from the city to comply with the provisions of this article may, within ten days after the mailing of such notice, request a hearing on the matter before the governing body. At any such hearing, the governing body shall review the matter and address the landowner's concerns. At the conclusion of the hearing, the governing body may determine that no work is required, affirm the original work required or issue a modified notice requiring different work. The governing body shall have no authority to relieve the landowner from compliance with this article entirely, or from compliance with any other effective Code provision applying to the landowner's property. 
(Ord. No. 2715, § 8, 11-26-2001) 
Sec. 70-134. - Use and occupancy. 
    With respect to any dedicated public drainageway in the city, every adjoining landowner shall have the full use of the land owned by such landowner which is within the boundaries of the public drainageway, except to the extent that such use would interfere with, or impede in any way, the flow of water through or across the drainageway. 
(Ord. No. 2715, § 1, 11-26-2001) 
Sec. 70-135. - Objects placed to impede, restrict of slow the flow of surface water. 
    No adjoining landowner may place or construct within the boundaries of a public drainageway any structure, object or planting that would impede, restrict or slow the flow of surface water across the drainageway. 
(Ord. No. 2715, § 2, 11-26-2001) 
Sec. 70-136. - Maintenance responsibility. 
    Every owner of land adjoining a public drainageway must maintain the adjoining drainageway. If the drainageway lies between private property and a public alley, street or highway, then the owner of the adjoining private property must maintain the entire drainageway. If private property abuts the drainageway on both sides, then each owner of abutting property must maintain the drainageway to the centerline thereof or to the center of the channel, if the drainageway contains an identifiable channel. The responsible property owner must keep all grass, weeds and similar vegetation mowed to a height of not more than 12 inches, and must maintain all shrubs, trees or other plantings and the surface grade so as not to obstruct, impede or restrict the flow of surface water across the drainageway. 
(Ord. No. 2715, § 3, 11-26-2001) 
Sec. 70-137. - Trash, rubbish and debris. 
    Every owner of land adjoining a public drainageway must keep the drainageway free of all trash, rubbish and debris, including, but not limited to, leaves, grass, twigs, sticks, branches, brush, paper, plastic, wood, metal or glass, regardless of the place of origin. Each owner's responsibility shall extend to the area required by section 70-136 to be mowed and maintained by such owner. 
(Ord. No. 2715, § 4, 11-26-2001) 
Cross reference- Solid waste, ch. 66. 
Sec. 70-138. - Responsibility for damage due to failure to maintain. 
    If any property owner fails or refuses to maintain a public drainageway to the extent required by this article, and such failure results in damage to the drainageway, then such owner shall be responsible for the reasonable costs of repairing the damage caused by such failure to maintain the drainageway. 
(Ord. No. 2715, § 5, 11-26-2001) 
Sec. 70-139. - Failure to comply. 
    Any landowner who fails to discharge the obligations imposed by this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor if, after being given written notice by the city of the failure of such owner to comply with the provisions of this article, such failure continues for a period of ten days. 
(Ord. No. 2715, § 6, 11-26-2001) 
Secs. 70-140-70-160. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - PRIVATELY-OWNED FACILITIES WITHIN PUBLIC RIGHTS-OF-WAY 

Sec. 70-161. - Definitions. 
(a)  Public right-of-way means all real property within the city in which the city has a dedicated or acquired right-of-way interest in the real property and all real property within the city dedicated on subdivision plats or acquired by contractual grant as utility easements. It shall include the area on, below or above present and future streets, alleys, avenues, roads, highways, parkways or boulevards dedicated or acquired as right-of-way and all area on, below or above present dedicated or granted utility easements. The term does not include the airwaves above a right-of-way with regard to wireless telecommunications or other nonwire telecommunications, or broadcast service, or easements granted to private utilities in platted subdivisions or tracts. 
(b)  Occupant means any person, firm, corporation, association, utility or entity, which proposes to enter upon, or enters upon a public right-of-way, or in any manner establishes a physical presence on, upon, in or over a public right-of-way, for the purpose of installing, constructing, maintaining or operating lines, conduits, wires, fiber optic cables, pipes, pipelines, poles, towers, vaults or appliances, or related facilities or appurtenances thereto. 
(Ord. No. 2826, § 1, 11-8-2004) 
Sec. 70-162. - Authorization from city required. 
(a)  No occupant may enter upon a public right-of-way, or in any manner establish a physical presence on, upon, in or over a public right-of-way, for the purpose of installing, constructing, maintaining or operating lines, conduits, wires, fiber optic cables, pipes, pipelines, poles, towers, vaults or appliances, or related facilities or appurtenances thereto, without the express written permission of the city. The permission of the city may be granted by a franchise pursuant to the provisions of K.S.A. 12-2001 et seq. or by such other agreement as the governing body determines is necessary or desirable to protect the public interest in the public right-of-way. 
(b)  Nothing in this article shall be interpreted as granting an occupant the authority to construct, maintain or operate any facility or related appurtenance on property owned by the city outside of a public right-of-way. 
(c)  The city shall process each valid and administratively complete application for any permit, license or consent as described in K.S.A. 17-1902(i) within 30 days after receipt of the occupant's completed application, shall make reasonable effort not to unreasonably delay or burden the applicant in the timely conduct of its business, and shall use reasonable efforts to assist the occupant in obtaining all such permits, licenses and other consents in an expeditious and timely manner. 
(d)  Applications for permits, licenses or consents required by the city in connection with an occupant's proposed installation of its facilities in a public right-of-way shall be in such forms, and for such purposes, including street and curb cuts, as are prescribed from time to time by ordinance, resolution or formally adopted policy of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2826, § 1, 11-8-2004) 
Sec. 38-163. - Health, safety, and welfare regulations. 
    The authority of an occupant to use and occupy the public right-of-way shall always be subject and subordinate to the reasonable public health, safety and welfare requirements and regulations of the city, including those set forth in this article and any further such requirements and regulations as may be hereafter enacted. 
(Ord. No. 2826, § 1, 11-8-2004) 
Sec. 38-164. - Use of specific portions of right-of-way restricted. 
(a)  Upon the recommendation of the city engineer, the city may prohibit an occupant from using or occupying specific portions of public right-of way due to a reasonable public interest necessitated by public health, safety and welfare, including location limitations imposed under subsection (b) below. Such prohibitions must be imposed in a competitively neutral manner and may not be unreasonable or discriminatory. Such prohibitions must be administered consistently with the provisions of K.S.A. 17-1902(e)(1) to (e)(4), inclusive. 
(b)  To promote the efficient, economical and orderly use of the public right-of-way, the city engineer may require that the location of specific utility installations be limited to specified portions of the public right-of-way, with respect to both horizontal and vertical location. 
(c)  If the city denies a request to use or occupy a specific portion of the public right-of-way, the prospective occupant shall be served a notice of such denial by first class mail. The notice shall indicated that the prospective occupant has ten days from the date of receipt of the notice to request a public hearing by the city's governing body concerning the denial. Failure to make a timely request for a hearing shall constitute a waiver of the prospective occupant's right to contest the denial before the governing body. The governing body shall hold the hearing within 30 days after the filing of the request, and the city shall give the prospective occupant reasonable notice of the time and place of the hearing. Following the public hearing, if the city governing body denies a potential occupant's request to use or occupy a specific portion of the public right-of-way, such determination may be appealed to district court. 
(Ord. No. 2826, § 1, 11-8-2004) 
Sec. 70-165. - Traffic control. 
(a)  Notification. No street, alley, or other traveled way shall be partially or completely closed by an occupant for any purpose without the approval of the chief of police. Each occupant shall be responsible for notifying emergency services (police, fire, ambulance) prior to such closure and upon re-opening. The need for such closures shall be described in the occupant's application for a permit. Occupant shall be responsible for notifying KDOT and obtaining necessary KDOT approvals for any closures involving KDOT regulated highways. 
(b)  Traffic control devices. All work zones established by any occupant shall be protected by appropriate barricades, channelizers, signs, and pavement markings conforming to the applicable provisions of the Manual of Uniform Traffic Control Devices (MUTCD), Millennium Edition, Part 6, Temporary Traffic Control, published by the U.S. Department of Transportation, Federal Highway Administration, or as outlined by the Kansas Department of Transportation (KDOT), Traffic Engineering Standards and Guidelines, as presently published or hereafter amended. All traffic control devices shall comply with the National Cooperative Highway Research Program, Report 350, "Recommended Procedures for the Safety Performance Evaluation of Highway Features," June, 2001. The referenced standards are incorporated herein by reference as if fully set forth herein. 
(Ord. No. 2826, § 1, 11-8-2004) 
Sec. 70-166. - Additional requirements. 
(a)  Public works policy. All occupants of a public right-of-way must conform their activities to the requirements of the policies of the city's department of public works as set forth in the Memorandum titled "Utility Cuts, Sanitary Sewer Taps," adopted September 9, 2002, and subsequent revisions thereto. These policies address (i) requirements to obtain a permit of open cut excavation of paved or unpaved streets and alleys, including documentation of the "as-built" configuration of the installation, (ii) requirements for backfilling open cuts, including use of flowable fill in paved or unpaved streets and alleys, and (iii) specific provisions relating to sanitary sewer taps, mains and laterals. 
(b)  Storm water. Occupant's work in the public rights-of-way shall not interrupt, change, or impede the existing flow pattern of storm water drainage, nor shall the existing drainage patterns be permanently altered without written consent from the city engineer. Any water discharged from or diverted around occupant's work area shall be discharged into an approved sediment control system. Sediment generated from occupant's work area shall be controlled by the use of silt fences, hay bales, or other devices. Occupant's storm water discharge quality and sediment control shall conform to the requirements of the city, the Kansas Department of Health and Environment (KDHE), and other public agencies having jurisdiction, as such requirements now exist, or may hereafter be amended. 
(c)  Americans with Disabilities Act. Restoration of public infrastructure, including without limitation, sidewalks, handicap ramps, and pavement, shall conform to the requirements of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), as set forth in the "ADAAG Manual, Americans with Disabilities Act Accessibility Guidelines," developed by the U.S. Architectural and Transportation Barriers Compliance Board (Access Board), latest edition. Occupant is responsible for work beyond occupant's work zone that may be necessary to meet ADAAG requirements in the occupant's work zone. 
(d)  Utility locates. Each occupant is responsible for notifying Dig-Safe prior to performing excavation work. The city is not a member of Dig-Safe. Occupant is responsible for notifying the city's department of public works three working days in advance of the need to perform excavation (including directional boring) so that the city can locate its sanitary and storm sewer lines. Any damage to the city's storm sewer or sanitary sewer utilities and appurtenances must be repaired to the satisfaction of the city, whether or not the city located them. 
(Ord. No. 2826, § 7, 11-8-2004) 
Sec. 70-167. - Emergencies. 
    If there is an emergency necessitating response work or repair, any occupant of the public right-of-way may begin that repair or emergency response work or take any action required under the circumstances, provided that the occupant notifies the city promptly after beginning the work and timely thereafter meets any permit or other requirement had there not been such an emergency. 
(Ord. No. 2826, § 7, 11-8-2004) 
Sec. 70-168. - Repair. 
(a)  General requirements. Any occupant of the public right-of-way is hereby required to repair all damage to a public right-of-way caused by the activities of that occupant, or of any agent affiliate, employee, or subcontractor of that occupant, while occupying, installing, repairing or maintaining facilities in a public right-of-way and to return the right-of-way to its functional equivalence before the damage, pursuant to the reasonable requirements and specifications of the city. Any and all excess excavated or other material shall become the property of the occupant and shall be removed from the public right-of-way and disposed of at the occupant's expense. If the occupant fails to make the repairs required by the city, the city may make the repairs and charge the occupant the city's direct and indirect costs in making them. 
(b)  Warranty. Occupant warrants that all modifications, replacements, or repairs to the public infrastructure, including but not limited to backfill, curb, gutter, pavement, street or alley surfacing, storm drainage facilities, sidewalks, handicap ramps, and related public improvements will be free of defects due to material or workmanship for a period of two years from completion and acceptance by the city. Occupant shall correct such defects within 30 days of notification by the city of the need for correction. Should occupant fail to correct such defects, the city may arrange for the necessary work to be done and the cost thereof billed to the occupant. 
(c)  Damage to occupant's installations. Neither the city nor any other occupant may be held liable for damage to an occupant's property installed in the public right-of-way caused by digging into it if the city or other occupant has exercised ordinary care to find the installation's location and protect it during digging. 
(Ord. No. 2826, § 7, 11-8-2004) 
Sec. 70-169. - Relocation. 
    Whenever requested by the city, in order to accomplish construction and maintenance activities directly related to improvements for the health, safety and welfare of the public, an occupant must promptly remove its facilities from the public right-of-way or relocate or adjust them within the public right-of-way at no cost to the city. Relocation or adjustment must be completed within the time set forth in the request by the city, as long as the request is reasonable. Damages suffered by the city or its contractors as a result of the occupant's failure to timely relocate or adjust its facilities shall be borne by such occupant. 
(Ord. No. 2826, § 7, 11-8-2004) 
Sec. 70-170. - Fees. 
    The following fees shall be assessed against occupants of the public right-of-way: 
(a)  A permit fee of $25.00 to partially offset review, administration, and record keeping costs associated with review of occupant's plans, issue curb-cut or street cut permits (if required), and provide written project-specific requirements (if required). 
(b)  An inspection fee of $100.00 for occupant's work that involves excavations not exceeding 200 square yards in area in a street or alley or that involves removal and replacement of sidewalks, handicap ramps, curb, gutter, storm drainage facilities, or other infrastructure. The fee is to partially offset city's costs associated with monitoring and inspecting occupant's work, occupant's restoration of public infrastructure, and occupant's maintenance of traffic control devices. The city may increase the inspection fee proportionately for larger excavations. 
(c)  Repair and restoration costs associated with repairing and restoring the public right-of-way because of failure of occupant to correct damage caused by the occupant, its assigns, contractors, and/or subcontractors. 
(Ord. No. 2826, § 7, 11-8-2004) 
Sec. 70-171. - Indemnity. 
(a)  Occupants must indemnify and hold the city and its officers and employees harmless against any and all claims, lawsuits, judgments, costs, liens, losses, expenses, fees (including, but not limited to, reasonable attorney fees and costs of defense), proceedings, actions, demands, causes of action, liability and suits of any kind and nature, including personal or bodily injury (including death), property damage or other harm for which recovery of damages is sought, to the extent that it is found by a court of competent jurisdiction to be caused by the negligence of the occupant, any agent, officer, director, representative, employee, affiliate or subcontractor of the provider, or their respective officers, agents, employees, directors or representatives, while installing, repairing or maintaining facilities in a public right-of-way. 
(b)  The indemnity provided by this subsection does not apply to any liability resulting from the negligence of the city, its officers, employees, contractors or subcontractors. If an occupant and the city should be found jointly liable by a court of competent jurisdiction, liability will be apportioned comparatively in accordance with Kansas law without waiving governmental immunity available to the city under state law and without waiving any other defenses of the parties under state or federal law. 
(c)  This section is solely for the benefit of the city and occupant and does not create or grant any rights, contractual or otherwise, to any other person or entity. 
(Ord. No. 2826, § 1, 11-8-2004) 
Sec. 70-172. - Claim notification. 
    An occupant shall promptly advise the other in writing of any known claim or demand against the provider or the city related to or arising out of the occupant's activities in a public right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 2826, § 1, 11-8-2004) 
Sec. 70-173. - Penalty provision. 
    Any person, firm, corporation, association, utility, or entity, or agent, contractor or subcontractor thereof, violating any provision of this article, shall be guilty of an unclassified violation as defined in section 1-11, and shall upon conviction be subject to the penalties set forth in such section 1-11. Each day of violation shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. 
(Ord. No. 2826, § 1, 11-8-2004) 
Secs. 70-174-70-200. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - STREET PAVING SPECIFICATION AND DESIGN STANDARDS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3105, § 1, adopted June 24, 2013, repealed the former Art. VI, §§ 70-201-70-207, and enacted a new Art. VI as set out herein. The former Art. VI pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 2943, adopted Dec. 17, 2007 and Ord. No. 2959 adopted May 19, 2008. 

Sec. 70-201. - Application. 
    Any person or legal entity desiring to construct any street improvements within the boundaries of the city shall preliminarily apply to the city's department of public works for approval pursuant to the then existing policy and procedures for such improvements. The final application, to consist of construction plans and specifications, a construction cost estimate and a soils testing report, all prepared and stamped by a professional engineer licensed in the State of Kansas, shall be submitted to the city's department of public works for approval. Simultaneously with the filing of the final application, a petition for the improvements prepared in accordance with K.S.A. 12-6a01 et seq. shall be filed with the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 3105, § 1, 6-24-2013) 
Sec. 70-202. - Types of streets affected. 
    The provisions of this article shall govern all of the city's streets, which are defined as follows: 
    Local residential streets. The primary function of which is to provide access to abutting property and movement of local traffic. 
    Collector streets. Streets which provide land access service and traffic circulation within residential neighborhoods and commercial and industrial areas. These streets differ from arterial streets in that collector streets may penetrate residential neighborhoods, distributing trips from arterial streets through the area to their ultimate destination. Collector streets also collect traffic from local streets and residential neighborhoods and channel it into the arterial system. 
    Minor arterial streets. Streets which interconnect with the principal arterial street system. They accommodate trips of moderate length at a somewhat lower level of travel mobility than that of principal arterial streets. 
    Principal arterial streets. Streets on which the nature and composition of travel is unusually significant. They primarily provide through travel service to rural-oriented traffic, but also provide service for major circulation movements within the city's immediate urban area. They serve the major centers of activity, with the highest traffic volume corridors and the longest trip desires, and carry a high proportion of the total urban area travel on minimum mileage. 
    As to any street included in a platted subdivision, the city's planning commission will make a recommendation as to street classification in its consideration of the subdivision plat. Final determination of any street classification will be made by the city's governing body prior to commencement of construction. 
(Ord. No. 3105, § 1, 6-24-2013) 
Sec. 70-203. - Minimum right-of-way and minimum street widths. 
    The minimum right-of-way and minimum street widths for all types of city streets shall be as set from time to time by resolution of the governing body which specifically references this section or corresponding section in the prior city ordinance for standards existing as of the date of the adoption of this article. The city, in its sole and absolute discretion, reserves the right to modify the minimum requirements described in this paragraph on a particular project for good cause after consultation with city professional staff and a majority vote of the city governing body. 
(Ord. No. 3105, § 1, 6-24-2013) 
Sec. 70-204. - Street layout and design. 
    The layout and design of public streets constructed after the effective date of this article, including those which are dedicated but unopened, shall conform to the provisions set forth in this article. 
(Ord. No. 3105, § 1, 6-24-2013) 
Sec. 70-205. - Design criteria. 
    The following minimum design standards shall apply for streets classified as set forth in this article. 
(1)  Pavement construction materials, strengths and methods of construction. Construction materials and methods of construction shall conform to the provisions of the latest Standards of Specifications for State Road and Bridge Construction published by the Kansas Department of Transportation, or supplemental specifications to the project prepared by a professional engineer and approved by the city's director of public works. 
(2)  Minimum pavement design. 
a.  The design engineer shall recommend pavement design thickness based on projected traffic volumes and an anticipated design life as set from time to time by resolution of the governing body which specifically references this ordinance or corresponding section in the prior city ordinance for standards existing as of the date of the adoption of this article. 
b.  A six-inch high standup curb and gutter similar to Kansas Department of Transportation combined curb and gutter Type I shall be required on streets classified as collector or higher. Such curb shall be constructed at the pavement edge to control drainage and provide pavement edge delineation. If conditions warrant, a six-inch high standup curb may be required on lower classification streets. 
c.  Portland cement concrete pavement may be required between curbs where conditions warrant. These areas may include, but are not limited to the following: intersections, approach pavement where vehicles decelerate and stop, approach pavement area to bridges or railroad crossings, or drainage overflow or valley gutter areas. 
(3)  Minimum concrete (Portland cement) pavement thickness. 
1.  Minimum concrete pavement design thickness shall be as set from time to time by resolution of the governing body which specifically references this ordinance or corresponding section in the prior city ordinance for standards existing as of the date of the adoption of this article. 
2.  Concrete mix design shall be submitted to the director of public works for approval in accordance with these standards prior to construction. Admixtures and fly ash are permitted in the concrete with the approval of the public works. 
(4)  Minimum asphalt paving thickness. Minimum asphalt paving design thickness shall be as set from time to time by resolution of the governing body which specifically references this article. 
(5)  Minimum sub-grade compaction. 
a.  Minimum sub-grade compaction shall be as set from time to time by resolution of the governing body which specifically references this article. 
b.  The design engineer's recommendation of sub-grade modification and stabilization, based on soils testing by the developer, must be reviewed and approved by the director of public works. 
(6)  Unique circumstances. The city, in its sole and absolute discretion, reserves the right to modify the requirements described in this section on a particular project for good cause after consultation with city professional staff and a majority vote of the city governing body. 
(Ord. No. 3105, § 1, 6-24-2013) 
Sec. 70-206. - Guarantee and/or warranty. 
    All contractors constructing streets within the city shall furnish to the city as a part of the job specifications and the construction contract a written guarantee or warranty, guaranteeing or warranting the street to be free of all construction defects for a period as set as set from time to time by resolution of the governing body which specifically references this article or corresponding section in the prior city ordinance for standards existing as of the date of the adoption of this article. Such a guarantee or warranty must be in a form acceptable to the city's director of public works and the city attorney, and must be included in the construction contract for the project. 
(Ord. No. 3105, § 1, 6-24-2013) 
Sec. 70-207. - Final approval and acceptance of streets. 
    Acceptance of the street and improvements by the city will not be made until the city has received the written statement of the city's inspecting engineer or other designated inspector that the street has been built according to plans and specifications as approved by the city's director of public works, and recommending that final payment be made to the contractor. Acceptance of the street will be deemed made upon acceptance of the recommendation of the director of public works and approval of final payment by the city's governing body. 
(Ord. No. 3105, § 1, 6-24-2013) 
Sec. 70-208. - Effective date; repealer. 
    This article shall take effect from and after its passage by a majority of the governing body of the city, signature by the mayor and publication of a summary once in the official city newspaper as provided by law. All ordinances and parts of ordinances inconsistent with this ordinance [Ordinance No. 3105] are repealed as of the effective date of this ordinance [Ordinance No. 3105]. 
(Ord. No. 3105, § 1, 6-24-2013)

Chapter 82 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 82-1. - Traffic infractions and offenses. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Ordinance traffic infraction means a violation of any section of this chapter that proscribes or requires the same behavior as that proscribed or required by a statutory provision that is classified as a traffic infraction in K.S.A. 8-2118. All traffic violations which are included within this chapter, and which are not ordinance traffic infractions, shall be considered traffic offenses. 
(b)  Fines. The fine for a violation of an ordinance traffic infraction or any other traffic offense for which the municipal judge establishes a fine in a fine schedule shall not be less than $10.00, nor more than $500.00. A person tried and convicted for a violation of an ordinance traffic infraction or other traffic offense for which a fine has been established in a schedule of fines shall pay a fine fixed by the court, not to exceed $500.00. 
(Code 1995, §§ 16-102, 16-103) 
Sec. 82-2. - Standard traffic ordinance-Adopted. 
    There is hereby incorporated by reference for the purpose of regulating traffic within the corporate limits of the City of McPherson, Kansas, that certain standard traffic ordinance known as the "Standard Traffic Ordinance for Kansas Cities," 2018 Edition, prepared and published in book form by the League of Kansas Municipalities, Topeka, Kansas, except such sections, parts or portions as are hereafter modified or changed. No fewer than three copies of the standard traffic ordinance shall be marked or stamped "Official Copy as Adopted by Ordinance No. 3281," with all sections or portions thereof intended to be changed clearly marked to show such change, and to which shall be attached a copy of this ordinance, and filed with the city clerk to be open to inspection and available to the public at all reasonable hours. The police department, municipal judge and all administrative departments of the city charged with enforcement of the ordinance shall be supplied, at the cost of the city, such number of official copies of the standard traffic ordinance similarly marked, as may be deemed expedient. 
(Code 1995, § 16-101; Ord. No. 2635, § 1, 9-27-1999; Ord. No. 2692, § 1, 12-11-2000; Ord. No. 2707, § 1, 7-2-2001; Ord. No. 2746, § 1, 8-12-2002; Ord. No. 2789, § 1, 9-22-2003; Ord. No. 2819, § 2, 8-30-2004; Ord. No. 2854, § 1, 7-18-2005; Ord. No. 2893, § 1, 9-18-2006; Ord. No. 2967, § 1, 8-25-2008; Ord. No. 2989, § 1, 9-21-2009; Ord. No. 3017, § 1, 8-16-2010; Ord. No. 3039, § 1, 8-29-2011; Ord. No. 3068, § 1, 8-13-2012; Ord. No. 3115, § 1, 8-19-2013; Ord. No. 3119, § 1, 8-26-2013; Ord. No. 3154, § 1, 9-8-2014; Ord. No. 3182, § 1, 8-31-2015; Ord. No. 3227, § 1, 9-26-2016; Ord. No. 3249, § 1, 8-21-2017; Ord. No. 3281, § 1, 8-13-2018) 
State Law reference- Adoption by reference, K.S.A. 12-3009 et seq., 12-3301 et seq. 
Sec. 82-3. - Standard traffic ordinance-Additions and modifications. 
    From and after the effective date of this section, Section 23(b) of the standard traffic ordinance shall read as follows: 
(1)  Total property damages of less than $1,000.00 shall be guilty of a Class C misdemeanor upon conviction; 
(2)  Injury to any person or total property damages in excess or $1,000.00 or more shall be guilty of a Class A person misdemeanor. 
    Further, from and after the effective date of this section, Section 87(a) of the Standard traffic ordinance shall be amended to read as follows: 
Sec. 87. Accessible Parking. 
No person shall stop, stand or park any vehicle in a parking space, whether on public or private property, which is clearly marked as being reserved for the use of persons with a disability or persons responsible for the transportation of persons with a disability unless such vehicle bears a special license plate, permanent placard or temporary placard issued pursuant to K.S.A. 8-161 or K.S.A. 8-1, 125, and amendments thereto, and is being operated by or used for transportation of person with a disability or disabled veteran. In addition to the temporary placard, a person issued such temporary placard shall carry the state or county receipt showing the name of the person who is issued such temporary placard. If a parking space on private property is clearly marked as being reserved for the use of a specified person with a disability it shall be unlawful for any other person to park in such space. As used in this Section 87(a), "clearly marked" shall require a vertical sign post with a handicapped parking sign attached and no merely painted handicap markings on the ground. 
    Further, from and after the effective date of this section, Section 87(e) of the standard traffic ordinance shall contain a further subsection (4) which shall read as follows: 
(4)  In any action prosecuted for violation of subsection (e)(1) of this section, it shall not be a defense that the parking space in which the alleged violator has parked was not properly designated as an accessible parking space as stated in subsection (d) of this section, as long as the parking space has been reasonably identified as an accessible parking space by the marking in or about such space of the international symbol of access. 
    Further, from and after the effective date of this section, Section 88 of the standard traffic ordinance shall read as follows: 
Parking for Certain Purposes Prohibited. 
No person shall park a vehicle upon any roadway or city-owned parking lot for a principal purpose of either: 
(a)  Displaying such vehicle for sale. 
(1)  For the purposes of this subsection, either of the following conditions shall raise the presumption that a principal purpose the vehicle was parked was to sell the vehicle: 
a.  The vehicle is not currently registered or tagged pursuant to K.S.A. 8-126 through K.S.A. 8-149, inclusive; or 
b.  The vehicle is tagged with a dealer's tag pursuant to K.S.A. 8-136 and has any markings or signs directly or indirectly indicating that the vehicle is for sale. 
Or 
Washing, greasing or repairing such vehicle except repairs necessitated by emergency and except to the extent that the vehicle is moved the same day to an appropriate location for such washing, greasing or repair. 
    Further, from and after the effective date of this section, Section 89 of the standard traffic ordinance shall be deleted in its entirety and in its place the following inserted: 
Sec. 89. Stall Parking. 
Where parking stalls or spaces are marked or designated on the pavement or curb, vehicles shall be parked or stopped within such stalls or spaces in direction of the flow of traffic or at the angle indicated by the markings, except a motorcycle shall park so that motorcycle's back wheel touches or is next to curb or curb line. 
    Further, from and after the effective date of this section, the provisions of Section 109.1 of the standard traffic ordinance pertaining to motorized skateboards shall not be applicable. 
    Further, from and after the effective date of this section, the provisions of Section 114.1 of the standard traffic ordinance shall be amended to read as follows: 
Unlawful operation of all-terrain vehicles. 
(a)  Except as provided in subsection (b), it shall be unlawful for any person to operate an all-terrain vehicle within the corporate limits of the City of McPherson. 
(b)  Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (a), all-terrain vehicles owned and operated by any unit or agency of state or local government (including the McPherson Recreation Commission and Unified School District No. 418, McPherson County, Kansas) may operate such all-terrain vehicles within the City of McPherson. 
(c)  No all-terrain vehicle shall be operated on any public highway, street or road between sunset and sunrise unless equipped with lights as required by law for motorcycles. 
    Further, from and after the effective date of this section, the provisions of Section 114.4 of the standard traffic ordinance shall be amended to read as follows: 
Unlawful operation of a golf cart. 
(d)  Notwithstanding the provisions of this Section 114.4, any golf cart owned or operated by any unit or agency of state or local government (including the McPherson Recreation Commission and Unified School District No. 418, McPherson County, Kansas) may operate such golf carts within the City of McPherson. Any such golf cart operated on any public highway, street or road between sunset and sunrise unless equipped with lights are required by law for motorcycles. 
    Further, from and after the effective date of this section, Section 116 of the standard traffic ordinance, shall be amended to read as follows: 
Section 116. Driving Upon Sidewalk. No personal shall drive any vehicle upon a sidewalk or sidewalk area, except: 
(a)  Upon a permanent or duly authorized temporary driveway; or 
(b)  On a bicycle, skateboard, tricycle, or other human-powered conveyances on public sidewalks not included in the B-3 Central Business District as defined by the City's zoning regulations except: 
(1)  Bicycles and tricycles are not required to use sidewalks; and 
(2)  Pedestrians shall have the full right-of-way. 
    Further, from and after the effective date of this section, persons operating roller skates or inline skates upon a roadway shall be subject to the requirements of Sections 128, 191 and 133(a) of the standard traffic ordinance otherwise applicable to bicycles. 
    Further, from and after the effective date of this section, Section 136 of the standard traffic ordinance shall not apply to roller stakes (including inline roller stakes) if operated by persons age 12 or over, or under age 12 if accompanied by a person at least age 18. 
(b)  Any person violating subsections (1), (2), or (3) shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $2,500, or by imprisonment for no more than six months, or by both such fine and imprisonment. Any person violating subsection (4) or (5) shall be punished as provided in section 201(d) of this ordinance. 
    Further, from and after the effective date of this section, Section 198 of the standard traffic ordinance is deleted in its entirety and in its place the following is added: 
(b)  Any person violating subsections (1), (2), or (3) shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $2,500, or by imprisonment for not more than six months, or by both such fine and imprisonment. Any person violating subsections (4) or (5) shall be punished as provided in section 201(d) of this Ordinance. (K.S.A. Supp. 8-142; K.S.A. 8-149) 
    Further, from and after the effective date of this section, Section 200(e) of the standard traffic ordinance shall read as follows: 
(e)  Unless the insurance company subsequently submits an insurance verification form indicating that insurance was not in force, no person charged with violating subsections (a), (b), (c) or (d) shall be convicted if such person produces in court, within 10 days of the date of arrest or of issuance of the citation, evidence of financial security for the motor vehicle operated, which was valid at the time of arrest or of issuance of the citation. Such evidence of financial security may be produced by displaying such information on a cellular phone or any other type of portable electronic device. Any person to whom such evidence of financial security is displayed on a cellular phone or any other type of portable electronic device shall be prohibited from viewing any other content or information stored on such cellular phone or other type of portable electronic device. For the purpose of this subsection evidence of financial security shall be provided by a policy of motor vehicle liability insurance, an identification card or certificate of insurance issued to the policyholder by the insurer which provides the name of the insurer, the policy number and the effective and expiration dates of the policy or a certificate of self-insurance signed by the commissioner of insurance. 
    Further, from and after the effective date this section, Section 201(e) of the standard traffic ordinance shall be added to read as follows: 
The fine for any violation of Standard Traffic Ordinance N. 85 or No. 86 shall be fifteen dollars ($15.00) without court costs. 
(Code 1995, § 16-104; Ord. No. 2635, § 2, 9-27-1999; Ord. No. 2692, § 2, 12-11-2000; Ord. No. 2707, § 2, 7-2-2001; Ord. No. 2746, § 2, 8-12-2002; Ord. No. 2789, § 2, 9-22-2003; Ord.
