ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Sec. 82-31. - Authority of chief of police. 
(a)  In accordance with the provisions of K.S.A. 8-2008, the chief of police, with the approval of the governing body, is hereby authorized to: 
(1)  Erect stop signs or yield signs at specified entrances to through highways; 
(2)  Designate any intersection as a stop intersection or yield intersection and erect stop signs or yield signs at one or more entrances to such intersection; 
(3)  Establish one-way streets, no parking zones, speed zones, angle parking areas and erect appropriate traffic signs at such locations as he shall determine. 
(b)  The chief of police is hereby authorized to designate any zone or portion of a street as a school zone or no passing zone and to place appropriate signs on or near the street to indicate such designation when such action is necessary for public safety. 
(c)  The chief of police is hereby authorized to provide proper signs and signals, and such other devices so as to conform to the Uniform Traffic Manual as he may deem necessary for the regulation and control of traffic over and along the public streets in front of, or near, parks and schools. 
(Code 1995, §§ 16-201, 16-202) 
Cross reference- Appointed officers and employees generally, § 2-81 et seq.; police department, § 2-161 et seq. 
Sec. 82-32. - Use of skateboards, roller skates or roller blades on sidewalks. 
(a)  No person shall ride any skateboard or propel himself or herself on roller skates or roller blades in the central business district of the city, on the sidewalk in front of any business premises, or on any public street, alley, sidewalk, plaza, drainage canal or other public property which has been posted to prohibit such activity, except to gain access to an immediately abutting premises to conduct business on such premises. For the purpose of this section "central business district" shall have the meaning defined in section 16-501(d) of this code. In other areas, where riding or operation of such wheeled devices on the sidewalk is not prohibited, pedestrians shall have the right-of-way to use the sidewalks for pedestrian travel. 
(b)  A violation of this section of the code shall be punishable by a fine of not less than $10 and not more than $100 and restitution of any damages. The chief of police may impound any such wheeled device ridden or operated in violation of this section pending final disposition of the violation. 
(Code 1995, § 12-243; Ord. No. 2794, § 1, 10-14-2003) 
Sec. 82-33. - Bank of America Plaza. 
    No person shall ride or propel himself in any manner on any bicycle, roller skates, inline roller skates, coaster or skateboard on the Bank of America Plaza that is located on the northwest corner of the intersection of Main Street and Marlin Street in the city, on land legally described as lots 11 and 12, and the south 5.4 feet of lot 10 in block 55, O.T.S., or on the public sidewalks adjoining such plaza. For the purposes of this section, the term "bicycle" shall have the meaning defined in section 82-141. The chief of police may impound any such conveyance ridden or operated in violation of this section, pending final disposition of the violation. 
(Code 1995, § 13-714; Ord. No. 2640, § 1, 10-18-1999) 
Sec. 82-34. - Operation of motorized scooters. 
(a)  Definition. As used in this ordinance the following term has the following meaning: 
    Motorized scooter means every motor vehicle that is a two-or three-wheeled device that has handlebars, is designed to be stood or sat upon by the operator, and is powered by an engine or electric motor that is capable of propelling the device with or without human propulsion, as follows: 
(1)  If the power source is a combustion engine, such engine has a piston or rotor displacement of 35 cubic centimeters or less regardless, of the number of chambers in the power source; or 
(2)  If the power source is electric, such motor has a power output of not more than 1,000 watts. 
The term "motorized scooter" shall not include motorized bicycles, motorcycles, motor-driven cycles, low-powered cycles or motorized wheelchairs as defined in the Standard Traffic Ordinance. 
(b)  Operation of motorized scooters. 
(1)  Every person operating a motorized scooter shall do so only in compliance with the provisions of Sections 127 to 133, inclusive, of the Standard Traffic Ordinance as adopted from time to time by the governing body of the City, insofar as such provisions apply to such vehicles. 
(2)  Notwithstanding any other provision of law, motorized scooters shall not be operated on any property within the city that is clearly and visibly marked by a sign or signs indicating that motorized scooters are prohibited thereon. A sign or signs generally prohibiting operation of bicycles, skateboards or in-line skates shall automatically apply to motorized scooters. Placement of any such sign on privately-owned property shall constitute authorization for the police department to enforce the provisions of this section upon such property. 
(c)  Certain operation of motorized scooters prohibited. No person shall: 
(1)  Operate a motorized scooter upon a public street or parking lot in any contest of speed or exhibition of acceleration; 
(2)  Operate a motorized scooter upon a public street or parking lot which has an exhaust system or drive spindle modified from the manufacturer's original equipment; 
(3)  Operate a gasoline-powered motorized scooter upon a public street or parking lot unless it has a functioning muffler complying with Section 175 of the Standard Traffic Ordinance as adopted from time to time by the governing body of the city. 
(d)  Impoundment. Law enforcement officers are authorized to impound any motorized scooter that the officer determines to have been used in violation of this ordinance. A motorized scooter impounded under this provision may only be released to the owner, or in the case of a violator who is under 18 years of age, the parent or guardian of the violator, upon proof of ownership and payment of an impound administrative fee. 
(e)  Registration. All motorized scooters shall be registered with the police department within 30 days of the date of purchase or acquisition and display a valid registration decal affixed in a conspicuous place on the frame. Registration shall be accomplished on a form provided therefore by the police department, which form shall require such information as the chief of police deems appropriate to identify the vehicle so registered. The registration fee for a motorized scooter shall be as determined by the chief of police. Registration of motorized scooters shall be non-transferable. 
(f)  Violations of ordinance; fines. It is unlawful for any person to violate any of the provisions of this ordinance. Penalties and fines for violation shall be assessed in the manner set forth in Section 201 of the Standard Traffic Ordinance as adopted from time to time by the governing body of the city. Any police officer finding a minor under the age of 14 violating the provisions of this section shall issue a written warning to such minor and given written notice of the violation, setting forth the nature of the violation, to such minor's parent or guardian. All persons who are above the age of 14 found to be in violation of this ordinance shall be issued a notice to appear for the violation and it to be filed in the municipal court of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2804, §§ 1-6, 1-26-2004) 
Secs. 82-35-82-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - GENERAL RULES OF VEHICLE OPERATION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Speed limits in parks, § 58-93; driving on grass in parks, § 58-94. 
State Law reference- Rules of the road, K.S.A. 8-1501 et seq. 

Sec. 82-61. - Speed limit in school zones. 
    The maximum speed limit when passing through any public or parochial school zone commencing one-half hour before school is in session and ending one-half hour after school is dismissed is 20 miles per hour. 
(Code 1995, § 16-202) 
Cross reference- Zoning, ch. 94. 
State Law reference- Authority to fix speed limit in school zones, K.S.A. 8-1560(a)(4). 
Sec. 82-62. - Careless driving. 
    Every person operating a vehicle within the city shall drive such vehicle in a careful and prudent manner, having regard for the widths, grades, curves, corners, traffic, surfaces, uses and other attendant circumstances of the city's streets or roads, so as not to endanger the safety of persons or property. Failure to drive in such a manner shall constitute careless driving, which is hereby declared to be unlawful. 
(Code 1995, § 16-209) 
State Law reference- Reckless driving, K.S.A. 8-1566. 
Sec. 82-63. - Through streets. 
    Through streets in the city shall be designated as follows: 
(1)  Main Street; 
(2)  Avenue A; 
(3)  First Street; 
(4)  Euclid Street; 
(5)  Kansas Avenue. 
(Code 1995, § 16-207) 
State Law reference- Authority to designate through streets, K.S.A. 8-2002(a)(6); stop signs and yield signs, K.S.A. 8-1528. 
Sec. 82-64. - Driving through processions. 
    See Standard Traffic Ordinance for Kansas Cities (adopted by section 82-2), § 120. 
(Code 1995, § 16-208) 
Sec. 82-65. - Weight limit on Avenue A. 
(a)  Established. It shall be unlawful for any person to drive or move, or for the owner or lessee to cause or knowingly permit to be driven or moved, on Avenue A within the corporate limits of the city, any vehicle or combination of vehicles in excess of 65,000 pounds gross weight. 
(b)  Violations. 
(1)  Any person violating the provisions of this section shall, upon a first conviction, be fined an amount equal to the amount determined by applying the following schedule for each pound in excess of the lawful limit: 
Pounds Overweight Rate of Fine Up to 1,000 $25.00 1,001-2,000  0.03 per pound 2,001-5,000  0.05 per pound 5,001-7,500  0.07 per pound 7,501 and over  0.10 per pound  
a.  For a second violation of this section within two years after a prior conviction, such person, upon conviction, shall be fined 11/2 times the applicable amount. 
b.  For a fourth and each succeeding violation of this section within two years and after three prior convictions, such person, upon conviction, shall be fined 21/2 times the applicable amount. 
(c)  Signs. The city department of public works shall prepare appropriate traffic signs showing the weight limits and place such signs at the entrances of the city and other common entrances onto Avenue A, as directed by the governing body. 
(Ord. No. 2618, §§ 1, 2, 4-19-1999) 
State Law reference- Weight limits authorized, K.S.A. 8-1912. 
Sec. 82-66. - Overweight vehicles prohibited on certain streets. 
(a)  Definition. The term "overweight vehicles," when used in this section, means any vehicle, whether loaded or unloaded, with a registered gross weight in excess of 12,000 pounds. 
(b)  Exemptions. All vehicles registered to, or leased by, a unit of local government or school district are exempt from the restrictions set forth in this section. 
(c)  Restrictions. Overweight vehicles shall not be permitted to travel upon the following streets within the city: 
East and West Lakeside Drive 
Eastmoor Drive, Lyndon Road and Glendale road as platted in Eastmoor Addition 
(d)  Signing. The city shall place signs on the restricted streets to notify the public of the restrictions provided for in this section in the following manner: VEHICLES OVER 12M PROHIBITED. 
(e)  Violation. Violation of this section shall be deemed an ordinance traffic infraction, subject to a fine of not more than $500.00 and other civil remedy as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 2762, 12-9-2002; Ord. No. 2768, 3-17-2003) 
Secs. 82-67-82-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Use of streets or parking for private purposes, § 70-1; parking restrictions for bicycles, § 82-147. 
State Law reference- Stopping, standing and parking generally, K.S.A. 8-1569 et seq.; authority to regulate or prohibit stopping, standing or parking, K.S.A. 8-2002(a)(1). 

Sec. 82-101. - Removal of illegally parked trailers. 
    If a trailer or semitrailer is found parked in violation of the provisions of this article, the fire chief, assistant fire chief or any police officer may require the owner or lessee of the trailer or semitrailer to move it within two hours. If such removal is not accomplished on the order of any such officer, such removal may be accomplished by any such officer, by any reasonable means, if the continued presence of the trailer or semitrailer at its parked location constitutes, adds to or prevents correction of a situation threatening imminent injury or damage to persons or property. 
(Code 1995, § 16-305) 
Cross reference- Manufactured homes and trailers, ch. 42. 
Sec. 82-102. - Limited parking restrictions. 
(a)  The chief of police is authorized to prohibit or limit the stopping, standing or parking of vehicles on any street, alley or parking lot subject to city traffic regulations, where deemed necessary, and in doing so, may designate zones or places where drivers shall not park, stand or stop any vehicle at any time or during specified times, or places where certain drivers shall not park, stand or stop their vehicles during such limited times or specified times. When signs are erected prohibiting or limiting the parking, standing or stopping of a vehicle on any street, alley or regulated parking lot, no person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle in such designated place in violation of any such sign. 
(b)  Limited or restricted parking zones designated pursuant to this section shall be graphically illustrated on maps to be kept on file in the offices of the chief of police and the department of public works. Prior to taking effect, such maps shall be approved by the governing body of the city. 
(c)  Limited parking zones designated pursuant to this section may be amended from time to time by order of the chief of police, with the approval of the governing body. Temporary amendments may be made upon the order of the chief of police. If a temporary amendment is made, the police department shall remark the parking zone temporarily changed and give the department of public works written notice of the change. The temporary amendment shall be effective for not to exceed one year from the date notice is given. 
(d)  Any person parking in violation of the limited parking restrictions in a zone designated pursuant to this section shall be guilty of a violation of the provisions of the Standard Traffic Ordinance for Kansas Cities currently in effect in the city, entitled "Stopping, Standing or Parking Prohibited in Specified Places," and shall be subject to the same penalties as are prescribed in the standard traffic ordinance for a violation of such section. 
(Ord. No. 2392, § 1(16-301, 16-306, 16-307, 16-309), 8-31-1992) 
Sec. 82-103. - Parking more than 48 hours. 
(a)  Except for a vehicle with a valid permit parked in a designated space of a designated parking lot under the city's central business district residential parking permit program, it shall be unlawful for any person to park, store or leave standing any motor vehicle upon the public streets, parkings, sidewalks, parks or other property of the city for any continuous period of more than 48 hours, and any motor vehicle which shall be found to have remained parked, stored or left standing upon any of the public streets, parkings, sidewalks, parks or other property in the city for a continuous period of more than 48 hours shall be deemed a public nuisance, to be abated in the manner provided in this section. In addition to being declared a public nuisance, the owner of such vehicle shall be guilty of a violation of the provisions of the standard traffic ordinance for Kansas Cities currently in effect in the city, entitled "Stopping, Standing or Parking Prohibited in Specified Places," and shall be subject to the same penalties as are prescribed in the standard traffic ordinance for a violation of such section. 
(b)  The city marshal, chief of police or any member of the police department acting upon authority of the chief of police shall diligently inquire as to the ownership of such vehicle as described in subsection (a) of this section, and if the ownership or person in charge or control of the motor vehicle cannot be located, shall cause a notice to the person in whose name the vehicle is registered to be published in the official city paper, which notice shall describe the make and model of the vehicle, together with the engine, serial and license numbers appearing thereon, and the location where the motor vehicle was unlawfully parked, stored or left standing and advising such person that the motor vehicle has been removed from the public street, parking, sidewalk, park or other public property as a means of abating the nuisance. 
(c)  Prior to the publication of the notice, the chief of police or a member of the police department acting under direction of the chief of police shall cause the motor vehicle to be removed from the public street, parking, sidewalk, park or other public property to any garage or other location within the city which the chief of police may designate. Unless the motor vehicle shall be claimed or redeemed by the owner within 30 days from the date of the first publication of the notice as provided for in subsection (b) of this section, the vehicle shall be sold by the city at public sale for the purpose of paying the storage, towing and publication charges, at a time and place to be stated in the publication notice, and the proceeds from the sale shall be paid to the general fund of the city, after having first deducted the costs of storage, towing and publication. All such publication notices shall be published twice in the official city newspaper, at least three days, and not more than seven days, apart. 
(Code 1995, §§ 16-401-16-403; Ord. No. 3028, § 1, 2-7-2011) 
Sec. 82-104. - Parking buses, trucks, tractors., etc., more than two hours in residential districts. 
    It shall be unlawful to park a truck with a manufacturer's rated capacity of over three-quarter ton, or a bus, truck tractor, road tractor, farm tractor, trailer, semitrailer, boat, boat trailer or camper trailer on any street in a residential district for a period of time longer than two hours, except that parking for a period of time longer than two hours is permitted when it is necessary for the loading or unloading of merchandise and a permit, issued by the police department, authorizing such parking is in possession of the operator or in the vehicle at the time the vehicle is parked for a period of time over two hours. Permits shall be issued for each time that over-parking is necessary. Such a permit shall be only upon a showing that traffic will not be obstructed or public safety endangered. 
(Code 1995, § 16-204) 
Sec. 82-105. - Unattended vehicles. 
    See Standard Traffic Ordinance for Kansas Cities (adopted by section 82-2), § 90 et seq. 
(Code 1995, § 16-203) 
Sec. 82-106. - Night parking on Main Street. 
    No person shall park a vehicle on Main Street between the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway Company tracks (Simpson Street) and Sutherland Street from 3:00 a.m. to 5:00 a.m. on any day. 
(Code 1995, § 16-205) 
Sec. 82-107. - Parked vehicle length limited on Main Street. 
    No vehicle with an overall length of more than 20 feet shall be permitted to park on Main Street or within one block east or west on any street intersecting Main Street between Skancke Street and Hill Street. 
(Code 1995, § 16-206) 
Sec. 82-108. - City owned vehicles. 
(a)  All city owned vehicles shall be marked with a decal at least eight inches in diameter and in colors sufficiently bright and conspicuously placed so that a citizen can easily identify such city owned vehicles, provided that police cars for use in undercover work may be exempt from such requirement by the chief of police and approved by the mayor of the city. 
(b)  Any city employee who willfully drives a city owned vehicle upon any road, street or highway in violation of the provisions of subsection (a) of this section shall be considered to be insubordinate and subject to disciplinary action as specified in the employees' manual and K.S.A. ch. 8, art. 3. 
(Code 1995, § 16-211) 
Sec. 82-109. - Central business district parking permit program. 
    There is hereby created a central business district parking permit program to permit eligible residents the permission for extended and overnight parking in designated locations within or near the central business district if the vehicle is validly permitted pursuant to this program. 
(1)  Parking permits shall be issued by the city clerk only to individuals showing proof of residency in the central business district. "Central business district" shall be defined as that area identified as the central business district in the zoning regulations of the City of McPherson. 
(2)  Permit applicants shall submit an application, permit fee, and present a current driver's license showing proof of residence in the central business district to the city clerk. 
(3)  The annual nonrefundable cost for each permit, new or replacement, shall be set by the governing body from time to time by resolution. Worn, damaged or unusable stickers shall be replaced to remain valid. If a permitted vehicle is replaced, a new sticker must be acquired and the permit holder shall notify the clerk of a vehicle change and a new sticker will be issued at a replacement cost. The permit fees shall not be prorated for partial years. 
(4)  Only one permit shall be issued for each licensed driver residing in the central business district. Each permit issued will cover one specified vehicle. 
(5)  All permits shall expire on December 31 of each year. New permit stickers shall be issued annually to renewing permit holders. Permits stickers will be different in appearance each year. 
(Ord. No. 3027, § 1, 2-7-2011) 
Sec. 82-110. - Designated areas. 
    A permit holder is entitled to park a permitted vehicle in designated spaces of designated parking lots located in and near the central business district. The city will designate such spaces and lots from time to time by resolution and display appropriate signage in such lots. The city clerk shall provide permit holders a copy of the resolution in effect at the time the permit is issued showing the designated spaces in the designated parking lots. The use of such spaces is non-exclusive with non-permit holders except during the hours of 3:00 a.m. to 5:00 a.m. In the event more significant maintenance is required on any designated parking lot, permit holder will be notified by e-mail or by letter of any temporary lot closures. The governing body may alter or amend the designated spaces and designated lots from time to time by resolution and all current permit holders shall be mailed, by regular first class mail at the address shown on the most recent permit application, a copy of such resolution. 
(Ord. No. 3027, § 1, 2-7-2011) 
Sec. 82-111. - Display of permit. 
    Permit stickers must be clearly displayed either on the rear window in the lower passenger's side corner of the permitted vehicle. Vehicles not clearly displaying a current permit sticker will be ticketed and be subject to removal and impoundment. 
(Ord. No. 3027, § 1, 2-7-2011) 
Sec. 82-112. - Other applicable requirements. 
    All vehicles tagged with permits shall be operable and roadworthy vehicles and shall be subject to the same requirements of all other vehicles parked in on-street authorized parking spaces. No permit shall be issued for a vehicle with an overall length of more than 20 feet. 
(Ord. No. 3027, § 1, 2-7-2011) 
Sec. 82-113. - Parking in front or side lawns prohibited. 
    Except for allowable off-street parking, as defined, no person shall park any motor vehicle, as defined by the standard traffic ordinances as adopted from time to time, on a front yard or side yard of a residential property as such terms are defined in the city's zoning regulations except temporarily to load or unload property or by a licensed contractor actively engaged in work on the property. 
    For purposes of this section, allowable off-street parking shall require a city approved curb-cut and a concrete entrance the length of the allowed curb-cut on the street and the full width of the distance from the curb-cut to the inside edge of the right-of-way. For residences constructed prior to January 1, 2015, the curb-cut and entrance requirements do not have to be completed until January 1, 2016. The remainder of the driveway and parking area shall be: 
(1)  For residences constructed or reconstructed on or after January 1, 2015, a paved surface complying with section 5-100(A)(5)(b) of the city's zoning regulations; or 
(2)  For residences constructed prior to January 1, 2015, either a paved surface complying with the requirements of (1) above or gravel or clean asphalt millings approved as to type, depth and compaction by the city's public works director. 
    A person convicted of a violation of this section shall pay a fine of $100.00 plus court costs for the first offense within a calendar year; $200.00 plus court costs for a second offense within a calendar year; $300.00 plus court costs for a third offense within a calendar year; $400.00 plus court costs for a fourth offense within a calendar year; and $500.00 plus court costs for five or more offenses within a calendar year. 
(Ord. No. 3161, § 1, 12-8-2014) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3161, § 1, adopted Dec. 8, 2014, set out provisions intended for use as § 82-109. To preserve the existing § 82-109, and at the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included herein as § 82-113. 
Sec. 82-114. - Parking on handicap ramps prohibited. 
    Except when in compliance with laws or the direction of a police officer or official traffic-control device, no person shall park any vehicle or drive any vehicle upon any handicap ramp or access ramp in the City of McPherson, Kansas. The sentence for any violation of this section shall be the same penalty as provided herein for a class C violation of the uniform public offense code as adopted from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 3161, § 2, 12-8-2014) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3161, § 2, adopted Dec. 8, 2014, set out provisions intended for use as § 82-110. To preserve the existing § 82-110, and at the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included herein as § 82-114. 
Sec. 82-115. - Business vehicles. 
    The owner of property in the central business district may apply for up to two parking permits per business. The permits shall not cover trailers or vehicles used primarily for storage. The owner may assign the right to such permits in writing to a commercial tenant of the qualifying property. The permits shall restrict overnight parking to specific lots that may be more limited than residential permits and unless specifically waived by the governing body, any permitted vehicle must fit within the marked parking space. In addition, the governing body may add such additional conditions on specific commercial permits as deemed reasonable by the governing body. The governing body shall set the permit fee for business vehicles including an additional fee for extra-large vehicles, from time to time by resolution. 
(Ord. No. 3236, § 1, 2-20-2017) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3236, § 1, adopted Feb. 20, 2017, set out provisions for use as § 82-113. Inasmuch as there were already provisions so designated, said section has been codified herein as § 82-115 at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 82-116-82-140. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - BICYCLES[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Operation of bicycles and play vehicles, K.S.A. 8-1586 et seq.; authority to regulate operation of bicycles, K.S.A. 8-2002(a)(8). 

Sec. 82-141. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Bicycle means every device propelled by human power, upon which any person may ride, having two tandem wheels, either of which is more than 14 inches in diameter. 
    Bike lane means a clearly marked lane on the side of a street or road, separated from automobiles by a painted stripe or raised divider. 
    Bike path means a path or road especially for bicycles and that is physically separated from vehicular traffic. 
    Central business district means all of that area lying between the north side of Simpson Street south to the south side of Sutherland Street, and from the west side of Maple Street east to the east side of Ash Street. 
(Code 1995, § 16-501) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 82-142. - Applicability. 
    The regulations of this article applicable to bicycles shall apply whenever a bicycle is operated upon any street, roadway, highway or any public path set aside for the exclusive use of pedestrian and bicycle traffic, and shall also include all public parks and playgrounds or other property under the ownership, jurisdiction or control of the city, the park board of the city or any other agency created to provide a public service in, or adjacent to, the city. 
(Code 1995, § 16-502) 
Sec. 82-143. - Operating police bicycles. 
(a)  Uniformed officers of the city's police department, when operating a bicycle while on duty, shall be deemed to be operating a police bicycle for purposes of this section. 
(b)  When necessary, and in the performance of their duties while operating a police bicycle, any city police officer is exempt from any of the regulations of this article regarding parking or standing, operating a bicycle on a sidewalk in the central business district, direction of movement or travel on city streets or alleys, or turns. These provisions shall not be construed to relieve the rider of any police bicycle from a duty to ride with due regard for the safety of all persons, nor shall such provisions protect the rider from the consequences of the rider's reckless disregard for the safety of others. 
(Ord. No. 2595, § 1(16-511, 16-512), 8-31-1998) 
Cross reference- Police department, § 2-161 et seq. 
Sec. 82-144. - Lamps and reflectors at night. 
    See Standard Traffic Ordinance for Kansas Cities (adopted by section 82-2), § 133. 
(Code 1995, § 16-504) 
Sec. 82-145. - Yielding right-of-way on sidewalks. 
    Whenever a bicycle is ridden in the sidewalk area outside the central business district, the operator of the bicycle shall yield the right-of-way to all pedestrians on the sidewalk or in the sidewalk area. 
(Code 1995, § 16-505) 
Sec. 82-146. - Riding on sidewalks. 
    No person shall ride any bicycle upon the sidewalks in the central business district of the city. A violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine of not less than $10.00, nor more than $100.00, and restitution of any damages caused. The chief of police may impound any such bicycle ridden or operated in violation of this section, pending final disposition of the violation. 
(Code 1995, § 16-510) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 70. 
Sec. 82-147. - Parking restrictions. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park or leave a bicycle on any street, alley, sidewalk or other public place in the central business district of the city, unless such bicycle is parked in a bicycle rack or is within an area designated for parking bicycles. 
(b)  Bicycle racks and areas designated for parking bicycles in the central business district of the city shall not be located on any street, sidewalk or other public property without prior approval of the chief of police. 
(c)  The police department shall be authorized to remove any bicycle that is unlawfully parked or left within the city and shall further be authorized to remove any bicycle left or parked on public property where that bicycle blocks pedestrian travel or presents a traffic hazard. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for a person to refuse to remove a bicycle that has been parked or left on public property upon the request of a police officer, and a police officer shall have the authority to remove a bicycle that is parked or left on public property if the person in control or possession of such bicycle refuses to do so. 
(e)  Whenever a bicycle shall have been impounded for a period of 90 days and no claim of ownership or the right to possession thereof shall have been made and established to the satisfaction of the police department, such bicycle may be sold at public auction, after legal publication of the time, date and location of such sale, or may be donated to the McPherson Police Department's Bicycle Recycle Program, or may be disposed of in any other method at the sole discretion of the chief of police. 
(Code 1995, §§ 16-506-16-509; Ord. No. 3238, § 1, 3-27-2017) 
Cross reference- Stopping, standing and parking, § 82-101 et seq.

ARTICLE II. - WATER SYSTEM[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Water service and connections, § 18-619. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 86-31-86-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - WATER SHORTAGES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Emergency management, ch. 30. 

Sec. 86-51. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Board of public utilities (BPU) means the city's board of public utilities, having jurisdiction and control over the city's water production, storage and distribution system. 
    Classes of uses of water include the following: 
(1)  Class 1 includes water used for outdoor watering, either public or private, gardens, lawns, trees, shrubs, plants, parks, golf courses, playing fields, swimming pools or other recreational areas, or the washing of motor vehicles, boats, trailers or the exterior of any building or structure. 
(2)  Class 2 includes water used for any commercial or industrial purpose, including agricultural, except water actually necessary to maintain the health and personal hygiene of bona fide employees while such employees are engaged in the performance of their duties at their place of employment. 
(3)  Class 3 includes domestic usage of water, other than that which would be included in either class 1 or 2. 
(4)  Class 4 includes water necessary only to sustain human life and the lives of domestic pets, and maintain standards of hygiene and sanitation. 
    Customer means the customer of record using water for any purpose from the city's water distribution system and for which either a regular charge is made or, in the case of coin sales, a cash charge is made at the site of delivery. 
    Waste of water includes, but is not limited to: 
(1)  Permitting water to escape down a gutter, ditch or other surface drain; or 
(2)  Failure to repair a controllable leak of water due to defective plumbing. 
    Water means water available to the city for treatment by virtue of its water rights or any treated water introduced by the utility into its water distribution system, including water offered for sale at any coin-operated site. 
(Ord. No. 2680, § 2, 8-21-2000) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 86-52. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this division is to provide for the declaration of a water supply watch, warning or emergency and the implementation of voluntary and mandatory water conservation measures throughout the city if such a watch, warning or emergency is declared. 
(Ord. No. 2680, § 1, 8-21-2000) 
Sec. 86-53. - Declaration of water watch. 
    Whenever the governing body of the board of public utilities finds that conditions indicate that the probability of a drought or some other condition causing a major water supply shortage is rising, it shall be empowered to declare by resolution that a water watch exists and that it shall take steps to inform the public and ask for voluntary reductions in water use. Such a watch shall be deemed to continue until it is declared by resolution of the governing body to have ended. The resolutions declaring the existence and end of a water watch shall be effective upon the publication of such resolutions once in the official city newspaper. 
(Ord. No. 2680, § 3, 8-21-2000) 
Sec. 86-54. - Declaration of water warning. 
    Whenever the governing body of the board of public utilities finds that drought conditions or some other condition causing a major water supply shortage are present and supplies are starting to decline, it shall be empowered to declare by resolution that a water warning exists and that it will recommend restrictions on nonessential uses during the period of such warning. Such a warning shall be deemed to continue until it is declared by resolution of the governing body to have ended. The resolutions declaring the beginning and ending of the water warning shall be effective upon the publication of such resolutions once in the official city newspaper. 
(Ord. No. 2680, § 4, 8-21-2000) 
Sec. 86-55. - Declaration of water emergency. 
    Whenever the governing body of the board of public utilities finds that an emergency exists by reason of a shortage of water supply needed for essential uses, it shall be empowered to declare by resolution that a water supply emergency exists and that it will impose mandatory restrictions on water use during the period of emergency. Such an emergency shall be deemed to continue until it is declared by resolution of the governing body to have ended. The resolutions declaring the existence and end of a water supply emergency shall be effective upon the publication of such resolutions once in the official city newspaper. 
(Ord. No. 2680, § 5, 8-21-2000) 
Sec. 86-56. - Voluntary conservation measures. 
    Upon the declaration of a water watch or water warning as provided in sections 86-53 and 86-54, the general manager of the BPU or his designated agent is authorized to call on all water consumers to employ voluntary water conservation measures to limit or eliminate nonessential water uses, including, but not limited to, limitations on the following uses: 
(1)  Sprinkling of water on lawns, shrubs or trees, including golf courses supplied with water by the BPU. 
(2)  Washing of automobiles. 
(3)  Use of water in swimming pools, fountains and evaporative air conditioning systems. 
(4)  Waste of water. 
(Ord. No. 2680, § 6, 8-21-2000) 
Sec. 86-57. - Mandatory conservation measures. 
    Upon the declaration of a water supply emergency as provided in section 86-55, the general manager of the BPU is also authorized to implement certain mandatory water conservation measures, including, but not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Suspension of new connections to the city's water distribution system, except connections of fire hydrants and those made pursuant to agreements entered into by the BPU prior to the effective date of the declaration of the emergency; 
(2)  Restrictions on the uses of water in one or more classes of water use, wholly or in part; 
(3)  Restrictions on the sales of water at coin-operated facilities or sites; 
(4)  Imposition of water rationing based on any reasonable formula, including, but not limited to, the percentage of normal use and per capita or per consumer restrictions; 
(5)  Complete or partial bans on the waste of water; and 
(6)  Any combination of the measures set forth in subsections (1)-(5) of this section. 
(Ord. No. 2680, § 7, 8-21-2000) 
Sec. 86-58. - Emergency water rates. 
    Upon the declaration of a water supply emergency as provided in section 86-55, the governing body of the board of public utilities shall have the power to adopt emergency water rates by ordinance, designed to conserve water supplies. Such emergency rates may provide for, but are not limited to: 
(1)  Higher charges for increasing usage per unit of use (increasing block rates); 
(2)  Uniform charges for water usage per unit of use (uniform unit rate); or 
(3)  Extra charges in excess of a specified level of water use (excess demand surcharge). 
(Ord. No. 2680, § 8, 8-21-2000) 
Sec. 86-59. - Regulations. 
    During the effective period of any water supply emergency as provided for in section 86-55, the general manager of the BPU is empowered to promulgate such regulations as may be necessary to carry out the provisions of this division, any water supply emergency resolution or emergency water rate ordinance. Such regulations shall be subject to the approval of the governing body at its next regular or special meeting. 
(Ord. No. 2680, § 9, 8-21-2000) 
Sec. 86-60. - Emergency termination. 
    Nothing in this division shall limit the ability of any properly authorized BPU official from terminating the supply of water to any or all customers upon the determination of such BPU official that emergency termination of water service is required to protect the health and safety of the public. 
(Ord. No. 2680, § 11, 8-21-2000) 
Sec. 86-61. - Violations; termination of service. 
(a)  If the general manager of the BPU, assistant manager of the BPU or any other utility official charged by the governing body of the BPU with implementation and enforcement of this division or a water supply emergency resolution learns of any violation of any water use restriction imposed pursuant to section 86-57 or 86-59, a written notice of the violation shall be affixed to the property where the violation occurred and the customer of record or any other person known to the BPU who is responsible for the violation or its correction shall be provided with either an actual or mailed notice. Such notice shall describe the violation and order that such violation be corrected, cured or abated immediately or within such specified time as the BPU determines is reasonable under the circumstances. If the order is not complied with, the BPU may terminate water service to the customer, subject to the following procedures: 
(1)  The BPU shall give the customer either an actual or mailed notice that water service will be discontinued within a specified time due to the violation and that the customer will have the opportunity to appeal the termination by requesting a hearing scheduled before the BPU governing body or a BPU official designated as a hearing officer by the governing body; 
(2)  If such a hearing is requested by the customer charged with the violation, he shall be given a full opportunity to be heard before termination is ordered; and 
(3)  The governing body or hearing officer shall make findings of fact and order whether service be continued or terminated. 
(b)  A fee as set by resolution of the governing body shall be paid for the reconnection of any water service terminated pursuant to subsection (a) of this section. In the event of subsequent violations, the reconnection fee shall be as set by resolution of the governing body for the second reconnection and any additional reconnections. 
(c)  Violations of this division shall be a municipal offense and may be prosecuted in municipal court. Any person so charged and found guilty in municipal court of violating the provisions of this division shall be guilty of a municipal offense. Each day's violation shall constitute an offense. 
(Ord. No. 2680, § 10, 8-21-2000) 
Secs. 86-62-86-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SEWERS AND SEWAGE DISPOSAL[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Sewers and drains, § 18-671 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 86-91. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    ASTM means the American Society for Testing Materials or publications thereof. 
    BOD (denoting biochemical oxygen demand) means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in five days, at 20 degrees Celsius, expressed in milligrams per liter. 
    Building drain means that part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system which receives the discharge from soil, waste and other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to the building sewer, beginning two feet outside the building wall. 
    Building sewer means the extension from the building drain to the public sewer or other place of disposal. 
    City inspector means the city inspector of the city or his authorized deputy, agent or representative. 
    Combined sewer means a sewer receiving surface water, runoff water and wastewater. 
    Footing drain means a drainage system used to surround the outer walls of a building. 
    Garbage means solid wastes from the domestic and commercial preparation, cooking and dispensing of food and from the handling, storage and sale of produce. 
    Health officer means a person having public health responsibility by the state or the county. 
    Industrial wastes means the liquid wastes from industrial manufacturing processes, trades or businesses as distinct from sanitary sewage. 
    Natural outlet means any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake or other body of surface water or groundwater. 
    pH means the logarithm of the reciprocal of the weight of hydrogen ions in grams per liter of solution. 
    Properly shredded garbage means the wastes from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food that have been shredded to such a degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater than one-half inch (1.27 centimeters) in any dimension. 
    Public sewer means a sewer in which all owners of abutting properties have equal rights and is controlled by public property. 
    Sanitary sewer means a sewer which carries wastewater and to which stormwater, surface water and groundwater are not intentionally admitted. 
    Sewer means a pipe or conduit for carrying sewage. 
    Slug means any discharge of water, wastewater or industrial waste which, in concentration of any given constituent or in quantity of flow, exceeds, for any period of duration longer than 15 minutes, more than five times the average 24-hour concentration or flows during normal operation. 
    Storm drain and storm sewer mean a sewer which carries stormwater, surface water and drainage, but excludes wastewater and industrial wastes, other than unpolluted cooling water. 
    Suspended solids means solids that are in suspension in water, wastewater or other liquids, and which are removable by laboratory filtering. 
    Wastewater means a combination of the water-carried wastes from residences, business buildings, institutions and industrial establishments, together with such groundwater, surface water and stormwater as may be present. 
    Wastewater collection system means all facilities for collecting and pumping of wastewater. 
    Wastewater treatment plant means any arrangement of devices and structures used for treating wastewater. 
    Watercourse means a channel in which a flow of water occurs, either continuously or intermittently. 
    WEF means the Water Environment Federation or publications thereof. 
    Uniform Plumbing Code means the Uniform Plumbing Code incorporated by section 18-611. 
(Code 1995, § 15-401) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 86-92. - Right of entry for inspections; confidentiality of information; observation of safety rules. 
(a)  The director of public works and other duly authorized employees of the city bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter all properties for the purposes of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling and testing in accordance with the provisions of this article. Information and data on a user obtained from reports, questionnaires, permit applications, permits, monitoring programs and inspections shall be available to the public or other governmental agencies without restriction unless the user specifically requests and is able to demonstrate to the satisfaction of the city that the release of such information would divulge information, processes or methods of production entitled to protection as trade secrets or secret processes of the user. When requested by the person furnishing a report, the portions of a report which might disclose trade secrets or secret processes shall not be made available for inspection or copying by the public, but shall be made available upon written request to the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) or state department of health and environment (KDHE), without notice to the person furnishing the report, for uses related to this article, the National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) permit and/or the pretreatment programs; provided, however, that such portions of a report shall be available for use by the state or any state agency in judicial review or enforcement proceedings involving the person furnishing the report. Wastewater constituents and characteristics will not be recognized as confidential information. 
(b)  While performing the necessary work on all properties referred to in subsection (a) of this section, the director of public works or duly authorized employees of the city shall observe all safety rules applicable to the premises established by the company and the company shall be held harmless for injury or death to the city employees and the city shall indemnify the company against loss or damage to its property by city employees and against liability claims and demands for personal injury or property damage asserted against the company and growing out of the gauging and sampling operations, except as such injury or damage may be caused by negligence or failure of the company to maintain safe conditions as required. 
(Code 1995, §§ 15-437, 15-438) 
Sec. 86-93. - Use of public sewers required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place or deposit, or permit to be deposited, in any unsanitary manner, on public or private property within the city or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city, any human or animal excrement, garbage or other objectionable waste. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet within the city or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city any wastewater or other polluted water, except where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with subsequent provisions of this article. 
(c)  Except as provided in this article, it shall be unlawful to construct or maintain any septic tank or other facility intended or used for the disposal of wastewater. 
(d)  The owner of any house, building or property used for human occupancy, employment, recreation or other purposes, situated within the city and abutting any street, alley or right-of-way in which a public sanitary sewer of the city is or may be located, is hereby required, at his expense, to install suitable toilet facilities therein and to connect such facilities directly with the proper public sewer in accordance with the provisions of this article within 90 days after the date of official notice to do so, provided that the public sewer is within 100 feet of the property line. 
(Code 1995, §§ 15-402-15-405) 
Sec. 86-94. - Areas outside city limits. 
    No sewer connection will be permitted for areas outside the city limits until the developer or owner obtains a permit from the city clerk (see section 18-71). Any sewer lines needed to connect with existing city sewer mains and laterals must conform to city and state specifications. In order to obtain sewer service, the city reserves the privilege of furnishing, at its option, any or all utilities, specifically water or electricity. As a further condition of permitting sewer service for areas outside the city limits, the owners of property served must agree to permit annexation of such properties when such action is deemed necessary by the city. 
(Code 1995, § 15-406) 
Sec. 86-95. - Sewer connection fee within city limits. 
(a)  There is hereby established and imposed a sewer connection fee of as set by resolution of the governing body for service to each residential dwelling house, commercial or retail business establishment, apartment house or building, mobile home park or court, industrial plant or other unit situated within the city limits which requires connection to the city sewer system. The fee shall be charged for all property wholly or partially outside of an established sewer district, for the privilege of connecting the unit to the sewer system. The fee shall be reduced in proportion to the ratio that the area of the property which is within an established sewer district bears to the entire area of the property, and if such property shall, within three years immediately following the making of such connection, be taken into a sewer district and be assessed for the construction of sanitary sewers, laterals and mains, the connection fee shall be returned to the owner of the property at the time the assessment for such sewer district is made. 
(b)  Such sewer connections as provided for in subsection (a) of this section shall be permitted only upon receiving a permit from the director of public works and upon payment in full of the connection fee. 
(Code 1995, §§ 15-102, 15-103; Ord. No. 2551, § 1(15-102), 3-31-1997) 
Sec. 86-96. - Sewer connections outside city limits. 
(a)  The owner of any property situated outside of, but adjacent to, the city, upon proving himself to the satisfaction of the city attorney to be the owner of such property, and upon compliance with the provisions, restrictions and limitations of this article and all other ordinances of the city pertaining to building construction, plumbing and electrical installation, and public health, safety and sanitation, may make application, as a concession, but not as a matter of right, for a license to connect such property to the city's sewer system and to discharge usual and ordinary wastewater into the city's sewer system. If such property shall, within three years immediately following the making of such connection, be taken into a city sewer district and be assessed for the construction of sanitary sewers, laterals and mains, the connection fee shall be returned to the owner of the property at the time the assessment for such sewer district is made. 
(b)  Any such owner desiring to make such a sewer connection shall apply in writing to the city clerk for a permit to do so. The application shall be signed by all of the owners of the premises and will constitute a contract by such owners to comply with applicable city ordinances and to submit to any penalties for a violation thereof. Such application shall state the: 
(1)  Legal description of the premises; 
(2)  Names and addresses of the legal, equitable and beneficial owners of the premises and the source of their title; 
(3)  Number and kind of sewer intake openings to be connected; 
(4)  Exact point of the proposed connection; and 
(5)  Applicants will comply with this article and all other present and future ordinances of the city the same as though such premises were within the city. 
(c)  The city clerk, upon receiving such application, shall present it to the governing body at its next regular meeting. Such governing body, if it finds that all requirements of this article have been complied with and that the sewer to which the applicant desires to connect is not, and will not become, overloaded and that wastewater from such premises can be disposed of without expense to the city in excess of the amount of the license fee as set forth in subsection (d) of this section, may direct the city clerk to issue the license applied for. The licensee shall pay all costs of lines, pipes, connections, fixtures and other charges for making the sewer connection. 
(d)  There is hereby established and imposed a fee as set by resolution of the governing body for the connection of any property outside the corporate limits of the city to the city sewer system. The sewer connection fee shall be paid in full at the time a license is granted. 
(e)  This section shall apply equally to all persons and property connected to the city sewer system beyond the city limits. The property shall be subject to the same inspections as are provided for within the city. 
(Code 1995, §§ 15-104-15-108; Ord. No. 2551, § 1(15-105, 15-107), 3-31-1997) 
Sec. 86-97. - Sewer connection surcharge. 
(a)  There is hereby imposed on each new sanitary sewer connection made after the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived, to provide sanitary sewer service to any lot or tract of land, or part thereof, which has not previously been assessed, a sewer connection surcharge (i.e., a charge in addition to other charges imposed by this article for connection to, or use of, the city's sanitary sewer system) in such amounts and determined in such methods as are set forth in this section. 
(b)  Except as noted, each residential unit making a separate connection to the city's sanitary sewer system shall be assessed a sewer connection surcharge (referred to in this section as the "connection surcharge"). Notwithstanding the above, for any multi-family residential structures that have common legal ownership of such residential units, the connection surcharge shall be assessed the connection surcharge per tap plus a unit fee multiplied by the number of units. The connection surcharge and the unit fee shall be set from time to time by resolution of the governing body. For purposes of determining the connection surcharge, the term "multi-family residential unit" means a duplex, triplex, fourplex, apartment, apartment buildings or mobile home dwelling units, but does not include a condominium or detached single family residence. The connection surcharge and unit fee, if any, shall be due and payable at the time the residential unit is connected to the city's sanitary sewer system. The connection surcharge shall be in addition to any other fees or charges payable upon connection to the city's sanitary sewer system. 
(c)  Each nonresidential unit making a separate connection to the city's sanitary sewer system shall be assessed a nonresidential connection surcharge. For purposes of this section, the term "nonresidential use" includes manufacturing, industrial, commercial, school or nonprofit organization users, other than a residential use owned or operated by a commercial business or nonprofit organization. For each nonresidential use, the initial nonresidential connection surcharge shall be 75 percent of the base connection surcharge for a residential unit. A second nonresidential connection surcharge shall be made 18 months after assessment of the initial connection surcharge. The second nonresidential connection surcharge shall be an amount equal to $550.00 for each 6,700 gallons of water actually used on the premises on an average monthly basis during the 18-month prove-up period. Water use on the premises shall be determined by the records of the water department of the city's board of public utilities. Credit shall be given against the second surcharge for the amount previously paid as an initial connection surcharge. Any nonresidential user may install a sewer meter on the premises to measure the amount of water discharged into the city's sanitary sewer system. If such a meter is installed and measures a discharge of water over at least 12 of the 18 months of the prove-up period, then the second connection surcharge shall be based on actual average monthly gallons of wastewater actually discharged into the city's sanitary sewer system during the prove-up period. 
(d)  With respect to any nonresidential user, the governing body may, from time to time, by resolution, modify the connection surcharge set forth in an ordinance for any particular nonresidential user, taking into account such matters as the quantity or quality of industrial waste discharged into the city's sanitary sewer system, water consumed in a user's industrial or manufacturing process or evaporated for cooling purposes and any other factor which may reasonably be determined to affect the quantity or quality of water discharged into the sanitary sewer system. Upon the enactment of such a resolution the connection surcharge for such industrial users shall be assessed as set forth in this section. 
(e)  For each separate new sewer connection to the city's sanitary sewer system for a user located outside the corporate limits of the city where the lot or tract of land, or part thereof, has not previously been assessed a connection surcharge, the connection surcharge shall be 150 percent of the connection surcharge determined as otherwise set forth in this section. 
(f)  If the use of an installation previously connected to the city's sanitary sewer system changes so as to increase the rate of discharge of water into the city's sanitary sewer system, the city may reclassify the user and assess an additional connection surcharge based upon the new classification. An 18-month prove-up period shall be allowed after the reclassification, during which period, water use data shall be assembled as in the case of a new nonresidential user. At the end of the prove-up period, the additional connection surcharge, if any, shall be due and payable. Credit shall be given against the amount calculated for the connection surcharge previously paid. If a use is changed so that a smaller amount of water is discharged into the city's sanitary sewer system than under the previous use, no refund of the previously paid connection surcharge shall be made. A change in the volume or characteristics of wastewater discharged by any user may be determined to be a change in use. 
(g)  Nothing in this section shall be construed as restricting the ability of the city to enter into special contractual arrangements with new users for the payment of such connection surcharges, or waive connection surcharges, as the governing body may deem to be in the best interests of the city's sewer utility or the community at large. 
(h)  The final cost for connection surcharge shall be calculated and verified by the city's director of public works or by his/her designee after a request is made for a new sewer connection. The director of public works may require a written application for sewer service, identifying the name of the owner and legal description of the lot or tract of land to which sewer service is to be extended, a description of the intended use of the property after the sewer connection is made, the estimated volume of wastewater discharge to be made pursuant to such use, any unusual characteristics of such wastewater and any other information deemed necessary in order to make a determination of the amount of the connection surcharge. At such time as the director of public works has made a determination of the amount of the connection surcharge, the owner of the property to be served will be rendered a bill for the amount of the connection surcharge, or the initial payment, if the proposed use is a nonresidential use. If any owner or lessee of a lot or tract of land believes that the use of the property has been improperly characterized by the director of public works, such owner or lessee may appeal such determination to the governing body. The governing body's action on any such appeal shall be final. If a determination of the amount of the surcharge has not been made at the time of connection to the sanitary sewer system, the owner shall pay the minimum connection surcharge for a residential or nonresidential use, as the case may be, and shall pay the balance upon receipt of a bill for such amount. Billings will be made only to the record owners of the properties to be served, and if a connection is made before the entire connection surcharge is made, then the city shall have a lien on the property served for the amount of the unpaid surcharge. The city may perfect its lien by filing a notice of lien with the county register of deeds, which notice must contain a legal description of the property subject to the lien, the names of the record owners of the property, the amount of the unpaid connection surcharge, the date on which the billing for the connection surcharge was made and a reference to this section or the corresponding section of this Code. If it becomes necessary for the city to foreclose its lien, the lien must be foreclosed in the manner provided by statute for mechanic's and materialman's liens, other than the statute of limitations for the filing of such actions, which shall not apply to actions to foreclose the city's lien. 
(i)  Payment of the connection surcharges imposed by this section shall ordinarily be due not later than the time of issuance of a building permit by the city. The city inspector may withhold issuance of a building permit until all connection fees due have been paid. In the case of a nonresidential user, payment due at the time of issuance of the building permit shall be the initial connection surcharge. 
(j)  All connection surcharge payments received by the city shall be deposited in the city's sewer utility system surplus fund, as such fund exists or may be modified in the discretion of the governing body. Application of such moneys shall be for the benefit of the city's sanitary sewer system as determined in the discretion of the governing body. 
(k)  If a billing for a connection surcharge remains unpaid for more than 30 days past the mailing of the statement to the owner of the property at such owner's last known address, then the amount owing shall be considered delinquent, and there shall be added to the amount owing a penalty in the amount of ten percent of the amount past due, but not to exceed $500.00. In addition, interest at the maximum statutory rate shall begin to accrue on the unpaid amounts from the 30th day after mailing of the statement. In addition, the city may, upon ten days' written notice to the owner of the property, discontinue water service or sewer service, or both, to the owner or occupant of the subject property. If the property is being used for a residential use, then the notice of termination shall state the date, time and place of a hearing to be held upon the termination, at which time, the owner or occupant shall be permitted to show good cause why water service or sewer service, or both, should not be disconnected. Nothing in this section shall be construed as a waiver or estoppel affecting the city's rights to bring a civil action for the collection of unpaid service charges, connection surcharges, penalties or interest, or for foreclosure of its lien. 
(l)  With respect to any property newly annexed into the corporate limits of the city, which property is connected to the city's sanitary sewer system, the owner of such property shall be assessed connection surcharges in accordance with this section if the property has not previously been assessed a connection surcharge and paid such surcharge. 
(m)  Any person or tenant occupying land or representing the owner or occupant of land upon, or to, which a sanitary sewer connection has been knowingly made in violation of the provisions of this section shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(n)  Notwithstanding anything to the contrary, a new tap installed to replace an existing tap that presently has sewer service will be $200.00 for a new tap. This fee may be changed from time to time by resolution of the governing body. 
(Ord. No. 2616, §§ 1-13, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 3141, § 1, 5-12-2014; Ord. No. 3235, § 1, 1-3-2017) 
Sec. 86-98. - Tampering. 
    It shall be a misdemeanor for any person to: 
(1)  Tamper with any water main, fire main, water meter or sewer line; 
(2)  Make any connection to the water or sewer system of the city without written permission from the city; or 
(3)  Reconnect service when it has been disconnected for nonpayment of a bill for service until such bill has been paid in full. 
(Code 1995, § 15-211) 
Sec. 86-99. - Damage and destruction. 
    No unauthorized person shall maliciously, willfully or negligently break, damage, destroy, uncover, deface or tamper with any structure, appurtenance or equipment which is a part of the wastewater treatment works. 
(Code 1995, § 15-436) 
Sec. 86-100. - Violations; liability. 
(a)  Any person found to be violating any provision of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(b)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall become liable to the city for any expense, loss or damage occasioned the city by reason of such violation, including such fines, penalties and other costs which may be assessed to the city for violation of sewage treatment plant effluent requirements, where such violation was created by a user of the sewage works who, in turn, is in violation of city, state or federal regulations. 
(Code 1995, § 15-440) 
Secs. 86-101-86-120. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PRIVATE SEWAGE TREATMENT SYSTEM[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Septic tanks, § 18-620. 

Sec. 86-121. - Compliance. 
    Where a public sanitary sewer is not available under the provisions of section 86-93, the building sewer shall be connected to a private wastewater treatment system complying with the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1995, § 15-407) 
Sec. 86-122. - Additional requirements imposed by health officer. 
    No statement contained in this division shall be construed to interfere with any additional requirements that may be imposed by the health officer. 
(Code 1995, § 15-413) 
Sec. 86-123. - Permit required. 
    Before commencement of construction of a private wastewater treatment system, the owner shall first obtain a written permit signed by the director of public works. The application for such permit shall be made on a form furnished by the city, which the applicant shall supplement by any plans, specifications and other information as are deemed necessary by the director of public works. A permit and inspection fee as set by resolution of the governing body shall be paid to the city at the time the application is filed. 
(Code 1995, § 15-408) 
Sec. 86-124. - Inspection by director of public works. 
    A permit for a private wastewater treatment system shall not become effective until the installation is completed to the satisfaction of the director of public works. The director of public works shall be allowed to inspect the work at any stage of construction and, in any event, the applicant for the permit shall notify the director of public works when the work is ready for final inspection and before any underground portions are covered. The inspection shall be made within 96 hours of the receipt of notice by the director of public works or his representative. 
(Code 1995, § 15-409) 
Cross reference- Appointed officers and employees generally, § 2-81 et seq. 
Sec. 86-125. - Compliance with state health recommendations required. 
    The type, capacity, location and layout of a private wastewater treatment system shall comply with all recommendations of the state department of health and environment. No permit shall be issued for any private wastewater treatment system employing subsurface soil absorption facilities where the area of the lot is less than 20,000 square feet, when a public water supply is used. In the case of a private water supply, the minimum lot size will be 40,000 square feet. No septic tank or cesspool system shall be permitted to discharge to any natural outlet. 
(Code 1995, § 15-410) 
Sec. 86-126. - Operation and maintenance. 
    The owner shall operate and maintain the private wastewater treatment facility in a sanitary manner at all times at no expense to the city. 
(Code 1995, § 15-412) 
Sec. 86-127. - Direct connection with public sewer required upon availability. 
    At such time as a public sewer becomes available to a property served by a private wastewater treatment system, as provided in section 86-125, a direct connection shall be made to the public sewer in compliance with this article, and any septic tank, cesspool and similar private wastewater treatment facility shall be cleaned and filled in accordance with section 86-128. 
(Code 1995, § 15-411) 
Sec. 86-128. - Time limit for connection with public sewer. 
    When a public sewer becomes available, the building sewer shall be connected to the public sewer within 60 days and the private wastewater treatment system shall be cleaned of sludge and filled with clean bank run gravel, locally available chat or dirt. 
(Code 1995, § 15-414) 
Secs. 86-129-86-150. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - BUILDING SEWERS AND CONNECTIONS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18. 

Sec. 86-151. - Permit required. 
    No unauthorized person shall uncover, make any connection with or opening into, use, alter or disturb any public sewer, or appurtenance thereof, without first obtaining a written permit from the city inspector. 
(Code 1995, § 15-415) 
Sec. 86-152. - Class of permit; application; inspection fees. 
    There shall be one class of building sewer permit for residential and commercial services. The owner or his agent shall make application for such permit on a special form furnished by the city. The permit application shall be supplemented by any plans, specifications or other information considered pertinent in the judgment of the city engineer and/or city inspector. A permit and the following inspection fees for residential or commercial building sewer permits shall be paid to the city at the time the application is filed: 
PLUMBING INSPECTION Item Fee Lavatories ..... As set by resolution of the governing body Sinks ..... As set by resolution of the governing body Bathtubs ..... As set by resolution of the governing body Closets ..... As set by resolution of the governing body Cellar drains ..... As set by resolution of the governing body Slop sinks ..... As set by resolution of the governing body Disposals ..... As set by resolution of the governing body Urinals ..... As set by resolution of the governing body Automobile washer ..... As set by resolution of the governing body Dishwasher ..... As set by resolution of the governing body Drinking fountain ..... As set by resolution of the governing body Sewer ..... As set by resolution of the governing body Water softener ..... As set by resolution of the governing body  
(Code 1995, § 15-416) 
Sec. 86-153. - Responsibility for installation and connection costs and expenses. 
    All costs and expenses incidental to the installation and connection of the building sewer shall be borne by the owner. The owner shall indemnify the city from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned by the installation of the building sewer. 
(Code 1995, § 15-417) 
Sec. 86-154. - Provision of separate and independent building sewers. 
    A separate and independent building sewer shall be provided for every residential dwelling unit except for adult care homes, hospitals, boarding or rooming houses, group homes, hotels, nursing or convalescent homes, rehabilitation homes, multi-story apartment buildings or other extraordinary situations, if approved in writing by the public works director. No condominium or lot split shall be allowed of any residential property within the city that does not provide for each dwelling unit to have a separate and independent sewer with a separate sewer tap. The definitions contained within the city's zoning regulations shall guide interpretation of this section. 
(Code 1995, § 15-418; Ord. No. 3279, § 1, 8-13-2018) 
Sec. 86-155. - Old building sewers. 
    Old building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings only when such sewers are found, on examination and test by the city inspector, to meet all requirements of this article. 
(Code 1995, § 15-419) 
Sec. 86-156. - Construction. 
    The size, slope, alignment and materials of construction of a building sewer, and the methods to be used in excavating and backfilling the trench, installing jointing and testing the building sewer shall conform to the uniform plumbing code, with the following modifications: 
(1)  Minimum internal pipeline diameter for all building sewers shall be four inches; 
(2)  Building sewers shall be constructed of one of the following pipeline materials: 
a.  Extra strength vitrified clay pipeline and fittings, conforming to ASTM C 70074; 
b.  Polyvinyl chloride (PVC) gravity sewer pipe and fittings, Type PSP or PSM, conforming to ASTM standard D 3033-75 or D 3034-74. All PVC sewer pipe shall be schedule 40; 
c.  Cast iron or ductile iron pipe of class 150, conforming to federal specification WW P-421b or ANSI A21.6 or A21.8, except that iron used in the manufacture of pipe shall have a minimum design strength value, in pounds per square inch, of 21,000 for bursting strength and 45,000 for modules of rupture. 
(Code 1995, § 15-420) 
Sec. 86-157. - Elevation. 
    The building sewer shall be brought to the building at an elevation of two feet below the basement floor. At the election of the builder, the building sewer may be installed just under the basement floor and imbedded in sand, provided that a grade of one-fourth inch per foot be maintained to within three feet above and from the sanitary sewer main. If the latter election is exercised, a 45-degree bend will be required to connect the building sewer to the sewer main. In all buildings in which weather option may be exercised because the building drain installation is too low to meet such requirements, a gate valve or combination check and gate valve shall be installed and made accessible for operation and maintenance, or in the alternative, an approved sanitary sewer lift pump method may be used. 
(Code 1995, § 15-421) 
Sec. 86-158. - Prohibited connections. 
    No person shall make a connection of a roof downspout, exterior foundation, exterior foundation drain, areaway drain or other source of surface runoff or groundwater to a building sewer or building drain which in turn is directly or indirectly connected to a public sanitary sewer. 
(Code 1995, § 15-422) 
Sec. 86-159. - Connection rules and regulations. 
    The connection of a building sewer into the public sewer shall conform to the requirements of the uniform plumbing code or other applicable rules and regulations of the city. All such connections shall be made gastight and watertight. Any deviation from the prescribed procedures and materials must be approved by the city inspector before installation. 
(Code 1995, § 15-423) 
Sec. 86-160. - Notification of readiness for inspection and connection. 
    The applicant for a building sewer permit shall notify the city inspector when the building sewer is ready for inspection and connection to the public sewer. The connection shall be made under the supervision of the city inspector or his representative within 96 hours of the receipt of the notice by the city inspector. 
(Code 1995, § 15-424) 
Sec. 86-161. - Excavations.
